text:
**Garbage in, garbage out**

Charging families for each bag of rubbish they throw away seems like a good idea for the environment and for saving money. However, it might not be as effective as it seems. In many developed countries, rubbish collection happens regularly. Rubbish bags or bins are taken away by special trucks to be disposed of. Economists find this strange because, in most places, this service is free. Families pay for it through local taxes, but a family that produces a lot of rubbish pays the same as a couple that produces very little. 

The cost of rubbish disposal is not zero. The more rubbish people throw away, the more collectors and trucks are needed, and the more local authorities have to pay for landfills. This creates a basic economic problem: if rubbish disposal is free, people will produce too much rubbish. A possible solution is to make households pay for the amount of rubbish they produce. This would encourage them to throw away less and recycle more, assuming local governments provide places to recycle.

However, economists Don Fullerton and Thomas Kinnaman found that this logical solution can lead to complicated and sometimes disappointing results. They studied several American towns that started charging households for rubbish. The most common method was to sell stickers or tags that families had to attach to their rubbish bags. Only bags with these tags would be collected each week.

In a study published last year, Fullerton and Kinnaman looked at a scheme introduced in Charlottesville, Virginia, where residents were charged 80 cents for each tagged bag. While this seemed like a good use of market forces, the benefits of the scheme did not cover the costs of printing tags, paying sellers, and running the program. Although the number of bags collected fell by 37%, this was mainly because people started cramming more rubbish into each bag instead of buying more tags. This method of compacting rubbish is not as effective as using machines at landfills. The actual weight of rubbish collected only fell by 14%. 

In 25 other Virginia cities without a pricing scheme, rubbish collection also fell by 3.5%. Some people even chose to dump their rubbish illegally instead of paying for collection. Although it is hard to measure, the authors estimate that illegal dumping might account for 30-40% of the reduction in collected rubbish. 

On a positive note, there was a 15% increase in the weight of materials recycled, suggesting that people chose to recycle (which is free) instead of paying for rubbish removal. However, many residents were already participating in a voluntary recycling program before the fee was introduced. 

In a more recent study, Fullerton and Kinnaman looked deeper into the economics of rubbish. They found that while pricing does reduce the amount of rubbish, the effect is small. On average, a 10% increase in sticker prices only cuts rubbish by 0.3%. This is less than in other studies, but it makes sense. To significantly reduce rubbish, people would need to buy less of everything. A small tax on rubbish is unlikely to make a big difference. 

It is also important to consider other factors, like income and education. For example, richer towns tend to throw away more rubbish and have less time for recycling. Should we say that charging households for rubbish is a bad idea? Not really; free disposal is probably too cheap. However, the effects of simple policies can be complex. Detailed economic models are often needed to understand them, and sometimes the results are not what we expect.

**Work and Change: Theodore Zeldin's Ideas**

Theodore Zeldin explores how our work life could improve. Do you feel respected and valued in your job? Simply being successful in your career is not enough anymore. Many people in different professions feel that their work is not appreciated, and even famous individuals often feel unhappy despite their success. 

In the past, loving your job was enough to make you feel special. Now, it’s important to think about how your job affects you as a person, your mind, character, and relationships. This is a vital question. No matter how skilled you are, if your work makes you boring or unable to connect with others, then no amount of money or status can make up for that. 

Zeldin wants to find ways to make work more fulfilling and meaningful for everyone, not just a way to make money. Work should help us live better lives, discover new talents, and meet different people. However, simply trying to eliminate unemployment is not enough. As more people get educated, they want jobs that are interesting and meaningful.

Even traditional professions, like doctors and accountants, are facing challenges. Doctors often feel more stressed than their patients, and accountants worry about their profession's ethics. Many architects do not get to use their creativity, and middle managers are losing their confidence. Companies and organizations are becoming smaller, and many employees feel disconnected from their work. In Britain, only 8% of workers feel that their values match those of their organizations.

Zeldin is studying different jobs to see how they affect people. He is looking at important topics like happiness, love, friendship, and respect. He believes we need to think about who we want to be and how we want to live, not just focus on making money.

For example, in the hospitality industry, which employs 10% of the workforce, many talented people work in low-paying jobs with little recognition. Hotels could be more than just places for travelers to sleep; they could be cultural centers where people from different backgrounds meet and connect. Hotel staff, many of whom are eager to learn and explore, often have only superficial interactions with guests. 

If hotels paid attention to their employees' ambitions, they could offer more services and create a richer experience for guests. However, many businesses focus only on maximizing profits, which limits their potential. 

Zeldin believes that work should be about relationships. As people seek more independence in their jobs, they should have the opportunity to design their own roles and choose their colleagues. This requires good communication skills, which go beyond just talking. 

True conversation creates a bond of respect and understanding between people. It allows us to connect deeply and can change our perspectives. Every meaningful conversation can make a small difference in the world.

**BROADCASTING: The Social Shaping of a Technology**

The term 'broadcasting' originally referred to spreading seeds widely by hand. This idea is not just about farming; it also represents a hopeful view of modern progress. It suggests planned growth and the potential for a good outcome if conditions are right. The metaphor assumes there are central resources available for spreading and sharing information.

We need to explore why a new technology that sends words and pictures electronically was organized in a way that fits this farming metaphor. Television, as a technology, is connected to other forms of communication like the telegraph and telephone. However, from the beginning, it was seen as a centralized 'mass' medium. This means that it was designed to send information from a central source to many homes, which matched the social and economic structures of modern societies.

There were attempts to create different ways of using television, but these remained just experiments. Two lesser-known alternatives are worth mentioning because they show what television could have been in a different social setting. In the early 1930s, radio enthusiasts in Britain experimented with two-way television as a possible replacement for regular telephones. Popular science magazines like Radio News published articles on how to build television transmitters and receivers, and many amateurs were active in this field.

However, in 1938, the British Radio Manufacturers Association set standards for television equipment and channel regulations, which pushed these grassroots innovators out. This marked the end of a chance for television to develop as a more democratic and community-based form of communication in Britain.

Broadcasting was not only influenced by strong economic interests but also by the deep structures of modern societies. Despite the efforts of TV amateurs, television was mainly used for public shows in the USA during the early 1930s and was seen as a competitor to the film industry. In fact, most early audiences in Britain and Germany experienced television in public places rather than at home.

The idea of grassroots or amateur two-way television was unlikely to succeed. Instead, television systems based on public viewing were operating in several countries in the 1930s. However, manufacturers recognized the potential for mass sales of home television sets, and as working-class people improved their living standards from the 1920s onwards, the dream of having a fully equipped home for entertainment became a reality for many in Western countries. This trend is now happening globally.

There is a clear link between social modernization and the structures of broadcasting. As societies modernized, there was more centralization of power and capital, and traditional communities broke apart, leading to new lifestyles. People became more mobile, both socially and geographically, which made them feel more isolated compared to those in stable early communities.

Centralized broadcasting was a way for governments to efficiently reach all citizens with important information. It also helped create a sense of community within the nation-state. These processes made broadcasting the dominant form of both radio and television.

However, it is important to recognize the positive view of broadcasting as a tool for democracy. During the time between the World Wars, many countries saw broadcasting as a way to ensure equal access to information, which is necessary for informed participation in political, social, and cultural life.

Television is changing, and there is a risk that the term broadcasting may become outdated or insufficient. If that happens, this metaphor will only refer to a specific way of organizing audio-visual technology during a certain phase of social modernization.

**Clutter**

Sometimes, it feels like no matter how many things you own, you still don’t feel secure. It is normal to want a comfortable home that meets your needs, but there comes a point when the desire to own more things becomes excessive. Modern advertising is designed to take advantage of our insecurities. We often receive messages that suggest if we don’t have certain products, we are not as good as others. To see how much advertising affects you, try not to read any billboards the next time you walk down the street. These expensive advertisements influence us in ways we may not even notice. We are surrounded by them on television, radio, newspapers, magazines, posters, t-shirts, and the internet, all encouraging us to buy more.

**Caves**

Research institutions and universities around the world have spent many years studying caves, focusing on their origins, water systems, and living organisms. Caves are a small but fascinating part of nature that spark our curiosity and desire to learn. Because they are natural features, they have been studied for a long time, especially in areas where caves impact our lives. However, exploring caves requires physical skill, which means that cave research often involves both professional scientists and amateur explorers who visit caves for fun.

**Weather Watch**

Many observant people, using only their senses, laid the groundwork for meteorology, which has developed into a complex science since the 17th century. Today, satellites and electronic tools provide us with quick weather information, and computers can solve complicated calculations much faster than humans. Meteorology uses many technical terms that can be hard to understand for non-professionals. However, human experience is still essential for turning data into weather forecasts. Personal observations can offer valuable insights that help professionals understand the mysteries of the atmosphere.

**MUSIC AND THEATRE**

Until recently, I believed that opera was mainly about theatre. Now, I think differently. After working at a national opera house, I realized that music is actually the most important part of opera. This makes sense, of course. However, I come from the world of theatre, where the words and the actors are the main focus. In theatre, once the performance starts, there is no one directing the action, and the performers and the audience usually share the same language.

At any music performance, whether in a concert hall or an opera house, there are many people, like me, who do not have a deep understanding of music. Some may feel embarrassed about their lack of knowledge, while most are amazed by the talent of the musicians. A skilled singer or a great string section is easy to admire. Even a good musician shows us the results of years of hard work. Watching top-class music is similar to watching an athletics event. We know that athletes are doing something similar to what we do when we run for a bus, but we also see how much better they are.

Theatre audiences have different expectations. They often do not understand the skills of actors and may not be impressed by an actor delivering a long speech, even though they often ask, "How do you remember all those lines?" This does not mean that theatre audiences are less demanding than music audiences; in fact, many people enjoy both. However, in theatre, audiences and performers often meet on more equal ground, regardless of how difficult the material is.

The question is whether music can learn anything from theatre about this relationship. I believe it can. I have seen how a different approach can improve the experience for concert-goers. Live music is very theatrical, filled with emotions like passion, humor, and sadness. It connects with the audience not just as individuals but as a group. The traditional ways of presenting music, such as strict dress codes and showing too much respect for conductors and soloists, create a clear divide between performers and listeners, which can feel uncomfortable.

On the other hand, when contemporary music audiences applaud between movements or after a difficult piece, it can disrupt the flow of the performance. While this is often a genuine expression of appreciation, it can also be disrespectful to the overall work.

Is there a solution? Yes, a lot is being done to attract new audiences to concert halls and opera houses and to break down the barriers that make people feel that "serious" music is not for them. I remember a special event, the community opera "In Search of Angels," which took place in different locations within a cathedral and then moved into the town. It was an incredible musical experience where the skills and generosity of the professional musicians were key, and it changed the lives of many audience members, who were not just there to watch and listen but also to participate.

What I wish for in music is a bit more of the excitement and boldness that theatre can offer. This can come from using unusual or challenging locations that change our expectations. This can create surprising effects for both performers and audiences. Sometimes, we may have to give up comfort; the sound might not be perfect, or it could be a bit cold. However, theatre audiences have learned to be brave and follow artists into unexpected places.

I know that most plays are performed in a traditional way, similar to concerts. However, I believe that we can and should change how we experience music. I can only speak as a fan: I love theatre and enjoy going to music performances as much as I can. I want both to succeed and for more people to enjoy the pleasure I find in being part of the audience.

**Sand**  
Although I appreciate how sand can be turned into useful things like glass and concrete, I do not like it in its natural form. To me, sand is mostly a barrier that separates a parking lot from the beach. It blows into your face, gets into your food, and can even hide important items like car keys and coins. When you are wet, sand sticks to you and is hard to remove, even with a strong hose. However, once you step onto a beach towel, get into a car, or walk on a clean carpet, the sand falls off easily. For days, you will find sand everywhere when you take off your shoes, and even more will fall when you remove your socks. Sand seems to stay with you longer than some illnesses. So, I would prefer to avoid sand altogether.

**Lock and Key**  
The need for a safe home, privacy, and security has been important since people first built houses. While old wooden beams have been replaced by modern electronic locks that use plastic cards, the desire to keep out unwanted visitors remains. The idea of a lock and key is partly psychological. Recently, some companies have tried using computerized locking systems with smart cards, but many people do not like them. People may accept these systems at work, but at home, they prefer the comfort of using a physical key. Because of this, when a locksmith company created a new electronic lock, they included a traditional metal key in the design.

**Modern Art**  
I felt nervous about visiting the new Tate Modern gallery because, like many people, I find modern art confusing. I do enjoy some pieces, especially furry objects, neon light sculptures, and large photographs. Maybe if I knew more about modern art, I would have stronger opinions. However, the goal is not to analyze art like a school essay but to let it speak to you. This is a nice idea, but it has not worked for me in the past. The new gallery tries to help visitors understand the art better. The first thing I noticed was the informative labels that explain the context and meaning of each piece. Instead of just staring at the art, these explanations helped me to understand it better.

**Every Picture Tells a Story**

Adapting novels into films usually means reducing and simplifying the story. This can be frustrating for writers, but it can also be enlightening. While working on a script, I realized that I could remove a lot of dialogue and descriptions from a scene in the novel and still convey the same message. This doesn’t mean that the original dialogue and descriptions were unnecessary. It’s about how each medium engages the audience and the type of repetition they use.

In novels, repetition can help readers remember character traits and understand who is speaking. For example, we often see phrases like "he said" to make it easier to follow the conversation. In stage plays, the dialogue mimics real speech, sometimes to the point where it feels repetitive and doesn’t clearly communicate the message.

**Watching Movies**

When we watch movies, we can feel completely absorbed in the story, escaping from our everyday lives for the duration of the film. However, once the movie ends and the lights come on, we return to reality. Many people, especially from older generations, did not see movies as art; they viewed them as simple entertainment. While they enjoyed watching films, they did not consider them to have artistic value.

**The Film Studios**

The Leiper Film Company studios were made up of many different buildings that were confusing to navigate. There were a few main areas, like the Script Department, but most of the rooms looked the same and were hard to find. There were three main entrances, but none of them provided clear directions for newcomers. Most people who worked there knew their way around, and it was their teamwork that brought stories of romance and adventure to life on screen.

**Film-Makers**

Many people dream of making movies. Bookstores are filled with guides on scriptwriting and film production, and universities offer related courses. There are even competitions that give away cameras like the one used by Robert Rodriguez to make his film *El Mariachi*, which cost only $7,000 and launched his career. Rodriguez reflects on his early success, noting that famous directors like Orson Welles and Steven Spielberg made their breakthrough films at a young age.

In the past, filmmakers had to take their time to learn the craft, often starting in smaller roles like editing or writing. For example, John Huston was 35 when he directed his first film, *The Maltese Falcon*. Today, without the support of studios or television, new filmmakers often have to find their own way to succeed.

In the past, the council houses were spread all over the western side of the city. They were rows of small, old buildings made of orange brick or pale white plaster. In the summer, the chemicals from a nearby factory created a strong smell of sulphur that filled the air around the houses. One common sight in that part of Norwich in the morning was a paperboy making a face as he walked up to someone’s front door. I have forgotten much of my early life, but I remember sitting near an upstairs window and looking at the houses as they disappeared into the distance. 

I also have memories of my mother, who I remember ironing towels in a house that I don’t think was ours, and snow falling on a big mansion at Earlham. My mother appears in these early memories because I remember her as a small, precise, and often angry woman. I never really understood why she was angry, so I couldn’t do anything to make her feel better. Even as a child, when I went with her to small shops or on longer trips into the city, I sensed that she was a very lonely person, feeling alone even in a crowded room. 

My mother had strict ideas about how to behave, which were not common in our neighborhood. This sometimes led to intense cleaning sessions or her telling me to "behave properly." I never fully understood her rules, which included not going into neighbors' gardens or risking their rose bushes while walking down the street. It also meant sitting quietly for long periods in a dining room, listening to radio shows that my mother liked. There were many rules I had to follow.

Over time, I noticed other people in our lives. Despite her loneliness, my mother had a few friends. There was Mrs. Buddery, who loved the Royal Family, Mrs. Winall, who rarely spoke except to agree with others, and Mrs. Laband, who was more lively but not always liked by the others. Looking back, I realize that these women were not very good company. They often talked about their bad legs, the cold weather, and ungrateful children, a group I often felt I belonged to.

I felt a heavy weight from the houses, my mother, her friends, and the pressure to "behave properly." It felt like my job to grow up and free myself from this weight, but it was not easy. Growing up in West Earlham followed a clear pattern. Until you were five, you stayed at home and bothered your parents. I remember long, boring days playing on a rug while my mother sat coldly in a chair. Then, after your fifth birthday, you went to Avenue Road infants school, which was half a mile away. Some lucky kids had mothers who could ride them on a bike, but my mother usually let other children take care of me on the way.

If I remember anything from those early years, it’s the summer holidays. During those days, I caught glimpses of the world outside West Earlham. There was an old man next to Mrs. Buddery who told stories about his time in the Merchant Navy. Once, there was a charity event at a house far away where a kind woman offered lemonade and tried to get me interested in something called the League of Pity, a kind of junior charity. However, my mother dismissed it, saying the organizers were "only after your money." 

My mother often talked about money and had a very low opinion of politicians. If she thought about the House of Commons, she imagined it as a place where rich people opened letters filled with money sent by gullible people. I might be exaggerating, and I know she had some good qualities, but she didn’t show much kindness. 

To be fair, my mother was aware of her role in my education. Sometimes, she would take me on the bus to the Norwich Castle Museum. We would walk through rooms filled with paintings by local artists. My mother didn’t completely dislike this activity and eventually started to have opinions about the art. I remember one time she stopped in front of a painting of a Roman soldier and said, "Well, I wouldn’t like to meet him on a dark night!" This was one of the few times I remember her trying to make a joke.

**Philadelphia Avenue**

I walked down the odd-numbered side of Philadelphia Avenue. The evening was getting darker, and the air was humid with a light drizzle that made my walk feel secretive. I knew this side of the street very well; I remembered our neighbors, the Matzes and the Pritchards, Han Kieffer's grocery store, and the houses of my first friends, all girls. Even though I didn’t know everyone by name, each house was clear in my memory, just like the small channels in the sidewalk that carried rainwater from the roofs to the street. As the street sloped down, I noticed that the houses changed too: the porches got lower, and the front yards became smaller.

Over the years, things changed. Wooden porch railings were replaced with iron ones that looked a bit Southern or Spanish. In Shillington, some houses I remembered as homes became stores, and strangely, some stores, like Pep Conrad's and Han Kieffer's, turned back into homes. I wondered how the people living there divided their space and how they dealt with the smells of the products that used to be sold there.

**Bachelor Fads Furniture**

Rick Gilbert, a furniture designer, lives in a flat that used to be a curtain warehouse. It has the typical features of a loft, like exposed brick walls and large doors that used to let curtains in from the nearby train tracks. However, Gilbert didn’t want a completely open space. He found it hard to work when his living area was so close. To create some separation, he used a large piece of corrugated plastic to divide the entrance area. This not only hid his office but also created a hallway and led the eye to the kitchen in the middle of the flat. He wanted the kitchen to be a neutral space where he could cook for friends or make coffee for clients. To balance the modern look of the plastic and stainless steel kitchen, he chose light wood for the floors. His flat is filled with modern furniture, but it also has sentimental pieces from his parents or things he bought at markets.

**Bruce Chatwin**

Bruce Chatwin's life was a mix of adventure and mystery, making him a fascinating writer. His first book, *In Patagonia*, published in 1977, changed travel writing. It reads like a thrilling story, full of imagination and insight. However, Chatwin often mixed facts with fiction, changing details to make his stories more interesting. He believed that through travel, one could discover hidden histories that were meant to inspire future explorers.

**Swimming**

During a warm summer rain, I quickly ran across my lawn and jumped into the pool. As I swam, I kept my eyes just above the water. Each raindrop created little fountains that burst into bubbles. The best moments were when the rain got heavier, drowning out the sound of birds and creating a mist over the water, as if the pool was rising to meet the sky. It was during this summer in 1996 that I started to think about swimming across Britain. I wanted to follow the rain as it traveled to the sea, escaping the frustration of swimming back and forth in a pool, like a tiger pacing in a cage.

Many of us live in a world where everything is labeled and explained. This makes our reality feel more like a visual experience. That’s why activities like walking, cycling, and swimming are so important. They help us reconnect with the wild and old parts of our world by taking us off the usual paths and away from the official stories. A swimming journey would let me explore the mysterious parts of our world, like dark forests or high mountains.

**Crying**

Charles Darwin believed that crying did not have a clear purpose in human evolution. However, recent studies suggest that crying has important social functions. Psychiatrist John Bowlby emphasized how crying helps create a strong bond between a mother and her child. Many people think that tears, especially in children, show feelings of helplessness. 

Understanding why adults cry is more complicated. The sound of crying may not be as important as the visual message it sends. In early human communities, crying might have helped build trust and connections among people. 

There are many reasons why we cry. We might cry to show sympathy for someone facing injustice. Sometimes, we cry without meaning to, like when we hear touching music or speeches. We are also more likely to cry when watching a sad movie with others rather than when we are alone. 

The social role of crying is clear, but research on this topic is still ongoing.

**The Heat is On**

We have all heard about global warming, but how much warmer will the Earth get, and how will it affect our lives? Most people know what global warming is, but many are unsure about its effects. A warmer climate will likely change the weather around the world. Since the atmosphere is connected to everything on our planet, any climate changes will significantly impact plants, animals, water, and soil. Humans have learned to use these natural resources to grow food, build cities, and support billions of people. Therefore, any changes to these resources are serious.

The challenge we face is understanding how the world will change and what is causing these changes. Over the last 100 years, human activities have greatly increased the levels of certain gases in the atmosphere, which are linked to global temperatures. These increased gas levels are likely affecting the global climate, but our limited knowledge makes it hard to predict the future accurately. 

We know that greenhouse gas levels have changed in line with global temperatures over the past 40,000 years, suggesting a strong connection between the two. Evidence shows that the Earth's surface has warmed by about 6°C in the last century. Most scientists believe this warming is not just a natural occurrence but is partly due to human pollution.

A lot of research has been done to predict what will happen with higher global temperatures. Scientists use computer programs called general circulation models (GCMs) to analyze how temperature, pressure, sunlight, and other factors interact to predict climate conditions. However, these models are simplifications of reality and have many limitations. Their predictions are only rough estimates, and they can be slow and costly to run. 

Despite these challenges, most experts agree on one important point: the rate of climate change will be faster than anything we have seen before. Current predictions suggest that by the year 2100, the average global surface temperature could rise by 1°C to 3.5°C, sea levels could increase by 15 to 95 cm, and changes in rainfall patterns will occur. Scientists also expect more extreme weather events, like heatwaves, floods, and droughts, in some areas. 

These predictions highlight the potential impact of climate change on the environment and humans. Changes in climate could affect where ecosystems, like forests and grasslands, are located, the types of species in these areas, and their ability to provide resources that societies depend on. This includes food production, water supply, and human settlements. Some effects may be irreversible and could be harmful in many regions, but not all impacts will be negative. 

In some places, climate change may have positive effects. For example, in Australia, research shows that wheat production has increased by about 0.5 tonnes per hectare since 1952, partly due to climate trends. Warmer temperatures have led to fewer frosts, which helps crops grow better.

However, many predicted effects of future warming are concerning. Even small changes in climate can affect water availability, especially in dry areas or places already facing shortages. For instance, in the Mediterranean Basin, there have been decreasing rainfall trends in some regions, with rain becoming more concentrated in a shorter time each year.

Another worrying effect is the change in glaciers, which will impact ice and water resources, wildlife habitats, and human structures. There is a strong chance that Arctic ice will melt completely, making transport easier but increasing risks from icebergs.

The most dramatic effect of global warming will likely be rising sea levels. This will happen because warmer water takes up more space and because of melting ice. Since about half of the world's population lives in coastal areas, rising sea levels could have severe consequences. Increased flooding is a major concern, with cities like London, New York, and Tokyo at risk of significant disruption. Many people could lose their homes and livelihoods, leading to millions of environmental refugees.

The most serious consequences may be faced by small, low-lying island nations, which could disappear if worst-case scenarios occur. This would be devastating for the people and cultures of these islands and would also create challenges for countries that would need to help those displaced.

**Mission to Mars**

Wanted: a married couple in their middle age for a 501-day trip to Mars. Applicants must be strong both physically and emotionally. This will be the profile of the first astronauts on Mars if millionaire Dennis Tito's plans to launch a spacecraft on January 5, 2018, succeed. 

The spacecraft will take the crew to about 160 km above Mars. It will use Mars' gravity to return to Earth without using extra fuel, which is very important. The 2018 launch date is set because the next time Mars and Earth will be in the right position for a launch is in 2031. 

This is a challenging task, but there is a race to create new technologies for the mission. If these technologies are ready in time, the spacecraft might succeed. Even if the mission does not happen, the work done will help improve future space missions.

**AESTHETICS**

The way we think about art can sometimes make it hard to understand it. This is because art exists as physical objects, like buildings, books, paintings, or statues, separate from our experiences. People often see art only as these objects, not considering how they affect us when we experience them. 

Additionally, some artworks are so admired that they create certain ideas or standards that can block new ways of thinking about them. Once a piece of art is considered a classic, it can feel disconnected from the human experiences that created it and the feelings it brings to life. When we separate art from its origins and its effects on our lives, we make it harder to see its true meaning, which is what aesthetic theory tries to explore.

A key task for anyone writing about art is to connect these refined works of art back to everyday experiences and feelings that everyone understands. Just like mountains are part of the earth and not floating alone, art is also part of our human experience. Those who study the earth, like geographers and geologists, show how the earth works. Similarly, those who study art must do the same.

To truly understand art, we sometimes need to set it aside and focus on the everyday experiences that we usually don’t think of as artistic. We need to take a different path to reach a deeper understanding of art. For example, while we can enjoy flowers for their beauty and smell without knowing much about plants, if we want to understand how they grow, we must learn about the soil, air, water, and sunlight that help them thrive.

To grasp the essence of art, we should start with the raw experiences that catch our attention and bring us joy. However, many people might be surprised to learn that they enjoy their everyday activities partly because of their aesthetic qualities. The arts that people find most engaging today are often things they don’t think of as traditional art, like movies, jazz, comic strips, and even sensational news stories. 

When art is only seen in museums and galleries, people often seek enjoyment in their daily lives instead. Many who criticize the museum view of art still hold onto the idea that art is separate from everyday experiences. However, the best appreciation of art happens when it is closely connected to the ordinary things we do.

**Observing Lions**

Many people think of lions hunting as a beautiful display of teamwork. In the fading light of sunset, a group of lions quietly surrounds their prey like skilled hunters. They seem to be perfect social animals, working together for a common goal: their next meal. However, after years of studying lions in the wild, we have a different view. 

When we began our research in 1978, we wanted to understand why lions hunt together, raise their young, and scare off rivals with their loud roars. If we measure an animal's success by how many offspring survive, then working together does not always help. If one animal is too generous, it may lose out while others benefit. So, why do lions seem to ignore the rules of self-interest? We thought we could answer this question in two to three years, but lions are very good at being inactive. 

It has taken various research methods to learn more about their behavior. Since wild lions can live up to 18 years, we are only now starting to find answers to our questions.

**Pop Music Review**

The release of Bedrock's third album was a significant moment for a band that had struggled in the past. "New Life" started a movement that changed rock music in this country for the rest of the decade. Gone were the serious themes and heavy guitars of the past; instead, a lighter mix of catchy local styles emerged. 

The album combined social commentary and strong emotions with sounds from fairground organs and brass bands. It featured humor and honesty, with voices that proudly showed their roots. Bedrock proved to be talented collectors and observers, as well as clever songwriters. They wrote about traditional English themes like sunbathing and lazy Sundays. However, the album's true strength was in its deeper, sadder songs, such as "So Low," which had a beautiful melody related to weather, and "To the Brink," a serious ballad. 

The beauty of "New Life" lies in its high quality—16 tracks with no weak songs, making it a standout album in an era of long CDs.

**Extract from an Autobiography**

As a child, I was always intrigued by stories of 'The Sibyl,' wise women who had great influence in ancient times. At first, I only knew of one from a story my mother told me. An old woman from Cumae offered King Tarquin of Rome nine books for 300 gold pieces. When he refused, she burned three books and offered him six for the same price. He still refused, so she burned three more. In the end, he bought the last three for the full price. I understood that there was a valuable lesson in this story about sales and life.

I was often a lonely only child. When I asked to play with other kids and was turned down, my mother advised me to do something so interesting that they would want to join me. It worked, and it’s a lesson I’ve never forgotten.

When I got the chance to write a travel book, I needed to find a topic that mattered to me. I’m not a keen traveler; I even sent my editor a long list of places I didn’t want to visit. I’m mainly interested in ruins because I prefer to travel through time in my mind.

**What Happens to Your Manuscript?**

When you send in your manuscript, it will likely join a pile of other submissions waiting to be reviewed, known as the slush pile. Usually, a junior member of the editorial team (often under 18) or an experienced freelancer will look at it. Neither has much power, but they want to find something original. The junior hopes to make a name for themselves, while the freelancer wants to keep their job.

If they think your novel has potential, they will pass it to a senior editor, who will discuss it in a meeting. This editor must explain why your novel is good and how well it might sell. They will also consider if you, as an author, seem like a long-term investment, which you should have mentioned in your letter. Additionally, they will think about how marketable you are, as a new novel needs all the support it can get. Because of this, publishers often prefer to meet potential authors before making an offer.

**Advertising on Trial**

If you work in an advertising agency, the early 1990s were likely very challenging. The recession was worse than expected, affecting many industrialized countries for about thirty years. In Britain, in 1991, the economy shrank, interest rates were very high, and consumer spending dropped significantly. Over half a million people lost their jobs, and around 75,000 homes were taken back by banks. Every business was impacted, with some industries, like vehicles and construction, seeing a 30% decline in sales. Many people and companies around the world faced difficulties.

Advertising professionals were not unique in losing their jobs during this tough time, but those who remained often felt a lot of pressure. They were seen as responsible for helping companies make money, which meant they were closely watched by their colleagues and bosses. At the same time, they were asked to do more with smaller budgets, being told that "less is more." Despite these challenges, the importance of marketing grew. Companies began to realize they needed to create products and services that customers actually wanted, rather than just what was easy for them to make. 

In the last ten to fifteen years, many companies have started to take marketing seriously. This has improved the status of marketing professionals, but it has also increased their workload. Marketing is often mistakenly seen as a solution to all problems. Since about half of marketing budgets go to advertising, the pressure is on advertising professionals to deliver results. While the 1980s were a great time for advertising, the early 1990s brought significant challenges due to the economy. 

The recession forced companies to rethink their advertising budgets and strategies. Many companies began to question the effectiveness of advertising, especially when they were trying to account for every dollar spent. They wanted to know what return they were getting on their investment. As a result, advertising was put under more scrutiny than ever before. Companies wanted better strategies, targeting, creativity, and media placement. They aimed to have the best people from advertising agencies working on their projects and wanted them to produce excellent work.

While this situation does not necessarily call for sympathy for advertising professionals, it does mean they face the same challenges as their clients: how to achieve more with less. Additionally, other factors have made effective advertising harder to create. Some of these issues are due to the recession, such as debates over production costs and a reluctance to take risks, which are often necessary for good advertising. Other changes, like demographic shifts, the growing power of retailers, changing consumer needs, the rise of sponsorship, and stricter advertising laws, have also played a role. 

Moreover, some companies now face the challenge of advertising in foreign markets. Together with the economic situation, these factors have led many advertising professionals to reconsider the famous saying by Lord Leverhulme: "Only half my advertising works. The trouble is I don't know which half." There is now more pressure than ever to ensure that advertising is effective.

Unfortunately, help for those looking to improve their advertising is not easily available. Companies and advertising agencies have been too busy dealing with these challenges to share their experiences. Those who have managed to succeed often want to keep their successful strategies private. As a result, while conferences and seminars may offer some useful insights, the available books on advertising often do not provide practical guidance. Many of these books treat the advertising process with too much respect, suggesting that the work produced by advertising agencies is always of high quality and value, which is not true and does not help the employees responsible for the advertising.

**The Lure of the Kitchen**

When I was in university, I decided I wanted to become a chef. This was an unusual choice among my friends. Most people did not see cooking as a desirable job. Being a chef is often seen as a tough profession: the work is long, stressful, and not well-paid. However, these factors did not discourage me. I was unhappy at university. The studies were difficult, and the social life felt closed and self-important. Becoming a chef seemed like a great way to escape this environment. It offered a sense of purpose and honesty that I felt was missing in my college life.

My desire to cook was not just a reaction to my university experience; it also reflected my love for beautiful food. I first realized this when I had a meal at a famous restaurant in London. It was an amazing experience. I still remember my starter clearly. After that meal, I felt so inspired that I wanted to learn everything about cooking. I changed my student life into a preparation for my future in the culinary world. My history degree felt meaningless compared to my passion for cooking. I learned by reading cookbooks, visiting markets, and cooking elaborate meals.

**The Swimming Instructor**

The swimming instructor at my school was a tough ex-drill sergeant, small but very strong, with tattoos on his arms. When I asked him to teach me how to dive, he told me to sit on the edge of the pool, raise my hands above my head, and roll forward, pushing off with my feet. I practiced this until the lesson was over. The next time, he had me stand up and dive off the edge. He was strict, and every time I came up from the water, he looked at me disapprovingly: "Don't look down, look up!" "Keep your legs straight." "Point your toes!" 

The following week, I climbed up to the high diving board. It felt very high as I stood there, trying to gather my courage. Slowly, the noise around me faded, and I felt like I was in a bubble of silence. I waved my arms as I had been taught, tried to look up, and jumped. For a moment, it felt like I was flying. But when I hit the water, I fell awkwardly, and my legs were everywhere. The instructor looked at me with disappointment and shook his head. But even he could not take away my happiness. I thought, "This is what they mean by 'free as a bird.'"

**The Traveller**

For many people, having a comfortable bed, running water, and the chance to live a long life are very important. In contrast, the idea of a traveller can seem strange and fascinating. These are people who choose to take risks, like climbing dangerous mountains or sailing alone on small boats. They might eat insects if there is nothing else to eat and can live for months in uncertain conditions. 

It is easy to see these travellers as unusual or eccentric, like hermits or extreme sports enthusiasts. While they do exist, their world is very different from ours, and we often think of it as irrelevant. We can feel relieved to return to our own lives, where the risks we face are more predictable, like crossing a busy street.

**Sailing**

Jonathan Raban is afraid of the sea, which is probably why he spends so much time on it. He does not say he is a world-class sailor, but he is skilled. As a writer, he enjoys writing about his sailing experiences. Sailing gives him many exciting stories to tell.

Raban's small boat has a device that tells sailors their exact location anywhere on Earth. While he appreciates this technology, he also believes that inventions like the compass have changed the way people relate to the sea. He thinks that since the compass was invented, sailors have stopped paying attention to the waves and the ocean. Instead of being a lively place, the sea has become just a space to navigate. Because of this, a sailor can often let an autopilot take over, which may be why Raban has time to observe the waves closely.

**Holiday Reading**

Summer brings us two great joys: escaping home and reading books. These joys are closely connected. Books can help us feel more at home in the world. We can relate our own experiences to those in great books written long ago or in faraway places. There are fewer types of people than there are individuals, so in the stories of others, we find our own thoughts and feelings. Authors can express our emotions and situations in a way that we might struggle to do ourselves. What we feel shy or confused about is clearly described in their words, which is even more impressive if the author is from a different time or place. We feel thankful to these writers for helping us understand ourselves better.

Through reading and traveling, we can break free from our daily routines. Our eyes are most open when we first arrive in a new place, just like when we read a great book that shows us things we might have ignored before. Our minds become more aware of the details around us, like the colors of the sky, the expressions on people's faces, or feelings we didn’t know we had.

**Author's Note**

These reflections on travel were published as articles in the Observer newspaper over seven years. I have made some small changes to restore parts that were cut for space, but I have added very little. I corrected a few mistakes, but only if they were minor details I should have gotten right. Looking back, I could have made more improvements, but that would have taken too long. For example, in my second article about China, I thought the Hong Kong dollar would stay strong, but a year later it fell. If I rewrote it to include that prediction, it would no longer be a report of what I experienced at that time. Like any traveler, I was there, not knowing what would happen next, just trying to understand what had already happened. This is the story of modern air travel: the world opening up to people who can afford a ticket. However, I don’t believe all my fellow travelers were completely unaware. Even a simple postcard can have a purpose.

**Ecotourism**

If there were awards for tourism phrases that have been misused, "ecotourism" would win first prize. This term appeared in the early 1980s, showing a growing awareness of environmental issues and a desire from travelers to minimize their impact while abroad. It quickly became a popular marketing term for holidays. Now, "ecotourism" can mean anything from a two-week stay with remote tribes to a one-hour boat trip through an Australian gorge. Any tour that includes cultural experiences, beautiful nature, wildlife, or a bit of adventure is likely to be labeled as ecotourism. While the original idea was to help travelers make informed choices, the lack of clear rules and definitions has left many confused in the ecotourism market.

**Transylvanian Journey**

I lost my notebook from my trip to Transylvania for 50 years, but I found it again by chance a few years ago. It has helped me remember that time and write about it, but it wasn’t as helpful as I hoped. In Transylvania, I had a much easier time than I expected, moving from one welcoming house to another and often staying for weeks. When I settled down for a while, I stopped writing, thinking there was nothing important to record. I was slow to start writing again when I moved on, and sometimes I only made quick notes instead of detailed stories. Worried that some details might be out of order when I began writing this book, I added many warnings. But then I realized that these pages were not meant to be a guidebook, so I let the story unfold without too many restrictions.

**Fashion**

Fashion is often thought of as a modern idea that developed because of capitalism in the 19th and 20th centuries. However, many fashion historians argue that fashion, especially in terms of style and design, has a long history. They often start their discussions with the growth of trade in the 16th and 17th centuries. As societies have become more complex, populations have grown, and new technologies for making different types of clothing have emerged, the meanings of what we wear have also become more complicated. Because of this, it is hard to say exactly what any piece of clothing means today. For instance, a man's suit, which is often seen as a sign of uniformity, can have very different meanings depending on the situation and the person.

**Writer**

Reports about publishers fighting over popular new books can give a false idea of what life is like for most novelists. For those of us who are not best-selling authors, there are two main ways to make a living. The smartest writers work in the evenings and have other full-time jobs that will still be there if their book is not quickly published or made into a movie. Others, like me, take on various small jobs, such as teaching, running workshops, and writing articles. I have heard of a writing job at a chocolate factory, but I have never found anything like that. Somehow, by balancing part-time jobs and using credit cards, and often thanks to the help of friends mentioned in the Acknowledgements, I manage to write my novel.

**Sudden Fame**

The small places where we performed around the country were starting to sell out, and we needed extra security to manage the growing number of excited fans. We had to use secret entrances to avoid being overwhelmed by our supporters. On the few nights we were not working, it was hard to go out without being followed by fans. In just a few days, we became celebrities. Our fans watched our every move, and our management took care of all our needs. Even though I still felt shy, I also experienced a strange, naive confidence that many shy people can understand when they suddenly find themselves in the spotlight. In short, I felt completely out of my comfort zone.

**Music - The Challenge Ahead**

Technological advances are changing our lives at work, home, and during our free time. Susan Hallam talks about how these changes affect music in Britain. In the late 20th century, there was a quick rise in ways to listen to music, such as through radio, TV, records, tapes, CDs, videos, and new multimedia technologies. However, this has led to fewer live music performances and fewer full-time jobs for professional musicians.

It is clear that access to music will keep growing because it meets many human needs. On a national level, music is present at all major state events. For individuals, music offers many activities, both formal and informal. A society without music is hard to imagine. The real question is not whether there will be music in the 21st century, but what kind of music it will be and if people will still feel the need to learn to play musical instruments.

I believe that people will continue to learn instruments. The music industry is a major source of income in Britain, and musical skills will remain important for various jobs, especially in media-related fields. Additionally, there is evidence that playing an instrument can help develop skills early in life. Research in the USA suggests that listening to or making music positively affects spatial reasoning, which is one part of measuring intelligence. While these results need more confirmation, studies in Europe show that group music lessons can improve social relationships in schools and help children focus, especially those with behavioral issues.

Current research is also looking into how playing an instrument might help develop skills that can be used in other areas. For example, regular practice can lead to better study habits and concentration, while performing in concerts can teach punctuality and organization. Because of these benefits, there will likely be a continued demand for instrumental teaching in the near future.

What about the long-term future? Will there be a change in focus, and if so, what will it be? I see two likely possibilities. First, the types of music people listen to will become more varied, with new genres combining different styles. Second, technology will play a bigger role in composing and performing music. This will make it easier for more people to create music without needing advanced technical skills, but it may also reduce the need for live performances and musicians focused only on that.

At the same time, more people of all ages will want to participate in making music. These activities will likely be community-based and reflect the musical traditions of those communities. If this future is to happen, the music profession must prepare. Instrumental teaching will need to change to help more people learn different instruments throughout their lives. This will require changes in the curriculum and how progress is measured to stay relevant for a wider audience.

Training for musicians will be essential. They will need to inspire and teach learners of all ages, work with large and diverse groups, and develop skills in communication, social interaction, entrepreneurship, and management for community work. This represents a big change from traditional methods and will require a response to demands for public accountability. 

Positively, this is an opportunity for everyone involved in music education to show the high quality of music teaching available. Finally, we must work to raise the importance of music itself. Music is vital in our lives, but it is often taken for granted. Those in the music profession need to collaborate actively to ensure this changes.

**The Actor's Craft**

Sometimes, actors face criticism and disrespect. This negative view often comes from the actors themselves when they are asked to talk about their work in interviews. Instead of sharing their true feelings, they often use boring phrases or get caught up in gossip. The actor Paul Scofield once wrote to a friend that an actor's work is only interesting when it is performed. He believed that discussing it makes it feel empty and unimportant. Each time an actor performs, they start fresh, learning about their character and the writer's ideas. After a play ends, they feel empty until they perform again, and this emptiness shows when they talk about their work.

**A Review of Hamlet**

Adrian Lester's performance as Hamlet shows a young man caught between childhood and adulthood. His acting is simple yet confident. He skillfully handles the text and shows great control over his body and emotions. Lester portrays Hamlet as a young man filled with anger but also humor, making him both strong and likable. His physical presence, like the way his arms hang, suggests he is waiting to be brought to life. Another actor, Handy, plays Horatio in a way that also feels like he is being moved by an inner force. This raises questions about acting: Is it just copying real behavior, or is it something deeper? What brings these characters to life? 

**One Director's Approach to Rehearsal**

This director's rehearsal process starts with a method called "dropping in." The stage manager shows the script on a screen while the actors listen quietly. When it is their turn to speak, they look at the screen, think about the first line, and find the reason to say it. For example, if the line is about waiting in the rain, they might picture a memory of standing in a queue. They should not plan their response in advance but instead trust that something will come to them in the moment.

**The Perfect Theatre**

The ideal theatre should make the audience feel that their presence matters. Attending a live performance is special, and the staff should understand this. It can feel very isolating if the people working at the theatre seem uninterested. The theatre should create a connection between the performers and the audience. The audience should be close enough to hear and see everything clearly. The design of the auditorium is important; it should fit the human voice and body. If the space is too large, it can feel wrong because drama is about human experiences. Many theatres built in the late 1800s got this right by creating spaces that feel welcoming. I appreciate theatres that have a sense of history, like old stone steps that show the presence of many people over time. 

When it comes to plays, you cannot please everyone. You cannot predict what the audience will want to see. When you go to the theatre, you want to experience something surprising and unique; otherwise, you might as well stay home.

**Paul Simon**

Rock and roll in the 1950s was mainly popular among young people, but it also had a big effect on the middle class and older adults. This music opened doors for the next generation of rock stars, who listened to it with excitement, knowing that this unique sound would be important in their lives. For Paul Simon and many other young people in the US, the best way to hear this exciting new music was through Alan Freed's radio show, Moondog Rock'n'Roll Party. Freed's show was essential listening for many young rock stars. Just like John Lennon, who was 3,000 miles away in Liverpool, listening to Radio Luxembourg, Paul Simon was captivated by the music from Freed's show. He was getting ready to make the next big move for a teenager who loved rock and roll: creating his own music.

**Snow**

I couldn’t see a clear path, but I thought I would be okay if I was careful. The wind was strong, pushing me over as I slipped on the icy ground. Suddenly, the snow that looked safe gave way, and I fell into a hole about four feet deep. The snow had formed a roof over a gap between two rocks, and when it melted, it left only a thin layer that I fell through. I managed to climb out, feeling shaken and worried about what would have happened if the hole had been much deeper. I sat against a pine tree that was sticking out of the snow to think about my situation. After an hour, I had only gone about half a mile. It was clear that I would have to change my plans.

**Qualitative Research**

There are many books that help researchers understand qualitative research. While a lot has been written about how to collect data, these books often do not explain how to analyze that data. There is still a lot of mystery about how researchers study their data. To help with this, we invited various social scientists who have worked on qualitative projects to share their methods. The goal was to provide insight into the process of analyzing qualitative data, rather than creating a guidebook for new researchers. This task involves making unclear processes clearer. Although this may seem easy, we found it to be quite challenging. Therefore, we allowed our contributors to present their work in different styles, including personal stories and more formal writing.

**Screen Learning**

Recently, I saw my six-year-old son eating noodles in a funny way. He was pretending to be a dinosaur and said, "I'm a little dinosaur." He was acting out a scene from a TV show, so I asked him what he remembered about dinosaurs. He didn’t remember much. 

There is a trend to use the internet and computers for learning, but is this a good way to learn? One writer shared his experience with an interactive program he tried with his son. The father read the words while the son played with the pictures. The father thought that if his son had spent ten minutes reading a book, he might have learned more. 

Research shows that learning happens best in an environment where there is conversation with teachers or parents. Technology can help teach our children, but traditional education is still very important.

**Hollywood**

By 1918, most of the world’s film-making had moved to Hollywood. The local people were not happy about this, seeing it as a bad influence. However, they eventually accepted it because success is a key American value, and success is measured by box office earnings. 

Hollywood has changed a lot in less than a century. It has grown from a small village to a town as famous as New York, Rome, or Paris. A hundred years ago, you would walk through orange groves to get to the village store. Yet, in some ways, it still feels like a village, focused mainly on films. People talk about how much movies make, who is dating whom, and who is working on which project. 

Many successful people in Hollywood try to live elsewhere while working there. Still, it remains the main place for anyone important in show business.

**Photography**

Photography was created by artists in the 19th century as a way to capture their surroundings. They wanted a lasting record of what they saw. The new technology of light, lenses, and chemicals produced images that were more detailed and realistic than paintings, which took much longer to create. 

This upset many traditional artists. They believed photography could not be considered art because it relied too much on machines. However, photographers saw it as a new form of art and a way to express themselves. They used photography like other artists use brushes and pencils to show their view of the world.

**Book Illustration**

In the past, every children's book needed illustrations. This also applied to many novels for older readers, although fewer were published over time. Children's publishing was mostly low-budget, which led to many average-quality works, but the best artists always gave their best effort. 

The collection of black-and-white illustrations is a mix of valuable and less valuable works, making it a great place for research and discovery. Many of these treasures will be shown to the public again, either through new editions of classic books or exhibitions of original artwork. There are signs that interest in this period of illustration is growing, and soon, a publisher will likely create a series of classic children's book illustrations.

**Blogging: Sharing with Caution**

Not long ago, a website warned about the dangers of public check-ins, which are online posts that tell people where you are. The message was clear: when you say, "Hey, I'm here," you are also letting many people know your location, including those you might not want to meet. This shows that while sharing our lives online can be exciting, it can also have negative consequences.

The internet gives us many chances to share our experiences with a global audience, which can lead to fame or wealth. However, as we share personal stories and photos, we may find ourselves in a crowded and risky space. It can feel overwhelming, but there is hope. We can learn from those who explored the internet before us.

In the early days of the web, a group of pioneers, now known as bloggers, faced many challenges. They lost jobs, made and lost friends, and dealt with the temptations of fame long before social media existed. Their experiences can teach us valuable lessons.

In January 1994, Justin Hall, a 19-year-old student, started sharing his life online. At that time, the web was mostly used by graduate students and scientists. Hall saw a chance to share his personal story. He created a blog filled with his thoughts, photos, and art. By January 1996, he was posting daily, attracting many readers who were fascinated by his boldness. Hall was open about everything, and while some saw him as an exhibitionist, others appreciated the artistic side of his work.

However, one day, visitors to his blog found it replaced by a video called "Dark Night." Hall shared that he had fallen in love, but when he wrote about it, his partner told him to choose between the blog and the relationship. Hall chose to remove the blog, feeling that sharing so much made people distrust him. This situation highlights a key point: while sharing online can be enjoyable, it can also lead to disappointment if you expect it to bring you closer to others.

In 2002, Heather Armstrong, a young woman in Los Angeles, had a blog called Dooce. She sometimes wrote about her job at a software company. One day, a colleague shared her blog with the company's vice presidents, including some she had criticized, which led to her losing her job. This situation illustrates the "online distribution effect," where people feel they can say things online that they would never say in person. However, our online lives are connected to our real lives, and ignoring this can lead to serious mistakes.

Armstrong's story had a positive ending. After taking a break from blogging, she got married and started a new blog focused on her family. Today, she is a successful "mommy blogger," and her writing supports her family. She learned an important lesson: while the internet allows us to say anything, it doesn't mean we should.

**Enough Sleep?**

Many people today feel tired all the time. In richer and busier countries, sleeplessness and anxiety have become common. Research in the USA shows that 40 million Americans suffer from chronic sleep problems. Some popular novels in Britain even have characters who cannot sleep or are set in sleep research labs. This shows a growing interest in sleep: its patterns, its importance, and the issues people face with it. A leading sleep researcher says, "People need more sleep." When people are busy, they often sleep less. They wake up early to avoid traffic.

Recently, a sleep researcher conducted an experiment. He let participants sleep for up to 14 hours a night for a month. After three weeks, they settled into an average of eight hours and fifteen minutes of sleep. This shows they needed more sleep than they were getting.

In Europe, a university sleep research lab in the English Midlands studies sleep in detail. They have looked at how tiredness affects sailors, how airport noise disturbs sleep, and the risks of driving when tired. They recruit participants through student newspapers. These subjects are picked up by taxi, paid £5 an hour, and asked to change their sleep patterns based on instructions. Dr. Louise Reyner reassures them, saying, "Some people worry because we put electrodes on their heads, thinking we can see their dreams or thoughts." However, the lab focuses more on physical effects.

In a dark room, there is a driving simulator with a large screen. Participants come in at 2 PM, which is when people usually feel sleepy, especially after a poor night’s sleep. They drive while answering questions. The road ahead seems endless, with bright sunlight and warm air. The young men insist they will not fall asleep. Dr. Reyner has a video of one participant trying hard to stay awake. At first, he sits up straight, but soon he starts to blink more often and his head begins to droop. Eventually, he falls asleep for a few seconds, causing the car to drift off the road. Dr. Reyner suggests that drinking two cups of coffee can help someone stay awake and drive safely for at least half an hour. She also recommends energy products like tablets and caffeinated gum, especially for shift workers.

But what do we really know about sleep? It is clear that humans, like other mammals, sleep in cycles. When we sleep, we go through four stages, from light sleep to deep sleep. Dreams usually happen during light sleep, and the brain temporarily paralyzes the body to prevent injuries. Beyond this, many ideas about sleep are still theories. Some believe sleep helps repair the body or restore muscles, but it might also happen during relaxed wakefulness.

Scientists agree that women tend to sleep about half an hour longer than men, and older people generally need less sleep, though the reasons are unclear. Some researchers even say, "Sleep is a way to travel through time without getting hurt."

Sleep patterns have changed over time. A history professor studied British sleep habits from 1500 to 1850 and found that people went to bed early, woke up after midnight for a while, and then went back to sleep. This time was used for thinking, remembering dreams, or even stealing. The poorest people benefited most from this quiet time, escaping their daily struggles. By the 17th century, with more artificial light, wealthy people began to adopt the sleep patterns we have today. The industrial revolution later forced most people to work longer hours in lit buildings.

However, in many non-western cultures, the old sleep patterns still exist. Some people go to bed for a few hours, wake up, and then sleep again. The idea of a full night’s sleep is not common. In certain tribal societies, noises from animals and the need to watch over fires make it hard to sleep continuously. It seems that people everywhere are in need of more sleep.

We are talking about really expensive cowboy boots. I stood in my 800-dollar designer cowboy boots on the rocks in the Arizona desert. Money was not a problem. I wore a full cowboy outfit, and if you have the outfit, you might look like a cowboy. But I wasn’t one. I looked out at the Arizona mountains and realized I didn’t belong there. I had flown in from Denver early in the morning, thinking I might look like a cowboy coming from the sky. But that thought disappeared when I saw a real cowboy at the Phoenix airport. He was wearing a dirty shirt, needed a shave, and was picking up his bag when he noticed my new cowboy boots. He raised an eyebrow and left without saying anything.

I thought there should be a set of clothes that an ex-racing driver could wear without feeling out of place. I loved being a racing driver and driving fast cars. I was addicted to it, and it was all I knew. But I couldn’t do it anymore. I wondered what I should do now. A racing driver should have other options for when he stops racing. I thought I had some, but they didn’t work out.

One idea was to be a commentator at races, but there were many former drivers ahead of me for that job. Another idea was to sell classic cars, but that didn’t go well either. It was a bad year for selling old cars, so I decided to step back before I lost everything. Being an "ex" at anything is hard. Who wants to hear about how I almost became the World Champion? No one wants to hear a story that ends with "almost." Even if I had been the champion, people would only listen for a short time before getting bored. Last year’s champion is just that—last year.

I don’t want sympathy, and I don’t get any. I had a good career, made money, and saved enough. But I really miss the excitement of getting into a powerful racing car. I miss the thrill of going from zero to 150 miles per hour in just 4.9 seconds. I even miss the danger of racing. I miss the bright, interesting people and the reporters who cared about what I said. They say you create your own luck, both good and bad. After that, I decided to work as a freelance photographer, which I thought was a smart choice. However, life had other plans, and things didn’t go as well as I had hoped. The mid-nineties were not the successful years I expected after my photo was featured on the cover of Time magazine. That’s why I found myself in Vienna instead of a more exciting place. But I was still taking photos and getting paid for it, which I thought was good.

My assignment in Vienna came about by chance. I had taken photos for a book called *Four Cities in Four Seasons*, which included London, Paris, Rome, and Vienna. I had received a nice payment for capturing different seasons in London. I had my own style, showing the beauty of daffodils in Hyde Park and the busy streets of Piccadilly. I knew that some of my best work would be ignored because it was just a picture book, not something meant to challenge people’s views.

After I submitted my winter photos of London, I learned that the Austrian photographer, Rudi Schussner, had left his job in Vienna for reasons I didn’t need to know. Instead of hiring someone new, they offered me the job. The Austrian publishers liked my work, and I was available, while other photographers were not. I was happy to go because things were not good at home. A week in snowy Vienna sounded great to me.

They put me up at the Europa hotel in the old city. I had visited Vienna before with my wife, but it had been a busy and hot trip, and I hadn’t taken many photos. This time, being alone in the cold January weather, I felt it would be different. As soon as I arrived and saw the beautiful light over the snow-covered roofs, I knew I would enjoy my time there and take great pictures.

On my first day, I didn’t rush to take photos. I rode the trams around the Ringstrasse, getting on and off to experience the city’s atmosphere. The weather was cold and still, just like the grand buildings from the old empire. I hadn’t seen what Schussner had captured in the other seasons, and I didn’t want to. This was going to be my Vienna, and I wanted to discover it for myself.

A photograph captures a moment, but you have to wait for the right moment to come. So, I took my time to look around until I was ready. The next morning, I woke up early. The snow from the night before made Stephansplatz beautifully white and almost empty. I struggled to find a way to capture the cathedral in one shot. Its tall spire reached into the grey sky, while at ground level, it was huge and dominating the city. I realized I might have to take a partial shot instead. In that weather and at that time, it could still be magical.

Photography has always had a sense of magic. Even the early photographers felt this before they fully understood the science behind it. You can watch a blank piece of paper turn into a photograph in a dark room. Even when you know how it works, the mystery of it remains. Maybe that’s why what happened at Stephansplatz that morning didn’t surprise me in a strange way.

**Kinetic Art Exhibition**

Exciting news: London's Hayward Gallery has changed from a serious place into one full of wonder.
