**The Camera Never Lies**

Arthur Conan Doyle, the writer of the Sherlock Holmes stories, thought of himself as a rational and scientific person. However, in 1920, he saw photographs of fairies taken in a garden and believed they were real proof of these tiny creatures. He published these photos with an article where he accepted fairies as magical beings. 

It was not until 1939 that the two women who took the photos confessed they were fake. They had simply cut out pictures of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The photos looked beautiful, but the simple trick showed that a basic idea about photography is wrong: that the camera cannot lie. In fact, it can, and it always has been able to. 

Today, we often use computer software to change our digital images, and it is a myth that photography ever had a time when it was completely honest. From the very beginning, when cameras started capturing images, those images were being changed.

**Blacksmiths**

Throughout history, iron has captured human imagination, and blacksmiths, who work with it, have often been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths were respected like doctors and astrologers because they made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also celebrated as artists. In the 18th century, blacksmiths created beautiful ironwork for St Paul's Cathedral, and the elegant metal designs in French and Belgian Art Nouveau buildings were made by talented blacksmiths.

However, by the late 1960s, the number of blacksmiths in Britain had greatly decreased because heavy industry no longer needed their skills, and modern architects rarely used beautiful wrought-iron features. In the last 10 years, there has been a revival of interest in decorative architecture and more creative interior design. Still, much of the new work looks similar to past styles, with manufacturers promoting their products as "classical" or "Victorian-style." You can find trendy design stores filled with rusty candlesticks and similar items.

Fortunately, there are new opportunities for blacksmiths, and several events are planned to promote their craft. The first event is an exhibition of forged ironwork by members of the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA), which opened last week at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, believes we might be starting a new Iron Age, as both the public and blacksmiths are becoming more aware of the craft. 

Power tools have made it easier for blacksmiths to work with metal, allowing them to bend, twist, and weld it more easily. Dawson explains that these artists now have the tools to express their creativity. About 250 pieces are displayed in the exhibition, including bookends and a spiral staircase, with prices starting at £90 and going up to much higher amounts. Most of the money will go to the individual makers, but a portion will be kept by the Association to promote good ironwork.

Dawson has created an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade. He describes his style as letting steel bend and take shape when it’s hot, comparing it to drawing with metal in space. Many artists are fascinated by iron. Unlike other metals that are soft when cold, iron and steel are tougher and more challenging to work with. Susan May, a trained jeweler, finds it magical because it is soft when hot but becomes hard and unmovable when it cools down.

Ann Catrin Evans creates door knockers and handles from mild steel, inspired by the dark castles often seen in horror films. One of her designs looks like a ball and chain, and another resembles a Celtic cross. She loves the cold, hard feel of steel and how it seems to last forever. No other metal has given people as much visual pleasure or a sense of security. It is likely that iron will continue to be used for decorative purposes for many years to come, as long as we can avoid more rusty candlesticks!

**The Day I Gave Up Smoking**

I thought everyone would be happy when I stopped smoking, but one of my colleagues was very angry. She shouted, "What do you mean? If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I found it hard to explain how I went from being a heavy smoker to not smoking at all in just a few hours. It was a bit annoying for me too. 

The stop-smoking session I attended was a mix of group therapy and hypnotherapy, and it happened two months and three weeks ago. I didn’t plan to stop smoking, and I didn’t really want to. I felt pressured by anti-smoking groups, and I still do. I also had low blood pressure and a healthy family. I didn’t cough or feel sick, and I seemed to recover from colds faster than my friends who lived healthier lives.

On that ordinary Thursday afternoon, I went to the Birmingham session of "The Easy Way to Stop Smoking" to write an article about others trying to quit. I said, "I won’t be trying to stop myself; I’m just here to write." I thought this was a reasonable approach because I enjoyed smoking and found pleasure in it. The counsellor seemed to understand me.

During the session, we were encouraged to smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was so full of smoke that we had to open the windows. I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I didn’t want to, and neither did the others. I think the messages about stopping smoking started to make sense to me. Just as smoking had become a challenge against opposition, the idea of quitting began to feel appealing. The thought of not being a smoker made me feel strong. It was a personal feeling that was just for me. 

In many ways, quitting was easy. The physical cravings for nicotine, which felt like hunger, went away after a minute or two and lasted only four or five days. I thought my work would be the hardest part without cigarettes, but it turned out to be fine. I had worried that I wouldn’t be able to meet deadlines without nicotine and that I would fail to write a story. Surprisingly, the hardest part was doing simple things at home on weekend mornings. 

I’ve come to realize that smoking helped me deal with boredom; having a cigarette was an activity in itself. Yes, I do miss smoking, but not too much. Every new experience as a non-smoker is something I have to get used to—like eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, or during a theatre break. These are all moments when I would have smoked before.

**Dorothy Who?**

Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize, yet many people in Britain do not know her name. For the past four years, I have been asking friends if they know about her. If they respond with surprise and say something like, "Isn't there already a biography?" they pass my test. 

Why should people in Britain know about Dorothy Hodgkin? She is important because she is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize. If someone in literature had this achievement, they would be very famous. Hodgkin, who passed away in 1994, was an extraordinary person, much like the crystals she studied. Her life shows significant changes in the 20th century, including the progress of women's education and the global nature of science.

When I started my research, I wanted to read scientific biographies. A friend of Hodgkin suggested I look for a biography of Linus Pauling, who was a close friend of hers and also a Nobel Prize winner. However, when I went to the bookstore, I found that there were no biographies of Pauling available. I was surprised that he was not considered interesting enough for British readers, even though he was a very important chemist.

Even scientists sometimes think that biographies about scientists are not interesting. Peter Medawar, another Nobel Prize winner, once said that the lives of scientists are often dull. If scientists believe this, it is not surprising that publishers and bookstores feel the same way. This idea that scientists are different from artists and writers is a common belief, and it means that only a few famous scientists get biographies.

It is not true that scientists have less interesting lives than artists, writers, or politicians. Some scientists are very careful about their public image. For example, a well-known geneticist said he would only talk about his work if he was not quoted or photographed, as he did not want to seem like he was promoting himself. This attitude can make science seem less appealing to young people and can create distrust among the public.

Fortunately, things are changing. Nowadays, scientists often appear in the media in ways that are not just about their research. For example, Professor Richard Dawkins gives out awards on a TV quiz show, and geneticist Steve Jones appears in car commercials. These activities help people see scientists as real individuals, not just researchers.

The world of publishing is also changing. Scientific biographies used to be very serious and often ignored the personal lives of scientists. However, this has changed with books like Richard Feynman's "Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman?", which is both funny and touching. Recently, even famous scientists like Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, Albert Einstein, and Marie Curie have been shown with their flaws, making them more relatable.

Dorothy Hodgkin was dedicated to her scientific work. She made significant discoveries, including the structures of penicillin and vitamin B12, which earned her the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1964, and insulin, which her team solved in 1969. She was also a devoted mother of three and had a husband who was often away due to his job as a historian. While her personal life may not seem directly related to her work, it shows how she balanced different parts of her life.

There is much to learn from her life, but her scientific achievements are also important. Hodgkin's passion for science was central to her success, and explaining this passion is a challenge for biographers. Many readers may not have enough scientific knowledge to understand complex ideas without detailed explanations. However, understanding science is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a new language; it just requires effort.

It is unfortunate that educated people who would feel embarrassed not to know a famous writer or artist often do not recognize the contributions of scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin.

**Margaret and Her Water-Finding Skills**

Margaret Wilkins is known for having a special ability, often called a "sixth sense." She can use a forked hazel stick to find water underground. Farmers whose wells have dried up are increasingly asking for her help. Along with her husband, Margaret runs a well-drilling business that uses modern tools like drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers. However, to find water, she relies only on her hazel stick. The couple has a success rate of over 90%.

This ability to find water, minerals, and lost objects underground is known as dowsing. There are many theories about how it works, from scientific ideas like magnetism to spiritual beliefs. One of the most believable theories suggests that everything on Earth vibrates, and water vibrates more than other materials. Some dowsers believe they can sense these vibrations, while others say they can smell water, as smell is a very strong sense.

Recently, during dry years, Margaret has been very busy, with a waiting list of almost six weeks. Most of her customers are farmers with dry wells. She explains, "We usually see customers only once because wells last a long time." Other customers include people with remote cottages or barns that have become holiday homes, where it is too expensive to run water pipes over long distances. There are also golf-course developers who need water for their clubhouses.

Margaret looks for water between 50 and 70 meters deep. She explains, "You can't drill a well if there is a risk of waste getting into the water supply. The water we find is in cracks of solid rock, and if we bring it up correctly, it should be clean. However, in Cornwall, there are many minerals, so we have to be careful about iron."

Another important factor is electricity to run the pump, which can be costly if the well is far from power sources. After considering these factors, Margaret begins her search for water. For large areas like golf courses, she starts with a map and a pendulum. She holds the pendulum still and moves it over the map. It will swing when she is above an area with water.

Once she has identified possible locations on the map, Margaret walks over the fields with her hazel stick, which is forked and equal in size on both sides. "When I am above water, I feel a strange sensation; I sway a little. When that feeling goes away, I use the stick to find the exact spot to drill." She holds the two forks of the stick with both hands and pulls them slightly apart to create tension. "When water is directly below, the straight part of the stick rises. It is crucial to drill exactly where the stick indicates. If we drill even a little off, we might miss the water completely."

Margaret's husband also checks the same area. Usually, but not always, they agree on the exact drilling spot. If they disagree, they will not drill and will keep searching until they find a common agreement.

Margaret Wilkins is not alone in her unique skill; many anthropologists and writers have been intrigued by this mysterious ability. She describes it as an "intuitive perception of the environment," which is the best way to explain how she finds water so accurately. If she did not have this "sixth sense," it would be hard to understand how her family could continue to succeed in their well-drilling business year after year.

**We Changed Lives for a Day!**

Have you ever thought about living someone else's life for a day? It could be fun to try something completely different! We arranged this for four people. Here’s what happened.

**Amanda's Story**

Amanda is 23 and a mother of two daughters. She swapped lives with her friend Cindy, who is 30 and works as a waitress in a busy restaurant in London. 

Amanda had never been in a place like that before. It was dark, loud, and full of people. It was very different from her quiet hometown, and she felt nervous. Being a mother is busy, but waitressing was a whole new challenge! She had only fifteen minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks. The other waitresses made it look easy, but when Amanda tried, the drinks slipped off the tray and spilled everywhere. She felt embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed and told her it happens to everyone.

By 11:30 am, there was a long line of customers waiting to get in, and Amanda felt even more nervous. Luckily, the orders were taken automatically, so she didn’t have to remember them all. After a few hours, her feet hurt, and she struggled to hear customers over the loud music. She often had to ask them to repeat themselves, which was embarrassing. By the end of her shift at 5 pm, she was exhausted and just wanted to soak her feet in hot water. One waitress told her it had been a "quiet" day, and Amanda realized how tiring waitressing could be. She thought it was an easy job, but it actually requires a lot of energy and a friendly attitude. Amanda felt relieved to return to her children, as being a mother seemed much easier after her day as a waitress!

**Cindy's Story**

Cindy is 30 and was nervous about being a mother for a day, but she was also excited. She knew Amanda's daughters could be cheeky, but she thought she could handle it. 

After Amanda left for the restaurant, Cindy had to get the two girls dressed and fed. After dropping Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, she thought she would have some quiet time. But she was wrong! Amanda reminded her that she still had to clean the house and do laundry. 

At 1 pm, Cindy picked up Katie, went shopping, and then took her home for lunch. When she brought Sophie home from school, things got chaotic. The girls turned the couch into a trampoline and screamed loudly while playing. Cindy thought they would tire out, but they had more energy than she expected! After a lot of effort, she finally got them to bed by 8 pm, but then the fun continued. The girls kept asking for water, just to come downstairs and watch TV. Cindy realized how tiring it is to take care of two small children. She had no time for herself, and the responsibility felt overwhelming. Still, she enjoyed the day.

**Rosemary's Story**

Rosemary is 42 and runs a dairy farm. She swapped lives with Hilary, who is 30 and a primary school teacher. 

On the farm, Rosemary usually wakes up at 5:30 am, but on this day, she got to sleep in until 7 am. She was nervous about how to dress for school, so she tried to blend in. At assembly, she hoped no one would notice her. 

In class, the children worked in small groups, which was different from Rosemary's school days. She helped with a nature project about snails. By lunchtime, she was tired and looked forward to a break, but teachers only have about five minutes to eat. After lunch, she attended a staff meeting and helped with athletics trials. The hardest part was speaking in front of the class, even for just two minutes. Although teachers have more holidays, Rosemary decided she prefers farming.

**Hilary's Story**

Hilary arrived at Rosemary's farm at 8:30 am, only to find that Rosemary had been working for three hours already! Rosemary's farm is large, with many cows and sheep. 

Hilary spent the morning in the ice-cream shop, filling milk containers and making ice cream. She had to resist eating the treats! At lunchtime, she checked on the sheep and helped a ewe that had fallen over. If sheep are not checked daily, they can die. After feeding the calves, Hilary started milking, which took two and a half hours. Rosemary does this twice a day, every day of the year!

Hilary found the day lonely and missed being around children, as animals don’t talk back. She realized that farming is not as easy as it seems. The work is constant, and it’s hard to take time off. Rosemary only gets about three days of vacation each year. Farming may look romantic, but the reality is very different, with an unpredictable income and dependence on the weather.

A trumpet isn't just for Christmas... It is interesting how many musicians, even famous ones, come from families without music. Hakan Hardenberger, the only son of parents who did not play music in a small town in southern Sweden, has become a unique trumpet player at the age of 30. His recordings are introducing new music, including concertos by forgotten composers from the baroque and classical periods, as well as new pieces. When you meet him, he looks younger than his age, with a bright and friendly personality, just like the sound of the trumpet.

Recently, he performed the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in one of London’s top concert halls. He also had a feature on television about his work and growth, filmed in both London and Sweden. Born near Malmo, his music career began with a Christmas gift when he was eight years old. His father, who did not play music but liked Louis Armstrong, decided to give his son a real trumpet instead of a toy. The gift was a success, and the boy played constantly. His mother found the second trumpet player in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra and convinced him to give her son lessons. Bo Nilsson, the teacher, quickly recognized Hakan's natural talent. Hardenberger is grateful to have had such a passionate teacher from the beginning, someone who loved the trumpet and sought out players from around the world.

Hardenberger explains that the trumpet is a simple instrument, and it is impossible to make a perfect one. There will always be some imperfections, and no two mouthpieces are exactly alike. He believes it is important to understand these imperfections and learn to work with them. From the start, he had a special ability to find the right balance and connect with the instrument. He notes that even as a child, his unique sound was already noticeable, which was the first thing he developed.

Unlike John Wallace, another famous trumpet player who started in brass bands and orchestras, Hardenberger has always seen himself as a solo artist. He admired the French trumpeter Maurice Andre and bought all his records. His parents supported his dream of becoming a trumpet player and allowed him to practice as much as he wanted. At 15, it was time to decide where he would study. Although Bo Nilsson wanted him to go to America, it was considered too far and dangerous, so at 16, he went to Paris to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud also believed that playing in an orchestra was not as fulfilling as being a soloist.

Hardenberger knew he played better than many of his peers, but it was only after entering a competition at 17 that he realized he had a special talent for connecting with the audience. Thibaud suggested he enter the competition for experience. Hardenberger prepared only for the first round but made it to the second. Fortunately, he already knew most of the pieces for that round too. When he reached the final, he faced a concerto that had intimidated him before. He did not win first prize, but he enjoyed the performance and realized that even if he felt he played poorly, people were still listening.

Hardenberger's honest view of his work might seem arrogant, but that is not the case. He thoughtfully avoids trying to explain what makes his communication with the audience special, saying that doing so might ruin it. He believes the power of music lies in its ability to move people.

**New In Paperback**

A. The story of Tristan Smith, a citizen in the made-up republic of Efica, is a powerful tale about human power, history, and humor. The author skillfully creates a world with its own history, traditions, and customs. The book is also known for its humor and the author's unique perspective, combined with deep psychological insights. It is a challenging but rewarding read.

B. Harriet is a confident middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. Normally, she would not meet Sheila, a traditional working-class woman who cares for her elderly father and has raised her grandson, Leo, since he was three. Their lives change dramatically when Leo violently attacks Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys refuse to discuss what happened. Leo, who was a good student and had never fought before, cannot explain his actions, while Joe physically recovers but becomes withdrawn. Harriet is deeply affected by her son's situation, and caring for him takes over her life. Sheila feels so guilty that she asks to meet Harriet, leading to an unexpected friendship. The author excels at showing how people respond to major changes in their lives and captures a mother's feeling that she can never do enough for her child.

C. This book, which was shortlisted for the Booker Prize, tells the story of one of the most isolated Scottish Orkney islands and its people over a long, quiet history. The narrative is set against important moments in Scottish history, imagined through the daydreams of a young boy named Throfinn Ragnarson. He suddenly disappears in the story but returns after World War II, having learned to appreciate the simple lives of his ancestors.

D. After his recent big success, the author has written a sequel that carries the same gentle humor and sharp observations about family life that made the first book popular. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway is nearing her seventies and has a lively friend, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora's approach to life is a mix of vanity, charm, and reluctant kindness, and Rosie helps her navigate her relationships with suitors and friends. By the end of the book, Aurora must face the passage of time and the arrival of a new generation. The author skillfully reveals the sadness that lies beneath the ordinary moments of life, focusing more on the shadows than the bright spots of human experience.

E. Six very different people are brought together by millionaire Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses beautiful descriptive language to explore the personal journeys of self-discovery that each sailor experiences as they prepare to return home, their spirits lifted by the adventure of being at sea. The author uses striking images to express themes of memory and awareness, which can be both isolating and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**

Rebecca Cripps meets five women who talk about their different jobs, including the good and bad parts and what a typical day looks like for them.

**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**  
**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  

**ANNE'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 6:30 am, go to the gym at 7 am, and arrive at work by 8 am. I start surgeries at 8:30 am. I perform surgeries all day on Mondays and Wednesdays, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most brain surgeries take about three hours, but some can last all day. There are times when I work for ten hours without eating or taking a break. Deciding when to operate can be stressful. I don’t feel stressed during surgery, but I sometimes worry about the next day. Brain surgery is often a last option for patients, but when it is successful, it feels amazing, even if it doesn’t always work. From 10 am to 1 pm, I see outpatients and explain the surgeries to them. I enjoy this and find it easy to talk to patients. If they get upset, I try to comfort them, but time pressure can make this hard. I usually leave work between 6 pm and 8 pm. Some nights and weekends, I am on call, and I always carry my pager. When I’m on holiday, I worry about my patients for the first few days, and I often dream about operating. I find it hard to relax."

**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**  
**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  

**MARITA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7:45 am, leave home by 8:20 am, and take the train to work, arriving at 9:15 am. On Mondays at 10:30 am, we have a meeting to discuss our work and any problems. I work in a team with three senior designers, a partner, and a junior designer. My job is mostly about production, with only 10 to 15 percent being actual design work. I receive a brief from the client, and if they have clear ideas, I spend three to four weeks designing and developing the project. After that, I present my ideas to the client. Once they approve, we create budgets and I start hiring photographers and illustrators. I also work with printers to ensure everything is done on time. Managing people is a big part of my job, and I need to communicate well with everyone. When their work comes in, I put everything together and send it to the printers. Juggling several projects can be very stressful, and deadlines are always tight. I usually have lunch at 1 pm for an hour, and we often go to a pub. If the client likes my designs, it feels great, but it’s disappointing when a project gets rejected. I usually get home by 7:30 pm, but sometimes it’s much later. I find it hard to relax after a busy day."

**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**  
**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  

**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I usually wake up around 7 am, but on some days, I have to get up between 4:30 am and 5 am to meet long-haul flights. At 10:30 or 11 am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. Since chauffeuring is a sitting job, I need to watch my diet and exercise. I usually have a big breakfast and snack during the day. People often ask for my recommendations for restaurants or shops, so I need to know the area well. Many jobs are pre-booked, which helps me plan my routes. Not all passengers are polite; some can be rude, but most are nice, and I have good relationships with my regular clients. Sometimes I hear private conversations in the car, but I focus on driving. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day, so I have to be careful not to get too tired. I try to go to bed by 11 pm."

**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**  
**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  

**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I wake up around 7 am, leave home at 7:30 am, and go to my first job. My assistant and I mainly maintain gardens we designed. We do some commercial work, but most is in private gardens, spending about an hour and a half at each place. Around 11 am, we take a break and go to a local café for breakfast. In summer, I might work until 10 pm, and in winter until 4:30 pm. I have a home office, so when I return, I check messages and calls. If someone wants a new garden, I usually set up a meeting in the evening. We focus on using old materials to make gardens look historic. Sometimes clients have strange ideas, but it’s very satisfying to see a garden we created bloom. I find it hard to relax in the evenings because I can hear the business phone ringing. I sleep well because my job is physically demanding, and I’m always tired at the end of the day."

**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**  
**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  

**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at the construction site by 8:30 am. I am the assistant resident engineer, overseeing the building of bridges and a retaining wall. I check that the contractors are following the schedule and safety rules while minimizing environmental impact. I help coordinate the site workers and solve any problems. The contractors start at 6 am, so my first task is to find out what happened since I left the night before. The rest of my day depends on what I learn from the clerk of works. I usually have paperwork to review or design questions to answer. I take a half-hour lunch break between 2 pm and 2:30 pm, but I often eat on the go. Since we check the contractors' work, it can create tension, so we need to maintain a good relationship. I see the resident engineer once a day, but if something urgent comes up, I act immediately. I usually leave the site around 6 pm and am on call all the time."

**Careers: Six People Talk About Their Typical Working Day**

**A. Credit Card Executive**  
I wake up at 6 am and get to the office by 7:30 am. I manage programs for our credit card users, including the Membership Rewards scheme in Europe. My job involves keeping in touch with current card users, finding new ones, and building relationships with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes organizing my day and then respond to emails. I work with marketing staff and advertising agencies to plan our advertising strategy. I have many meetings throughout the day, but I keep my door open for anyone who has questions. I travel to different European markets once or twice a week to discuss any issues. When I’m in London, I usually leave work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.

**B. Record Company Executive**  
I start work at 10:00 am and check the mail, which includes about ten to twenty demo tapes, letters from producers, concert information, and invoices. The phone starts ringing around 10:30 am with calls from producers and publishers. I have meetings throughout the day to discuss projects for artists, which may involve the press and marketing teams. When I listen to demo tapes, I know that these are important to the artists, so I try to give helpful feedback. Once I sign a band, we begin working on their first album, choosing songs and a producer. I also manage budgets and spending. I usually leave work by 7:00 pm and often go to concerts, sometimes seeing up to five new bands in one night. I often don’t get home until 1:00 am, when I listen to music to relax.

**C. Sales Director**  
I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work, arriving by 9:30 am. I check the mail and my schedule to see if we have any clients visiting. I enjoy showing customers around the showroom and selling furniture. We sell antiques that cost between £1,000 and £6,000, and we buy from various sources. Many items need restoration, so I work with restorers and other specialists. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette while drinking coffee to stay updated on the business. I handle accounts once a month and do tax returns every three months. I usually go home at 5:30 pm, and it takes me about an hour to relax after work.

**D. Air Traffic Controller**  
I work on a set shift schedule. On early shifts, I leave home at 6:00 am and start work at 7:00 am, taking over from the night shift. I control aircraft movements with a team, working at different stations for about an hour and a half at a time. In winter, we manage around 1,000 movements a day, and even more in summer. Night shifts are quieter, and I often read about new air traffic rules during those hours. This job can be stressful, and I take sick days if I feel unwell. I hope to become a watch manager and eventually the general manager of the airport.

**E. Shop Manager**  
If I have an early shift, I leave home by 8:00 am. I start by setting up the electronic point-of-sale system and making sure someone is at the till. I spend the morning helping customers find and order books. I enjoy serving customers, but it can be challenging when they expect me to gather many books quickly. From 2:00 pm to 4:00 pm, publishers’ representatives visit, and I discuss new titles with them. I need to decide how many copies of each title we should order. I finish my early shift at 5:45 pm. On two days a week, I work late, closing the computer system and locking up before going home.

**F. Financial Analyst**  
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then get up and take a taxi to work, arriving by 8:45 am. I contact freelance reporters to find out what is happening in my area. I assess financial risks for companies operating abroad, warning clients about potential problems. I provide three services: an online newsflash, a security forecast, and a travel information security guide. From 9:15 am to 9:30 am, I meet with editors to discuss the stories I will cover. I have tight deadlines, with my first report due by 10:00 am and the second by 11:00 am. I travel to Africa about three times a year to report on events. I usually leave work around 6:00 pm, but it can be hard to relax, and I often stay awake until 1:00 am.

**Career Power: Take Control at Work**

**A. What Makes a Good Leader?**  
A good leader inspires others and helps create change. Leadership is not about being tall or having a high IQ. According to Pat Dixon, author of *Making the Difference: Women and Men in the Workplace*, leadership is about getting things done with the help of enthusiastic people. A good leader should communicate clearly and confidently. Dixon says it’s important to say "I believe" instead of "I think."

**B. Discovering Your Leadership Potential**  
John van Maurik, who runs a Leadership in Management course, believes that most people have more leadership potential than they realize. Becoming a leader means recognizing and developing your hidden talents. In a way, we are all born leaders; we just need the right environment to grow. While it’s easy to see leadership in famous figures like Emmeline Pankhurst or Mahatma Gandhi, it can be harder to see it in our own workplaces. However, leadership is now seen as essential for good management.

**C. Comparing Bosses**  
Think about the best and worst boss you’ve had. They might have been equally good at setting goals and meeting deadlines. But how did they achieve these goals? The best leader motivated you and provided support. The worst leader made you feel unimportant and blamed you when things went wrong. The first was a great leader; the second was a poor manager.

**D. Leaders vs. Managers**  
Leaders and managers are different. Managers like to work within set rules, while leaders create new opportunities. Micheal Shea, author of *Leadership Rules*, says a good manager can keep a company running smoothly, but a good leader can change a struggling organization for the better.

**E. Improving Your Leadership Skills**  
Whether you are a boss or a middle manager, you can improve your leadership skills. Here are some tips:  
- Leadership works best when you choose to lead. Find what you are passionate about and act on it when you feel inspired.  
- Start seeing yourself as a leader. Your ability to lead is an important part of who you are.  
- Collaboration is good, but sometimes strong leadership is needed. Try different leadership styles. If you usually ask for others' opinions, try taking charge instead. Notice how this changes the results.  
- Set goals and strive to achieve them. Identify areas in your job where being a leader can improve your effectiveness and career.

**F. Developing Leadership Skills**  
- Leadership doesn’t just happen; it develops through taking charge, taking risks, and learning from mistakes. Learn to delegate, motivate, organize, and give feedback.  
- Don’t assume everyone will accept your leadership style right away. Work on your communication skills. You don’t need to be liked, but your ideas should be respected.  
- Be visible and approachable to important people.  
- Remember, you don’t have to lead all the time. Know when your leadership is needed and how you can help others become leaders too.

**Films on Video: Reviews by Film Critic Nick James**

**A. Abyss**  
Before "Titanic," director James Cameron created a tense Cold War thriller called "Abyss." It tells the story of oil workers and navy experts trying to save a nuclear submarine deep underwater. The characters, especially foreman Bud and his team, remind us of tough heroes from older films by Howard Hawks. The film has great production design and special effects, but the dialogue and character development are weak. Despite the skilled filmmaking, the story feels like a typical B-movie.

**B. The Thin Red Line**  
This video release of "The Thin Red Line," based on James Jones's novel about the battle for Guadalcanal, offers a different take compared to Terrence Malick's recent film. While Malick's version is poetic and mystical, Andrew Marton's film is more traditional but often stays true to the book. It focuses on one soldier and his difficult relationship with his tough sergeant. Malick's film is richer and more complex, but Marton's version has its strong moments, especially a flashback where the soldier dreams of his wife.

**C. On Guard**  
"On Guard" is a fun swashbuckler inspired by Paul Feval's 1875 novel. It stands out from other musketeer films with a great villain played by Fabrice Luchini, who is a sneaky politician causing chaos. Vincent Perez plays a lively hero, and although Daniel Auteuil might be too serious for this type of film, he also has his good moments as a swordsman. The filmmakers use familiar costume-drama elements with so much charm that it doesn't feel boring.

**D. Character**  
"Character" is a serious story set in early 1900s Rotterdam. The detailed production and costumes make it look like a museum piece. Jan Decleir plays the harsh bailiff Dreverhaven, who is cruel to his tenants. The main conflict is between him and his son, but the filmmakers focus too much on the historical details and not enough on the dark story.

**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This newly re-mastered version of "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly" highlights director Leone's skills. The sound editing is excellent, making every sound clear. The story is harsh, and whenever it slows down, Morricone's powerful music brings excitement back. Morally, there isn't much difference between the good (Clint Eastwood), the bad (Lee van Cleef), and the ugly (Ell Wallach), as they all act ruthlessly in the post-Civil War West.

**F. The Longest Day**  
The promotion for "The Longest Day" boasts about its "forty-eight international stars." With four directors and 23,000 extras, it feels overdone. The early scenes, where experienced soldiers wait for news about the invasion, are slow and drag on for both the audience and the characters. While it is impressive in terms of logistics, it really needs to be seen on a big screen. Watching it on video makes the experience less enjoyable.

**BOOK A** Steve Martin's *Compelling Evidence* is indeed very interesting. The story follows a lawyer who is trying to start a new practice after leaving a powerful law firm. He ends up defending his boss's wife, who is on trial for her husband's murder. The trial scenes are exciting, and the outcome is uncertain until the very end, with a surprising twist in the last pages. This is a great first book in a popular genre.

**BOOK B** *Curtains for the Cardinal* starts with a strong beginning and follows the charming Sigismondo, a problem-solver for the rich during the Italian Renaissance. He gets caught up in a mix of politics, church secrets, and serious crimes, but we always believe he will find out who is guilty. The plot is complicated, and the book is a bit too long, but it is still very enjoyable.

**BOOK C** *File Under: Deceased* introduces a new detective from first-time author Sarah Lacey. Leah Hunter is a tax inspector who finds herself in a detective role when a strange man collapses at her feet. Despite facing challenges and the disapproval of a handsome local detective, Leah is brave and skilled, making her a great character.

**BOOK D** *Double Deuce* by Robert B. Parker features Spenser, a smart private investigator, who helps his friend Hawk remove drug dealers from a poor neighborhood in Boston. The dialogue is quick and clever, and while there are not many deaths, there is more thoughtful discussion than usual. Parker always provides high-quality entertainment.

**BOOK E** *False Prophet* by Faye Kellermann includes her regular detectives, Pete Decker and Marge Dunn, who investigate a robbery and attack at the home of a famous film star's daughter. The author's easy writing style and attention to unusual human behavior make this an enjoyable mystery.

**BOOK F** *Blood Red, Snow White* is written by husband and wife team Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock. It features another lawyer and a female client, but the action takes place outside the courtroom, and the lawyer becomes a victim as the story unfolds. The book combines romance, money, and violence to create a gripping suspense novel.

**BOOK G** *Dead for a Ducat* by Simon Shaw features actor Philip Fletcher as a character who is supposed to be the victim. A funny group of characters comes together to film a story about Robin Hood, but Philip feels that this is not the right direction for his career. Simon Shaw usually entertains well, but this time the shift from dark comedy to farce is not as strong as his usual work.

**BOOK H** *Fall Down Easy* is Lawrence Gough's best book in a while. It follows Canadian police as they search for a clever bank robber who targets female bank tellers. The story builds tension slowly and portrays the intelligent but troubled robber, making it stand out from typical detective novels.

I might be too old for this adventure, but here I go! At 34, Tim Pozzi has left a good job to go backpacking. He thinks about why he and others his age are making this choice. This summer, I quit my job and decided to rent out my flat to travel in South East Asia for a year. You might think I'm lucky, but I'm also nervous. I have traveled before; after university, I spent two years backpacking in North and South America. When I returned, I promised myself I would do it again someday. But then life happened: I fell in love, started a career, bought a flat, and got used to earning a salary. Over time, I realized I was sacrificing my happiness for my job. When I handed in my resignation, it felt like I was taking control of my life again. 

I have no ties now. Many of my friends are married with children, and while they wouldn’t trade places with me, they envy my freedom. I’m not in a relationship and I don’t have strong career goals. I feel I should make the most of this freedom, at least for my friends’ sake! But why am I so nervous? First, I need to make all the arrangements. How can I let someone else live in my home? How do I organize the rental? And I still need to decide where to go. I tend to procrastinate and I’m already behind schedule. I thought, “I might as well enjoy the summer in England,” and then, “Why not wait for the football season to start?”

Letting go of emotional ties makes it harder. I’m delaying because I wonder if I can still handle backpacking. Will I be able to adjust to a simpler way of life? Will I feel out of place among younger backpackers? Maybe not. I’ve noticed that more Britons in their late twenties and thirties want to break free from their lives and travel abroad. Jennifer Cox from Lonely Planet says that more people are realizing that adventure is possible: “People who always say ‘I wish I had that opportunity’ are now understanding they can have it anytime. They just need to be brave, organized, and confident.”

For Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, this trip is a chance to enjoy life before settling down. They bought a round-the-world ticket for a year. Danny says, “I’m willing to give up job security for this trip. There’s always a worry that I won’t move up in my career when I return, but I think it’s a risk worth taking. When I left the office, I threw my calculator into the river as a sign of defiance!”

For Matt, who just left the Army, traveling for a year was a time of change. “In the military, there’s a strict way of doing things. I needed to change that to live well as a civilian.” There are many reasons for people my age to travel, but some common factors exist. Angela Baron from the Institute of Personnel Development says, “Today’s workforce is more flexible. Many people work on short-term contracts, so if your contract ends, you have nothing to lose.” Some large companies even have policies for career breaks. “If you’ve invested time and money in training someone, it’s good to know they’ll return instead of going to a competitor.”

Dan Hiscocks, managing director of Travellerseye, says more thirty-somethings are reassessing their lives. “If you’re not happy with your job—and many people aren’t—it’s no longer just about sticking it out. People know there are opportunities, and jobs aren’t permanent anymore. Travel allows you to step back and think about your life.”

Is wanting to travel just a sign that my generation struggles with adulthood? Jennifer Cox doesn’t think so. “It shows a better-educated, more stable society. We care less about just paying bills and more about living a balanced life. We’re taking the time to ask, ‘Is this what I want?’” Ben, a 32-year-old picture researcher going to Central America for a year, believes he’s not running away. “I’m running towards something. I want to grab opportunities for myself.” But he also feels nervous about leaving his comfortable routine of going to the office and chatting with colleagues.

I share Ben’s concerns about leaving a stable life with few challenges. I’m not sure I would be going on this journey if I hadn’t found my boss so difficult. Jennifer Cox points out that this is common. “There’s often a trigger, like a breakup or losing a job, that pushes people to travel.” It took a little push for me to get moving, but I’m now looking forward to the next 12 months with excitement. No matter what happens, I’ll be proud to have taken this step. I believe many of us older backpackers feel the same way.

**Plugging in the Home**

Georgina McGuiness took a long break from journalism and felt out of touch with new technology. In this article, she shares how she turned her home into an efficient workplace.

The Christmas before last, I turned 37 and realized I needed to revive my journalism career, which I thought was lost due to technology. Looking at my resume, I saw that I was stuck in the 1980s, when typewriters were the latest technology. I felt that no one would trust me to use a computer in a newsroom. Many job ads asked for experience in desktop publishing, which I didn’t have. I thought I would have a better chance of hosting a seminar on nuclear physics than learning to design a page on a computer. I was the family technophobe; even using a calculator was confusing for me, and I still didn’t know how to use the timer on the video.

I knew I had to act quickly to fill the gap in my career. I thought leaving home before my children would be difficult, but then I entered a competition in a local newspaper. To my surprise, my family and I won a computer package. We received a laptop for my husband and a personal computer for the family. We jumped into this new world, and terms like cyberspace, Internet, and surfing became part of our everyday language. We started chatting online with strangers from around the world. The children stopped watching TV, and I set up a small office in the kitchen with a phone, a fax machine, a CD-ROM, and a modem to connect to the Internet. I had everything I needed to work from home while still taking the kids to school.

My children were already comfortable with computers from school, but I was nervous, thinking I would lose my work if I pressed the wrong button. I was wrong. Although I wasn’t very skilled, I learned the basics. It turned out to be logical and easy. With practice, I improved a little every day. I recently started freelancing for a magazine, writing about two articles a month, and I feel proud to have the best of both worlds.

How has the computer helped me? Since school, my desk has always been a mess, and I often lost important papers. The computer has made me more organized, especially with office tasks. I can use spreadsheets to track income and expenses, and ready-made invoices and letterheads save me a lot of time. As a journalist, being online allows me to research stories, ask for information in forums, and discuss the pros and cons of working from home with people worldwide.

However, there are downsides to working from home. You can feel isolated without face-to-face contact. There are also distractions, like household chores, and when the kids are home, we sometimes argue over who gets to use the computer. Still, more people are buying multimedia PCs, not just for education and entertainment, but also for the convenience of avoiding the daily commute to the city.

As we move into the next century, a report called "PC Usage in UK Homes" describes the typical computer user: they are 38 years old and well-educated; 93% own a personal computer, 32% have a CD-ROM, 38% have a laser printer, and 50% have a modem. Considering this, I feel I am ahead of the game. Who knows, one day I might be emailing a column to a newspaper in Melbourne or even publishing my own magazine from home. It seems that the possibilities are endless in this digital age.

**The Tartan Museum**

The Tartan Museum is located in Edinburgh, Scotland, and its modern design stands out against the historic city. Sally Varlow visited the museum just before it opened to see what it had to offer.

You can't miss the new Museum of Scotland. It has a large yellow sandstone tower and unique buildings that look like cheese wedges. Last winter, people had mixed feelings about the building. Some called it a "masterpiece" or "stunning," while others were more cautious or even negative. Now, as the museum prepares to open, the exhibitions are also expected to receive mixed reactions.

The museum tells the story of Scotland through many interesting displays. It features important historical objects, like jewels belonging to Mary Queen of Scots and silver from Holyrood chapel. The museum is designed to be enjoyable for everyone, not just experts. Dr. David Clarke, who leads the exhibitions, believes that visitors should have a pleasant visual experience.

Dr. Clarke prefers to show real objects rather than imaginary scenes from the past. He believes that the public deserves to know the truth about history. This means that what you see in the museum is based on what experts have discovered.

However, there is a question about whether the stories of these objects can be told effectively using just explanation panels, captions, and multimedia displays. The museum has around 30 computers to help with this, but it is still uncertain how engaging the experience will be.

Inside the museum, visitors will notice a variety of gallery spaces with pale walls that look like stone. Natural light comes in through special windows and roof lights, creating a pleasant atmosphere to enjoy the displays.

The museum also has a Discovery Centre, thanks to a group of children aged 9 to 12 from all over Scotland. They wanted to create a fun way to explore the exhibits. Although they didn't get to ride through the displays, they did create a hands-on area for children.

The Twentieth Century gallery on the top floor is the only temporary exhibition. It features items chosen by Scottish people that have had a significant impact on life in Scotland during the twentieth century. Suggestions included an electric guitar, televisions, and favorite toys. While this idea is entertaining, it may not address more serious topics.

Dr. Clarke believes that objects can tell stories about the past better than anything else. As for the museum's modern architecture, it looks great from the inside and the top, but whether it fits well in its historic location is still up for debate.

**The Future of Print Newspapers**

The idea of "transition" is often seen as a positive change. It means moving from the present to the future in a smooth way. However, the transition of newspapers to the online world is not so easy. Many people believe that this change will happen eventually because print newspaper sales are falling while visits to their websites are increasing. For example, newspapers like The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian have seen their print sales drop by 8% to 10% each year, while their online traffic continues to grow.

But not everything is clear. A recent survey by the World Association of Newspapers showed that global newspaper circulation actually increased by 1.1% last year, reaching 512 million copies a day. While sales in Western countries have decreased, Asia has seen a rise in sales. News magazines, which many think would struggle in the digital age, reported a 5.4% increase in sales.

The same trend is seen in books. E-readers like Kindle are becoming very popular, with sales rising significantly. However, when bookstores looked at the sales of physical books over the last six months, they found only a small decrease of 0.4%. This suggests that people are buying both digital and physical books.

The idea that young people are completely giving up reading newspapers is not entirely true. Recent data shows that nearly 5 million people aged 15 to 35 still read major national newspapers. Different countries also have different trends. In Britain, print sales have dropped by 10.8%, but in Germany, the decline is only 7%, and in France, it is just 3.1%.

Media experts in the US once believed that online advertising would support the shift to digital newspapers. However, digital ad revenues are now falling, and many major US newspapers have started charging for online access. The best way to attract paying readers seems to be offering both print and digital subscriptions together. This means that print newspapers are still important for selling online subscriptions, as they generate much more advertising revenue than online ads.

Maintaining both a print edition and a website is challenging and costly for newspaper companies. However, print newspapers still have a strong presence, and being noticed online is much harder.

**Photographing People**

People are the most interesting subjects to photograph. A picture with a person is usually more engaging than one without. However, photographing people can be challenging. Besides technical skills, photographers must pay attention to actions, gestures, and expressions. The camera can sometimes make people act differently.

**A. Grouping People**  
When taking group photos, avoid straight lines. Ask people to stand at different angles and distances. If possible, have some people sit or kneel in front so all faces are visible, or raise your viewpoint.

**B. Posing for Pictures**  
People often feel stiff in front of the camera. Help them relax by suggesting comfortable positions, like folding their hands or putting them in their pockets.

**C. The Right Approach**  
Don’t pretend you are not taking a picture when it’s obvious. This can create tension. Most people will agree to have their picture taken, but they may feel self-conscious. You might need to guide them to look at the camera instead of off to the side.

**D. Eye Contact**  
A picture is more powerful if the subject looks at the viewer. Ask them to look into the lens, and remind them just before you take the shot. You can also say something funny to get a natural reaction.

**E. Candid Concentration**  
Instead of direct eye contact, have the subject focus on something in the picture. This can make them feel more comfortable, and it gives the viewer a sense of observing the subject naturally.

**F. Expressions and Gestures**  
Expressions and gestures reveal a lot about a person. A laughing child can make viewers smile, while a sad face can evoke sympathy. Look for common expressions like shrugs, winks, or smiles; they communicate feelings instantly.

**G. Situation Interest**  
While close-up shots of faces are impactful, the background can add more context. When including a background, avoid distracting details. Use a wide-angle lens to make the subject stand out against the background.

**H. Interaction**  
Capturing moments where people interact, like talking or laughing, can lead to great photos. Look for connections, such as eye contact or physical touch, to show relationships between people.

**I. People and Places**  
Many photos of people are taken during trips. To show both the person and the place, use a wide-angle lens and step back to include the background. Position the subjects close to the camera to create a balanced picture.

**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**  
Decide why you want to take the picture. If it’s to remember someone, a posed photo might be best. However, family pictures can become boring if they are all formal poses. Candid shots of events are often more lively and memorable. A spontaneous picture can capture real moments better than a posed one.

**Under Sarah's Spell**

Sarah Janson is a trompe-l'oeil artist, which means she creates paintings that trick the eye into seeing something that looks real. In this interview with Joanna Watt, we learn more about her.

Not many artists choose not to sign their work, but Sarah Janson is one of them. She believes that the artwork is more important than the artist. She says, "It's not the artist who is important, but the work." Sarah is very humble and almost makes it seem like her paintings create themselves. This attitude makes it a bit challenging to interview her. She admits, "I just don't like to shout about myself," and she even gets nervous when asked to be photographed.

After some time, Sarah becomes more comfortable, and the interview turns into a fun and interesting conversation. She has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years. Before that, she spent two years drawing at art school, earned a degree in graphic illustration, and worked at a publishing house. However, she was not satisfied with illustration and decided to work with a specialist decorator named Jim Smart. He asked her to create one trompe-l'oeil painting, and that sparked her interest. She left to start her own career, unsure of where it would lead but feeling it was the right choice.

Sarah's skills in observation and attention to detail, developed through her illustration work, are very important for her trompe-l'oeil art. She often gets asked where people can learn this technique, but she believes it cannot be taught. "Trompe-l'oeil is the school of life. It's all about observation," she explains. She feels she is still learning and says, "The moment you think you've mastered a field, you might as well give up."

Sarah is honest about her weaknesses, like her struggle to paint bread, which she says always looks like grey concrete. She also admits to having trouble with math, especially when she had to measure for a large project at Lulworth Castle. She often questions herself, saying things like, "You're not Michelangelo. Who do you think you are?" This self-doubt makes her view her talent from a distance. Sometimes she talks about herself in the third person, saying, "When I finished that ceiling, I thought, 'Well, I didn't do it, she did.'"

Her trompe-l'oeil work is exceptional and stands out from others in the field. She has completed many important projects for both businesses and private clients. Much of her art is inspired by architecture. For example, she created a trompe-l'oeil dining room based on a Venetian palace and a painting that makes it look like you can enter two more rooms at the end of a hallway.

However, there is a risk with trompe-l'oeil art: once people understand the trick, they may lose interest. Sarah knows this and says, "Trompe-l'oeil has to do two things. First, it must draw you in; it's got to trick you. Secondly, it has to hold you and engage your imagination. That is the most important part."

Sarah believes that trompe-l'oeil art should also be personal to the client. She enjoys working with clients because that is where the best ideas come from. "Without the rapport, the job of creating a trompe-l'oeil scheme becomes rather difficult," she says. Some clients have clear ideas, while others do not, so she must listen carefully to understand their vision. Many of her clients become friends because she spends a lot of time with them while working on their projects.

Sarah appreciates her clients, saying, "I am very grateful for the mad ones who have let me loose on their walls." They seem happy with her work, which is why she is always busy, even though she tends to downplay her talent. "I really don't like to shout about myself," she repeats. "Like my work, I am very restrained. I don't want it to shout. You become bored with things that shout." 

While she may not want to draw attention to herself, her work is certainly impressive and deserves to be recognized more widely.

**Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West**

Acupuncture is a practice that is over two thousand years old. It comes from traditional Chinese medicine, which also includes herbal medicine, massage, diet, and exercise. Acupuncture is used to treat many health issues, but it is especially known for helping with pain. Some general practitioners (GPs), midwives, and physiotherapists use it regularly for pain relief.

**What is Traditional Chinese Medicine?**

Traditional Chinese medicine believes that health is when the energy of the mind, body, and spirit are balanced. This energy, called Qi (pronounced "chee"), flows through the body along pathways known as meridians. There are twelve main meridians, each connected to an internal organ, and many smaller meridians that carry Qi to every cell. If the flow of Qi is blocked or weak, it can lead to weakness or illness. During a visit to an acupuncturist, they will check for imbalances in your Qi by feeling your pulse, looking at your tongue, and assessing your overall health. They will also ask about your medical history, current health, mental state, and your eating and sleeping habits. Acupuncturists use very thin needles that are inserted into the skin. They may also use heat from burning herbs or apply pressure to certain points to help the flow of Qi.

**Acupuncture Points**

The points used in acupuncture are connected to the meridians and may not be near the area that hurts. Many people report feeling a mild ache or tingling when the needle is gently moved. This can be done by hand or with a machine that provides electrical stimulation. Acupuncturists believe this sensation means the needle has reached the Qi in a meridian. There are over three hundred acupuncture points on the main meridians, with many more that are used less frequently.

**Scientific Understanding**

Even though not all doctors accept the ideas of traditional Chinese medicine, many agree that acupuncture can help relieve pain. Scientists have suggested that acupuncture might work by blocking pain signals from reaching the brain or by releasing natural pain-relieving chemicals in the body called endorphins.

**Types of Pain Treated**

Many people with long-term pain try acupuncture when other treatments have not worked. Commonly treated pains include back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, and pain after surgery. Acupuncturists also claim to help with menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain in terminally ill patients.

**Modern Use of Acupuncture**

Although acupuncture has been practiced in China for over 2,000 years, its use as an alternative to anesthesia during surgery began in the 1950s. This helped some doctors outside China to see that acupuncture has real benefits. In China today, acupuncture is used in many types of surgeries, from tonsil removals to heart surgery. Needles can be used alone, with electrical stimulation, or with medication. While some people report that pain is greatly reduced, results can vary from person to person. Many might find the idea of being awake during surgery unappealing, but acupuncturists say that acupuncture has fewer side effects than traditional anesthesia and allows for quicker recovery.

**Effectiveness of Acupuncture**

Like many alternative therapies, it can be hard to conduct clinical trials on acupuncture. However, studies show that 50 to 80 percent of people find it effective for chronic pain. Acupuncturists generally agree with this success rate. They understand that it may not work for everyone and that people respond differently. Traditional acupuncturists suggest that for long-term pain, it usually takes six to seven visits to feel significant relief, but some improvement can be felt after just two or three sessions.

**A Different View on Pain**

Western and Chinese medicine have different views on pain. Acupuncturists look at their patients as a whole, not just focusing on specific symptoms. They spend time diagnosing the problem and looking for underlying issues with the Qi. They also consider external factors that might affect the pain, such as weather conditions or the type of pain (sharp, dull, throbbing, etc.). These factors are important in deciding how to use acupuncture for treatment, which is not something most medical doctors would typically consider.

**Choosing an Acupuncturist**

Some medical professionals have training in traditional acupuncture, while others, including many GPs, prefer scientific explanations. Traditional acupuncturists believe that using traditional methods can lead to deeper healing, which is hard to measure in studies. It is important to choose a qualified acupuncturist, who should refer you to a medical doctor if further investigation is needed.

P.D. James is a well-known crime writer whose gentle appearance hides a clever and imaginative mind. Her full name is Phyllis Dorothy James, and she has a strong presence that makes you think she could have been a headmistress at a girls' school if she hadn’t become a writer. However, she is actually quite shy. She admits that her main character, Adam Dalgliesh, the detective in her books, is based on herself, or how she might have been if she were a man. Dalgliesh likes to solve crimes alone, just like P.D. James prefers to write in private. 

Although she is considered one of Britain’s best crime writers, she is modest about her success. Her 12 detective novels are popular worldwide, and she enjoys reading the works of her friend Ruth Rendell, especially those written under the name Barbara Vine. She also likes books by female authors like Iris Murdoch and Anita Brookner, but she appreciates male writers like Graham Greene and Evelyn Waugh as well.

P.D. James found success later in life. She was 42 when her first novel, Cover Her Face, was published. She was born in Oxford and grew up in Cambridge. She met her husband there, who was a university student. She chose Cambridge as the setting for one of her books, An Unsuitable Job For A Woman. 

Her life has not always been easy. After her husband, Connor Bantry White, returned from World War II very ill, she had to work long hours to support him and their two daughters, Clare and Jane. Although she had many ideas for stories, she struggled to find time to write. Thankfully, her husband’s parents helped take care of the children during those tough years.

While working full-time in the National Health Service, she used her strong organizational skills. She managed several psychiatric clinics and later worked for 11 years at the Home Office, first in the Police Department and then in juvenile crime. During her time in forensic science, she became used to seeing dead bodies, but she was not interested in death itself. Instead, she loved the challenge of writing a crime novel. 

P.D. James did not want to write about her own life experiences. She saw writing detective stories as a good way to learn how to be a serious novelist while keeping her personal life separate. She realized that it was possible to follow the traditional structure of a detective story and still create a meaningful novel about people. For her, writing detective stories is a way to bring order to chaos, and solving a crime shows the value of life, even if that life is difficult. She believes that nobody truly enjoys violence.

**The Pen is Mightier than the Psychoanalyst**

The study of handwriting to understand a person's character is becoming more popular. In some countries, if you apply for a job, you will likely be asked to provide a sample of your handwriting. This handwriting sample can play a big role in deciding if you are suitable for the job. Handwriting analysis, also known as graphology, is considered a real science in many places. Researchers believe it can help identify certain health issues, like heart disease and cancer, and can show psychological states and emotional problems. 

More companies are using handwriting analysis for job guidance and during interviews. Many large companies now hire graphologists to examine the handwriting of job candidates. However, many doctors and psychiatrists are skeptical about the usefulness of graphology. Patricia Marne, a professional graphologist with over 20 years of experience, argues that it should be taken more seriously. She believes handwriting can reveal psychological traits and some medical conditions. 

Marne states, "Handwriting is a strong indicator of social class and intelligence. It can also help determine if someone should focus on arts or sciences and whether they have a deceitful or honest character." She claims that graphology can be especially helpful in identifying possible criminal behavior. According to her, criminals often have disturbed handwriting, which can be poorly shaped and childish. Many criminals come from difficult backgrounds and show emotional issues, which can be seen in their handwriting.

Marne explains that handwriting can indicate if someone is honest, manipulative, or reliable. For example, young male offenders often have tall letters, suggesting they live in a fantasy world. Graphologists can also predict if someone is under extreme stress or has violent tendencies. Handwriting can even help identify potential suicides. 

She notes that heart and lung problems can sometimes be seen in handwriting. "You can't make a diagnosis from just one sample unless the writing is clearly shaky or disturbed. But if handwriting changes over time or if a signature breaks from its usual style, it could mean something serious is happening," she says. A major emotional upset can also change a person's signature temporarily.

Marne explains that handwriting can show other psychological traits. For instance, people whose letters connect in a thread-like way may be clever but deceitful. Those who write mostly in capital letters might be hiding their true selves. Light pressure in writing can indicate sensitivity and low energy. The more original the handwriting is, the more it shows confidence and creativity. Disconnected writing often suggests a person is a loner. Very small signatures can indicate feelings of inferiority, while circles over the letter "i" may show a desire for attention. Heavy crossing of the letter "t" can suggest intolerance and a condescending attitude.

Marne believes it takes six years of study and experience to analyze handwriting accurately, along with empathy and intuition. She thinks more research is needed to establish graphology as a scientific field, and she believes this will happen soon. "It's actually more accurate than psychoanalysis because it can reveal a person's entire history, including emotional crises, without asking them questions that they might answer incorrectly."

Despite these interesting claims, there is little solid evidence to support them. Some psychiatrists criticize graphology, arguing that handwriting is influenced by education, artistic skills, and the type of writing taught, and that it has no deeper meaning.

**Is Your Office Working Well?**

Fresh air and good chairs are important for a happy and healthy workplace, according to a new survey. We visited four different offices to see how healthy and happy they are. Our expert panel included a building health consultant, an ergonomist (who studies working conditions), and an occupational psychologist. Here are their opinions.

**Office A: Advertising Agency**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office is very simple; it has no central heating or mechanical ventilation, and the windows open directly to the street. It’s surprising that this space works, but the small team of seven people seems happy. They adapt to the weather by opening doors or using electric heaters, similar to how they would at home. This may be the reason for their happiness; they have created a comfortable working environment without too many rules.

- **Ergonomist:** The furniture is mismatched and creates bad sitting positions. Many chairs are old and not adjustable. However, the staff has a varied work schedule, which helps reduce tiredness and boredom.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** The team enjoys the variety of work and the office size. It’s small enough to know what everyone is doing but big enough to focus on personal tasks. The office feels attractive and fun, showing both efficiency and creativity.

**Office B: News Service**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office may not be very exciting, but it is comfortable and the staff does not dislike it. The air quality is good, partly because of a No Smoking policy.

- **Ergonomist:** The company has hired an ergonomist, so the chairs and lighting are good. The layout could be better, but the environment feels impersonal with plain grey walls.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** The walls are mostly bare, except for some planners and a poster about maternity rights. Most staff have been there for over five years, and relationships are good. The office could improve by arranging desks to make sharing information easier.

**Office C: Bank**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office gets mixed reactions. It feels like being in a glass box, with many people around. The air quality is surprisingly good, even with smokers nearby.

- **Ergonomist:** The office is standard and uninspiring. The desks are just okay, and not all chairs are suitable for computer work. The setup for computer screens is outdated.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** Staff support each other well and have good technology. There are many awards on display, but the wood paneling and brown carpet make it feel a bit dull. The office is busy with activity.

**Office D: Newspaper**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office has many problems. The air conditioning is not good, leading to uncomfortable temperature changes. The space is cluttered, and there is not enough desk space. It is also very dusty.

- **Ergonomist:** The furniture looks more like it belongs in a workshop than an office. Many chairs are old and not suitable for people who work at computers.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** The office has old chairs and dirty carpets. It needs a good cleaning, and individual achievements should be recognized more. The air conditioning needs to be fixed, especially since there are many smokers. When we visited, there were few conversations, and everyone seemed stressed and focused on deadlines. The company should encourage teamwork.

**Chewing Gum Culture**

Chewing gum is popular, does not belong to any social class, and Americans chew about 12 million sticks every day. This ancient habit has turned into a big business. Each stick of chewing gum has fewer than ten calories, but it is considered food and must meet the standards of the American Food and Drug Administration.

Today, most gum is made from synthetic materials, with added pine resins and softeners to keep the flavor and improve the texture. However, this was not always the case. The ancient Greeks chewed a resin from the mastic tree, which grows mainly in Greece and Turkey. Greek women especially liked mastic gum to clean their teeth and freshen their breath. American colonists learned from the Native Americans in New England and chewed resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, lumps of spruce for chewing were sold in the eastern United States, making it the first commercial chewing gum in the country.

Modern chewing gum began in the late 1860s with the discovery of chicle, a milky substance from the sapodilla tree found in Central America. Gum made from chicle was smoother, more enjoyable, and more elastic to chew, leading to the growth of a whole industry. However, attempts to grow sapodilla trees commercially have not been successful. As the chewing gum market expanded, synthetic alternatives were created.

Today, the few remaining chicle gatherers, known as chicleros, live a difficult and dangerous life. They travel long distances to collect sapodilla in very humid conditions. The environment is dangerous, with poisonous snakes and many insects. One of the most concerning pests is the chicle fly, which lays its eggs in the ears and nose of the gatherers. Despite these dangers, experienced chicleros can climb trees quickly to collect the sap, which they carry back to a camp where it is boiled and made into bricks.

Life at the camp is also hard, with a boring diet mainly of maize and local alcohol made from sugar cane. Even though this work is tough, chicleros worry about their jobs. Not long ago, the United States imported 7,000 tonnes of chicle each year from Central America, but last year only 200 tonnes were collected in Mexico's Yucatan peninsula.

As chewing gum sales have increased, manufacturers have turned to synthetic materials to lower costs and meet demand. At the same time, gum producers are finding creative ways to market their products. They claim that chewing gum helps you relax, boosts your energy, and reduces stress. During both world wars, soldiers were often given gum. One of the main benefits of gum is that it can help reduce tooth decay. When we eat, plaque acid forms, but our saliva helps neutralize this acid and provides important minerals. Gum manufacturers say that chewing for 20 minutes can increase saliva flow.

Research is ongoing to create new textures and flavors. Glycerine and other vegetable oils are now used to make the gum base. Most new flavors are artificial, but some still require natural ingredients.
