The kids wanted to try the new ride, Fear Factor, but we were relieved they were too small for it! The park is so well designed that even waiting in line for rides isn’t boring. It was very clean, and the staff were great. When I couldn’t sit with both girls on one ride, a staff member kindly went with one of them.

**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**  
We arrived at one o'clock and were disappointed that the park closed at 5 p.m. This park is excellent for younger children because the rides are not too scary. I’m not very brave, but I still had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slowly and then becomes very exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over too quickly! I wouldn’t go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun if you are brave. If the children were a bit older, they might have found it a little boring, but they were the right age and loved it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**  
According to the park’s advertising, there is "No Limit to the Fun," and we definitely felt that way. Europe’s tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, is the main attraction, and Ben thought it was the scariest ride. Jennie thought the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was even worse! There are about a dozen main rides, which the older kids went on several times. Sarah was too small for some rides but enjoyed the Long Slide. We found the staff’s attitudes varied. Some were great with younger children, but the welcome was not always friendly. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World, and we wouldn’t have dared tell the kids we were going home early.

**Running a Business in the Countryside**

Five women share their experiences of starting a business in the countryside.

A. **Christine Hogan** runs a computer-aided design business that makes over £200,000 a year and has four full-time employees. She says, "My customers are friends." Christine moved from London to the countryside when her children were young. She wanted a job she could do from home. With her background in computers, her husband suggested she start a design business. Although it was hard at first and required a lot of money, she managed carefully and communicated with her bank manager about spending. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evenings if needed. Her business is small, and most customers pick up their work directly.

B. **Maggy Sasanow** is a greetings card designer who works from home. She studied art at university and initially wanted to work in a museum. However, after moving to the countryside, she decided to start her own business. She creates 50 different greetings cards that she sells to museums. Maggy works in a large room upstairs but finds it hard to focus because there are always chores to do, like mowing the lawn. She does not advertise; her business grows through word of mouth. Although she misses sharing ideas with others, she believes the benefits of working alone outweigh the downsides.

C. **Delia Turner** runs a curtain-making business that has faced ups and downs. She started her business eight years ago when it was growing quickly, and her income increased from £24,000 to £80,000 in two years. At one point, she had six full-time employees, but she had to let them go due to economic decline, which was difficult because jobs are hard to find in her area. Now, she makes curtains at home with her husband’s help and works with women who also work from home. Delia knows she must sometimes lower her prices and look for new opportunities.

D. **Tessa Strickland** manages her children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago for financial reasons and because she loves the area. Tessa enjoys the flexibility of working when she wants, but 80% of her income comes from international deals, so she often takes calls at unusual hours. She publishes children's books from different cultures and collaborates with authors and artists. Although she felt lonely at first, she has adjusted to her new life.

E. **Meg Rivers** runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop that earns £250,000 a year and employs six people, some part-time. She started her business ten years ago at home, focusing on health by making fruit cakes with high-quality ingredients. After friends and family requested her cakes, she began sending them across the country. Seven years ago, she rented a small building where everything is made, and now she manages the business side instead of baking. Her biggest challenge has been handling the finances, as she did not have a lot of money to start with.

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**

The Watkins family is special because they are all involved in music. The sons are composers and award-winning musicians, while their dad makes musical instruments. 

John and Hetty Watkins, who are schoolteachers in South Wales, wanted to buy a cello for their ten-year-old son, Paul, but found it too expensive. John thought about making one himself. He discovered a local school for instrument making and took evening classes for about three years. After trying to make violins and violas, he successfully made his first cello. Paul, now 28, remembers that the cello turned out great, and he used it until recently.

John has now retired from teaching and works full-time as a craftsman, making about twelve violins each year. One of his violins was even sold to a famous American musician, Jaime Laredo, which he considers a great achievement.

Paul and his younger brother, Huw, started playing music when they were young. Paul began with the piano and later switched to the cello. Although their dad wanted Paul to play the violin, Paul was inspired by a cellist in his dad's music group. Huw, now 22, is also making a name for himself as a pianist and composer. He appreciated the support from his parents and felt motivated by Paul’s success rather than pressured.

Paul has achieved a lot with the cello his dad made. He won the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition and became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra at just 20 years old. Recently, he started using a different cello, a Francesco Rugeri, which is over 300 years old, but he still values the one his dad made.

Paul will soon perform on television with the Rugeri cello in Elgar's Cello Concerto. However, he won’t be able to watch it because he will be playing at the Cheltenham Festival that same night. Huw will also be busy, as his String Quartet will have its London premiere at the Wigmore Hall. John and Hetty will have to be very organized to keep up with all their sons' musical events in the coming weeks.

**Looking After the Countryside: The National Trust**

The National Trust is an organization that aims to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and speaks with Gareth Roberts, a warden who works for the Trust to care for its beautiful areas.

According to Gareth, a National Trust Warden needs common sense and good people skills. This is important because he often interacts with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and construction companies. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people applied for the warden position, but Gareth's local knowledge and farming experience helped him get the job, even though he did not have formal training.

Gareth finds it helpful to still farm with his parents, as it allows him to understand farmers' problems better. He also has the physical strength needed for the job, which includes tasks like building fences, planting trees, and constructing walls. Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. He remembers collecting flowers, butterfly larvae, and birds' nests when he was younger. He now realizes that farming has changed the countryside, but he believes it is not the farmers' fault; they were just following government advice.

When Gareth started his job, farmers and conservationists often disagreed. However, they are now communicating and understanding each other better. Gareth believes they are close to finding a way to work together. His work includes conservation, allowing public access to Trust land, planting trees, and meeting with tenant farmers. He aims to complete tasks efficiently and enjoys seeing projects finished, even though he spends a lot of time on reports and paperwork.

Gareth is passionate about his job and enjoys talking to the public, although he finds some people's attitudes frustrating. He dislikes when visitors come in, make demands, and leave without appreciation. However, he believes that common sense is key to handling these situations.

If you have common sense and enjoy outdoor work, you might consider applying to be a warden like Gareth. Just keep in mind that there may not be a job available on the Lleyn Peninsula for a long time!

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day, which included teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. I asked her if people looked at her strangely while she trained. She replied, "I focus so much on my movements and my feet that I don’t notice anything else. I might see cars slowing down out of the corner of my eye, but that’s it."

Kendra said, "My whole life is about being my best for the Championships." She follows a strict schedule to be as fit as possible. This will be her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest one yet, with 27 countries participating. "We will have home support, which is very special," she said. "It’s important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. Playing at home means there will be more pressure on us. The crowd will have expectations and will support us more. People want us to start the tournament with a good game."

Their first match is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. Kendra mentioned, "We have always beaten them, but they will be exciting to play against because they are very skilled." The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world, but Kendra knows the Championships will be challenging. "You have to push yourself to play every day. There is no rest between games like in a series. In a series, you can still win if you lose the first game. But in the Championships, you only have one chance, so you must be ready."

In the fifteen years she has played at a high level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. Kendra said, "You don’t train hard just to lose. But once the game is over, we become friends again." 

Netball is also using more scientific methods for fitness testing. Kendra explained, "It’s important for us to think and train like world-class players. As captain, I need to have a strong mindset and lead by example. I see my role as supporting and encouraging my teammates."

Kendra added, "From the start of my netball career, I have planned everything carefully. I decided a while ago that this competition would be my last as a player." She will likely coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have tears in her eyes.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

How can parents help a child with exceptional musical talent? It can be difficult to know the best way to support their gift. Some parents might not realize their child's needs until they show frustration through difficult behavior. While most schools can help children who excel in academic subjects, musically talented children often need special attention that regular schools may not provide, especially if music is not a priority there. 

Children who are musically gifted, or those whose talents are encouraged by their parents or teachers, may benefit from attending a specialist music school. In Britain, there are five such schools, which have been established recently. These schools create a supportive environment for gifted children aged seven to eighteen, allowing them to develop their musical skills with the help of professional musicians.

At specialist music schools, students spend about one third to one half of their day on music activities. This includes individual lessons (up to three hours a week for their main instruments), playing in orchestras and chamber groups, voice training, conducting, and music theory. They also practice in well-equipped private rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is spent on a limited academic program that focuses on essential subjects like English, math, basic sciences, and languages. However, students can study more subjects if they wish.

All five British specialist music schools are independent, with smaller class sizes and a high teacher-to-student ratio. Most students live at the school, which means they spend their formative years with peers who share similar goals and interests.

What are the downsides? One major issue is the cost; fees can be high (between £12,000 and £17,000 a year for boarders). However, schools often provide scholarships and financial help for parents of exceptionally talented children. Additionally, not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. Many directors of these schools have concerns about admitting children as young as seven into such a strict environment. They emphasize that their goal is to help students become well-rounded individuals.

It is important to note that separating musically gifted children from their peers at an early age can create stress. Some children may lose their musical talent during their teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to feelings of failure. However, specialist schools closely monitor each student's progress and offer support when needed.

While many former students feel they gained a lot from the high-quality music education, some worry about the limited academic program, which often takes a back seat to music. Many musically talented young people are also very intelligent and can handle academic challenges, so they may feel frustrated if their academic needs are not met.

For these reasons, it might be better to wait until a child is older and can make their own choices before considering a specialist music education. Children who are also academically gifted may thrive in a regular school with a strong music program or by combining a normal school schedule with music training at junior departments of music colleges. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with excellent teachers, as well as opportunities to play in orchestras and chamber music groups. However, this option may not be available for families living far from London or other major cities.

**An Eye for Detail**

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. The large garden around her house provides many of her subjects. It is filled with her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread all over the garden. The two long flower borders along the paved path that goes from east to west are full of colors, shapes, and structures. This beauty is partly due to the previous owners, who loved gardening and left plants that Susan liked. She also kept the gardener, Danny. "In fact, it was really his garden," she says. "We got along very well. At first, he would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it' for some of the things I wanted to add, but when I told him I wanted to paint them, he understood my vision."

Susan prefers to paint detailed studies of individual plants instead of the whole garden. Sometimes, she paints a group of plants, but usually, she picks one flower and takes it to her studio. "I don't set everything up at once," she explains. "I take one flower out and paint it, which might take a few days. Then I bring in another one and build the painting that way. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish."

Her busiest time is spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all come out together, and you're so busy," she says. But she also finds beauty in the way flowers change as they decay. For example, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for a day, and they change shape. They open up and look amazing. At first, you think they are boring, but they keep changing."

Susan has always loved plants. "I studied botany in school and used to collect wildflowers from the countryside," she says. "I wasn't really interested in gardening then; I didn't like garden flowers because they looked fake, like silk or plastic. I was fascinated by how wildflowers could grow in difficult places, like cracks in rocks or on cliffs."

Today, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they seem just as comfortable in her garden as they do in their native lands like China or the Himalayas. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, like a caring aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause serious trouble. 

With two upcoming exhibitions to prepare for and plenty of subjects right outside her door, Susan has found it hard to spend time in the garden lately. She now hires an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected to her work, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, shares her experiences as a chalet girl in Val d'Isère, France. This is her second year in this job, where she cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets. Sarah studied French and History of Art at Oxford Brookes University and graduated last summer. She sees being a chalet girl as a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more permanent career. "It's a good way to meet successful people," she says.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. She has her own breakfast before preparing breakfast for the guests, which includes porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., she cleans up and either makes afternoon tea for the guests or cleans the rooms, which she finds the least enjoyable part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski herself and enjoys being on the slopes until about 4:30 p.m.

After skiing, Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower first but avoids sleeping because it makes her feel tired. Dinner is a three-course meal served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen because she dislikes coming back to a messy space the next morning. Sometimes she chats with the guests, but other times they prefer to be alone. "Good guests can make a week great," she says, but some weeks are not as enjoyable.

Sarah lives in the chalet with her friends, and they often go out around 11 p.m. They usually start at a place called Bananas, then go to G Jay's, and maybe end the night at Dick's T-Bar. However, she does not stay out too late on Saturday nights because Sundays are her busiest days. "It's a tough day," she explains, "when you don’t want to cook breakfast feeling tired."

On Sundays, Sarah starts work earlier, with breakfast for guests served by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, she quickly cleans the chalet, clearing breakfast and changing the beds. If she hasn’t done the shopping on Saturday, she does it now. By around 3 p.m., after finishing the cleaning, she prepares tea for the new guests who arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they seem confused and have many questions, which Sarah finds amusing.

Between tea and dinner, she helps guests who need ski equipment by taking them to the ski shop and getting a ride back to the chalet. Soon, it’s time for dinner again, and she might chat with friends, but sometimes she is too tired and goes to bed early.

**Changing Lives with a Stranger**

Mandie Currie is a zoo-keeper who spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. She found it hard to choose what to wear because she usually wears a uniform at the zoo. Her day started in a photo studio and then she went to press previews before lunch. The zoo is a calm place, but at the magazine, she felt rushed. Some people on the fashion team seemed stressed, but her job at the zoo is not very stressful. During a fashion shoot in the afternoon, she laughed at the thought that she would normally be cleaning cages or handling rats. She is interested in how magazines work, but she loves her job at the zoo and wants to stay there.

Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent a day at London Zoo. She arrived wearing leather boots and dark blue trousers, but the zoo gave her a green polo shirt to wear, which was good because she got very dirty. While petting an elephant, she thought about Mandie probably packing clothes at the magazine. By five o'clock, she was dirty but had a wonderful day. She could see herself working with elephants in Africa after she retires from fashion.

Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, worked with the team from the gardening show Ground Force. She was very excited to meet the team, especially Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter. She enjoyed being outside because her hospital shifts sometimes keep her indoors. Although the work was hard, she had a lot of fun. She thought she was strong, but she felt weak compared to the gardening team. She realized that gardening requires a lot of physical work and planning, so she does not plan to leave her nursing job.

Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener from Ground Force, spent a day working at Hammersmith Hospital. He made beds and handed out medicine. He thought he might feel faint doing some tasks, but he was surprised that it didn’t bother him. He enjoyed the friendship among the nurses and felt it was very different from his usual male work environment. Although his day at the hospital was not easy, it gave him a great sense of satisfaction.

Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. When she put on the uniform, she felt different and noticed that people looked up to her. Before the flight, her supervisor talked about safety, which she already knew from her fitness training. When passengers boarded the flight to Paris, she handed out magazines and felt self-conscious as everyone stared at her. On the way back, there were 80 schoolchildren on board who wouldn’t sit still, and she wished she was back in the gym with one sensible adult.

Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. She was nervous about this swap because she doesn’t exercise. She was surprised by how much attention trainers give to one person, while in her job, she meets 130 passengers four times a day. At lunch, she noticed that some trainers didn’t eat very healthily, but they all drank a lot of water. She wouldn’t change her job for this experience, but it inspired her to join a gym and try to be healthier.

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Memories**

**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit as often as I can. There is a local train from Cannes that goes along the coast and crosses into Italy. It takes you past beautiful sea views. No matter the weather or the time of year, the journey is always magical. Out of the other window, you can see some of the best gardens and homes in France. It feels like you are looking into the lives of the rich and famous. The passengers are always lively, with a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the stunning views.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have had many great train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which travels through the northern Sudan desert. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to Kruger National Park because I was considered too young and troublesome. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still hadn’t traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first real train station I saw, and its large glass dome amazed me.

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I am very grateful to one train in particular: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone said that pink is good for the brain, and I have worn it ever since. The journey was wonderful, traveling through France and then by boat up the Nile. It was the perfect way to relax after all the wedding planning.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on articles about a round-the-world trip and needed to cross a desert in Africa. There were no roads, so we took the Desert Express. The schedule was not reliable; we were just told to be ready on a certain day. The driver often waited for days if he knew people were still coming. When the train arrived, many people rushed to get on, even climbing onto the roof for free. At night, the train passed through some of the most beautiful landscapes I have ever seen. It felt like a dream, like traveling across the moon.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people have childhood memories of trains, but I do not. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It wasn’t until I was a teenager that trains became important in my life. I made a film that featured a railway in Yorkshire. Most of the filming was on an old, unused part of the line that volunteers had taken care of. That’s where my love for steam trains started. When we weren’t filming, we took every chance to ride the train, and when I returned last year, everything was just as I remembered, even the gas lights on the station platform!

**Trying to Get Published?**

If you want to publish your story, expert Margaret Stubbs has some helpful advice. Many readers of this magazine ask, "I have written a story or book. Who should I send it to?" The first thing you need to do is research the market and learn about publishers while also improving your writing skills. Turning your writing into something that can be sold requires a good understanding of the publishing world.

No matter what type of writing you do, you should know the markets you want to reach. One of the best ways to learn about these markets is to read as much as you can. Visit your local library, bookstores, and newsagents. Reading widely will help you understand what kinds of writing publishers are currently accepting. 

As time goes on, you need to keep updating your knowledge because new publications are always coming out. Editors change jobs, and magazines can change their focus. Publishers are always looking for new writers, so you need to give them what they want.

At first, you might not be sure what you want to write. For example, if you think you want to write short love stories, the first step is to find out which magazines publish love stories. This market is quite limited these days, so get recent copies of those magazines. Learn about the types of stories they buy and who their readers are. These readers have specific expectations, and the editor wants to meet those needs.

Writers often ask me, "This story has been rejected three times. Am I wasting my time? Do I have a chance?" As a former teacher, I never want to discourage anyone. However, it is likely that the work is not ready for publication. Many new writers are too eager to send out their work before they are prepared. If you have only written one story or article, it is very unlikely to be published. This rarely happens. When you hear about someone’s success, they usually have been in publishing or journalism for years before achieving it.

When you finally send out your work for the first time, keep writing while you wait for a response. Write ten more stories, or even twenty. Each one will be better than the last, and you will start to see yourself as a writer. This will help you gain confidence and improve your skills. Instead of giving up on your stories, work on improving them. 

I also recommend not sharing your work with others in the early stages. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections before finding success. Do everything you can to advance your writing career. Look for a creative writing course nearby, or join a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence from other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if you can.

**No Title**

On the last day of a difficult year, I was waiting at the Baltimore railway station for the 10:10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people there than I expected. The station, usually bright and clean, felt crowded. Older couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and many college students had left their bags on the floor. 

A grey-haired man was walking around, talking to different people. He looked well-off with his tanned skin, nice sweater, and soft beige coat. He approached a woman sitting alone and asked her if she was going to Philadelphia. She replied that she was going north, but to New York. He thanked her and moved on. 

Next, he asked an old lady if she was going to Philadelphia, but she said she was going to Wilmington. He continued down the row to a couple with matching luggage. I moved closer, pretending to look at the platform, even though I was going to Philadelphia too. I understood why he didn’t ask me; he probably thought I looked unreliable. 

He seemed stressed as he approached a woman reading a book. “Please! Tell me you’re going to Philadelphia!” She looked up and said she was. He then asked her for a favor. I stood a few feet away, pretending to check my wrist, even though I didn’t have a watch. I could tell the woman was becoming cautious. 

The man explained, “My daughter is flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, but when I got home, my wife was upset. My daughter forgot her passport and called from the station in Philadelphia, not knowing what to do.” The woman listened sympathetically, but I thought it was better to stay quiet and see where this was going. 

He continued, “I told her to stay at the station, and I would send someone with her passport.” I thought it was strange he didn’t go himself if it was so urgent. The woman asked, “Why don’t you go yourself?” He replied, “I can’t leave my wife alone for that long. She’s in a wheelchair.” I thought this was a weak excuse. 

I noticed the man was holding a padded envelope, not a regular one, which seemed odd. It looked stapled shut too. I thought to myself, “Be careful, lady.”

**Gary and Me**

John Moore, the owner of a restaurant, talks about his relationship with his son Gary, who is a famous TV chef. John believes that everyone gets a chance in life. His chance was to run a restaurant, and Gary's chance was to cook.

When John found out about the restaurant opportunity, he quickly went to see it. The place was in bad condition, but it was just what he needed. Starting this business reminded him of his childhood. He remembers feeling sad when his mother went to work in a factory and left him alone. Because of this, he wanted to make time for family. His wife took care of the children and managed the accounts while John ran the restaurant. They lived above the restaurant and always made sure to have meals together. This helped their children, Gary and Joe, become very confident. From a young age, they would talk to the regular customers, which gave them a good start in life.

Gary was a lively child. When he was about seven, he jumped into a corner bath like it was a swimming pool and knocked himself out. As he grew older, he had to earn pocket money. He started with small jobs and by the age of ten, he was working in the kitchen every weekend, which meant he had a lot of money at school. He was very disciplined and would wake up even before John. In a family business, everyone helps out, and John was happy to see Gary working.

Although Gary was not very good at school, he excelled in the kitchen. By the age of 15, he was as skilled as the adult chefs and sometimes even managed the kitchen. He could prepare over a hundred meals, and John knew Gary would pursue a career in catering. When Gary needed work experience for school, John sent him to a friend’s restaurant.

Recently, Gary started playing the drums and formed his own band. John wonders what will happen to Gary's cooking if his music career takes off. He advised Gary to focus on one thing at a time, saying, "If you chase two hares, you catch neither." John also told Gary that he needed to achieve his goals by the age of 30, or it might be too late.

At 17, Gary went to catering college. On his first day, while other students were just starting, Gary quickly chopped all his vegetables and sliced the meats. He even helped his classmates. Everyone is amazed at how successful Gary's TV cooking show has become, and John is very proud of him. He always tells Gary that if you want something, you have to work hard for it because nothing is given for free. Gary has recognized the opportunities he has and has taken full advantage of them.

As parents, we talk to our children as they grow up, and even if they only remember a little of what we say, we should be happy. John sees that Gary listens and learns from him, which makes him proud.

**Finding a Flat in Dublin**

Finding a good flat in Dublin that you can afford is very difficult. The best way to find one is through personal connections. If you know someone who knows someone else who is moving out, that can help. But if, like Jo, you just arrived in Dublin, you don’t have those connections. So, Jo had to stay in a hostel and look for a flat. For her, Dublin felt very unfamiliar. She felt nervous when she took the train to start her new job there. She didn’t question why she was going; everyone at school expected her to leave her small town. They all wanted to escape and experience life in a bigger city. Some of her classmates had already moved to nearby towns like Ennis or Limerick, where family members helped them settle in. But Jo was going to Dublin alone.

Jo’s mother thought it would be good for her to stay in the hostel permanently. It was run by nuns, so her mother believed she would be safe. Her father hoped the hostel would be warm because they are often cold. Jo’s sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy for staying in a hostel for a whole week. But Jo didn’t know they were still talking about her while she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen and bathroom." It was very close to her job at the post office and seemed too good to be true. Jo hoped it would be nice, that the people would like her, and that it wouldn’t be too expensive.

There wasn’t a long line for this flat because it was more about finding a "Third Girl Wanted" than just a flat to rent. The mention of "own television" made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked normal. It was a simple red-brick house with a basement, but the flat was upstairs. As Jo climbed the stairs, a cheerful girl with a college scarf came down. "Desperate place," she said to Jo. "They’re both awful. Common as dirt."

Jo asked, "What do you mean?" The girl replied, "She didn’t have to do anything. She just looked around and acted like it was terrible in a posh accent. We wouldn’t want her here, would we, Pauline?" Pauline, who had colorful punk clothes and hair, was also there. Jo was surprised to meet a punk in person since she had only seen them on the street.

"I'm Jo, I work at the post office and I called about the flat," she said. Nessa, the girl with the college scarf, said they were about to have tea. She brought out three mugs: one with "Nessa," one with "Pauline," and one labeled "Other." "We’ll put your name on a mug if you come to stay," she said kindly.

**Behind the Dolphin's Smile**

People love dolphins. We enjoy watching them in seaside areas, movies, and TV shows. However, according to the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, dolphins are in serious trouble. Mark Simmonds reports on the decline of dolphin populations.

Dolphins are special to us. They are very intelligent, sensitive to human feelings, and they inspire us with thoughts of freedom in the ocean. Our affection for dolphins has been supported by TV shows. For example, there was "Flipper," and now we have Darwin from "Seaquest." But these happy images hide the harsh reality of dolphins living in polluted and overfished oceans today.

The population of North Sea harbour porpoises, a type of dolphin, has decreased by up to 89,000. You might think that such beloved animals would be protected by laws and cared for in special marine reserves, but this is not true. The lack of plans to protect them could lead to one of the biggest wildlife disasters of our time.

There are forty different types of dolphins around the world. In northern Europe, the most common are the striped dolphin, the common dolphin, the bottlenose dolphin, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The striped and common dolphins usually live far out in the open sea and are seen only in small groups. We know very little about them. Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises used to be common near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are very social and were often seen along the Channel coast and in rivers like the Thames. Now, they can only be found in a few places, like the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few that remain show signs of stress, such as skin injuries.

The reasons for the decline in dolphin numbers are complicated. Overfishing is reducing fish populations and threatening local fishing industries, which also puts dolphins and porpoises at risk. Porpoises need to find food quickly, and if fish are removed from one area, they may not survive long enough to find food elsewhere. They can also get caught in fishermen's nets, which they cannot see. Many modern fishing methods use large nets that are either left floating or pulled quickly through the water. In recent years, many dead dolphins have washed up on the beaches of France and Cornwall. Marks and cuts on their bodies show that they died after being caught in these nets.

Dolphins can also store harmful substances in their bodies. For example, pesticides can build up in their fat. When female dolphins produce milk, it can be rich in these poisons, which can harm their young. There has been at least one case of a young dolphin dying from its mother’s poisoned milk.

Another serious threat to dolphins comes from human activities. Dolphins live in groups and rely on sound to understand their environment. Noise pollution from ships and oil drilling travels much better in water than in air, which may disturb dolphins in ways we do not fully understand.

**GETTING FIT**

Exercise is very important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you stay balanced, especially when life feels chaotic and fast-paced. You might be tired of reading about fitness, but there are many good reasons to exercise, and very few reasons not to.

Exercise helps improve your muscle tone and can quickly change your body shape. It makes your muscles stronger and helps you maintain good posture, which is how you hold your body when sitting or standing. It also prevents muscle imbalances that can lead to injuries. You can see quick improvements in areas like your thighs, stomach, and upper arms. Additionally, exercise is good for your heart, lungs, and blood circulation.

You may have heard these benefits many times, but here’s something new: exercise can help reduce feelings of depression and tiredness, and it can help you sleep better. It also helps manage stress and can relieve some medical conditions. 

If you still need convincing, just remember that exercise is good for you. There are many types of exercise you can try, such as aerobics, jogging, or using weights. However, be careful not to train too hard or lift too much weight, as this can cause injuries. If you’re unsure about what exercises are right for you, it’s a good idea to talk to your doctor.

Good posture is essential for improving your body shape. If you have poor posture, it can make you look and feel less energetic and can lead to health problems. To improve your posture, imagine that a helium balloon is pulling the top of your head up towards the sky. This can help you lift your chest and breathe better, while also making your body look slimmer.

Stretching is also important. It improves your flexibility and helps you move easily. Stretching can prevent injuries and muscle tears. If you stretch four or five times a week, you will become more flexible and fit. 

A good exercise routine should include a warm-up, stretching, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**

What makes film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman leave their comfortable homes for months? They are looking for the perfect shot. In the jungles and plains of East Africa, it can be very hard to find them. Right now, they are in the Ngorongoro Crater, which has had six months of almost constant rain, causing many unexpected problems. Newman explained that they had to buy an expensive piece of equipment so that if one of their vehicles gets stuck in the mud, Amanda can pull him back to safety. Their teamwork has produced some of the best wildlife films on TV, including a popular film about leopards. While this film was being shown, they were already back in the field, this time following the shy jackal.

Traveling film-makers have been exploring the world to film exotic wildlife since television began. I spoke to Newman during one of his rare meetings with other people at a safari lodge. He said, "We do have occasional arguments, but we usually get over them quickly." Neither of them sees themselves as the leader, and they get along well because they both view the animals in a similar way. 

When they are on the move, they set up their tents each night. But now, they are working from a more fixed camp. They wake up at 5 a.m. and often make tea the night before to keep it warm. Their daily meals consist of pre-packed food that they heat and serve as needed. "It's not unusual for us to be out for up to eight weeks, so cooking can sometimes be stressful," says Newman. 

Their life can be tough, but being in remote areas allows them to get close to the animals. Newman remembers filming a family of lions, where one lioness would often go off alone. When she returned, she would greet all the other lions, and eventually, she also greeted their car as part of her routine.

Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called "The Great Rift." Two years later, they began working together to film Arctic foxes. Since then, they have learned to spend four months in the field to gather enough material for each half-hour film. Before they can start filming, they must submit a script for approval. 

Newman says, "Amanda and I built a good working relationship from the start because we shared the same ideas and vision. We aim to create a film that captures the true spirit of the place and the animals, and that touches people's hearts. I believe that if you can make people feel something, it is much better than just appealing to their minds."

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met Kendra Slawinski, the captain of England's netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day, teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. I was surprised by her training location. I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I focus so much on my movements and my feet that I don’t notice anything else. I might see cars slow down a little, but that’s it."

Kendra said, "My whole life is about being my best for the Championships." She follows a strict schedule to be as fit as possible. This is her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest one yet, with 27 countries participating. "We will have home support, which is very special," she said. "It’s important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. Playing at home means there will be more pressure than usual. The crowd will have expectations and will support us more. People want us to start the tournament with a good game."

Their first match is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. Kendra believes they have always won against them, but she knows they will be a tough team to play. The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world, but Kendra warns that the World Championships will be challenging. "You have to push yourself every day. There is no break between games like in a series. In the Championships, you only have one chance, so you must be ready to take it."

In the fifteen years she has played at a high level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive now. Kendra said, "You don’t train hard to lose." But once the game is over, everyone is friendly. 

Netball is also using more scientific methods for fitness testing. Kendra believes it is important for everyone to think and train like top players. As captain, she wants to have a strong mindset and lead by example. "I see my role as supporting and encouraging the team," she said.

Kendra has planned her netball career carefully. She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She will likely coach young players in the future, but right now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have tears in her eyes, knowing her loyal supporters are with her every step of the way.

**In Hot Water**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she gets into a small steel vehicle used for underwater exploration and dives three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes.

Inside the vehicle, Rachel says, "The space is so small that I can touch the two pilots. We cannot stand up or move, and we must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface."

"If there is a problem and we need to get to the top quickly, we can hit a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that rises quickly to the surface. No one has tested it yet, but I don’t think it would be a pleasant journey."

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. It was on a ship, and she got in with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would react in such a small space.

Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew. "We went to a site five days west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. There is a large area of underwater volcanoes that release black smoke. This is where the Atlantic Ocean is very active. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study a project that would create a hole 150 meters through a volcano."

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it so I can continue my research on the 'black smokers.' This is another name for underwater volcanoes, where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It flows out at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees."

Rachel recalls a frightening moment when she first dived with an American team. They were towing equipment when suddenly there was an explosion. "There was a huge bang, and I thought, 'I'm going to die.' We looked at each other in silence, waiting. When nothing happened, we were incredibly relieved to be alive!"

"Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is such an adventure. Every time I look out of the porthole and see those chimneys, I feel amazed. I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them before. I studied the black smokers for three years for my Ph.D., and seeing them for real was an incredible feeling."

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. Studies show that people form opinions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, our body language, and how we speak, including our speed, volume, and tone of voice, as well as the words we use.

Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She worked hard to earn her degree and felt confident when she graduated. She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. On the day of the interview, she noticed a small hole in her jacket. She thought about changing but decided it would make her late, and she believed being on time was very important. Unfortunately, Mary did not get the job. A friend who worked at the school told her that the Head Teacher said, "If someone doesn't take the time to present her best image at an interview, what kind of teacher will she be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says that candidates who care about their appearance are more likely to care about their jobs. People often say that what matters is inside, but during an interview, it is important to present yourself well.

Many people overlook the importance of a professional image. For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a large accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the position but did not get an interview. She thought it was a mistake and asked the Director of Personnel what happened. He told her that she did not fit the image of an office manager and suggested she improve her wardrobe before applying again. Janet was shocked because she believed her work performance should matter more than her appearance.

Body language and gestures also affect an interviewer's first impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that only 7% of our message about feelings comes from the words we use, 38% from our voice, and 55% from our facial expressions. If our facial expressions and words send different messages, the listener will pay more attention to the non-verbal message. Therefore, it is important that your words match your body language. Mixed messages can confuse the interviewer.

It is also important not to seem too desperate for the job or overly eager to please. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion and had a great interview. She was offered the job immediately. However, she reacted with too much excitement. Once her boss saw how happy she was, he offered her a lower salary than she expected. She believes she could have negotiated a better salary if she had controlled her excitement.

Finally, what you say and how you say it can affect your interview success. David Artesio, a manager at an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. For example, reading the annual report can help you understand the company better. Mentioning an area that interests you during the interview can show your interest in the company.

Business consultant Marian Woodall advises having a few questions ready and avoiding long, confusing sentences. She says, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and highlight key points."

**A NEW LIFE**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. He says, "After 14 years in the business, I found that working in the City was no longer exciting. It became very tiring, and no one was enjoying their work. I didn’t plan to leave for another five or ten years, but then I lost my job unexpectedly. I didn’t get a great pay-off, but it was enough to start my farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a well-known hotel restaurant. By supplying them with meat, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat online. I’m happy to be out of the office, but surprisingly, my work hours are still long, about 80 to 90 hours a week, and I’m still selling a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Able was a manager in advertising, but now he makes a living as an artist. He explains, "I started painting as a hobby, but I found it much more exciting than my job. It made sense to take redundancy and become an artist. A career counselor helped me a lot. I think I was the first person to tell him, 'I don’t want to go back to my old job.' He was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to find work quickly for money. My wife and I married young, and our children are now independent, so we took a risk and moved to northern England, where we didn’t know anyone. We left our friends behind, but we’ve been lucky; many of them still visit us."

**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business in her London flat. She says, "Being a lawyer was fun and paid well, but the hours were terrible. I didn’t want to become a senior partner and work even longer hours, so I decided to leave. Many people thought I would get bored, but that hasn’t happened. The key is to set deadlines. In the fashion business, there are always collections and new designs to work on, so I have to keep a strict schedule. I feel happier now and less stressed. However, I miss the social interaction with colleagues. What I love about this job is that I am fully responsible for my work. If I do a bad job, I am the one to blame. When you work for a company, you care, but when your name is on the product, you care even more."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He shares, "I was in financial markets from the age of 22, making deals. I enjoyed the excitement, but I never found the work fulfilling. I almost lost my job in 1989, but I decided to resign and travel for a year. During that time, I thought about what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited some of the best gyms and talked to their owners about how they started. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took various massage courses. Then, I got a part-time job at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my life, which is the best part."

**Dedicated to Their Sports**

Four young athletes share their experiences.

**A. Darius (Runner)**  
I have always loved sports. I tried many, but I was best at football and athletics. When I was 14, I tried out for a professional football team, but I chose to focus on athletics instead. My biggest achievement was competing for my country in the youth team and winning a medal. Unfortunately, it didn’t get much media attention, which was disappointing. I hoped to get some sponsorship because training can be expensive. I train at home all winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It’s fun there with great facilities and nightlife, but I have to be disciplined. If friends invite me out the night before training, I have to say no. I wish I could go, but dedication is important in this sport. My main goal is to compete in the next Olympics – that would be amazing.

**B. Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so I often see the same people at competitions. Professional surfers take it seriously, and the best waves are usually at dawn, so I have to skip late-night parties. I don’t mind too much, but I do enjoy sleeping in, which I often have to give up. However, it’s worth it because my dedication helped me win the National Championships last year. After a win, I always celebrate with a big night out, and if I win money, I treat myself to a nice trip. Winning the championship also led to me being chosen to present a surfing series on TV, so I guess I’m a bit of a celebrity now.

**C. Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
When I’m on a boat with my teammates, we have a lot of fun. We are traditional and celebrate our wins in style. Some people say we act a bit childish, but we don’t seek media attention. Sometimes, reporters seem more interested in our celebrations than our race results. I spend eight months a year away, so it’s nice to come back and hang out with friends from different backgrounds. You can’t focus on the sport all the time; it’s not healthy. I’m known in sailing, but I rarely get recognized in public, which I prefer. I receive nice letters from fans asking for signed pictures, and I reply to each one, even if it takes time.

**D. Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It feels great to walk onto the court and feel the crowd’s support. At my last tournament, things got a bit wild with fans crowding around. I enjoy being recognized by fans when I’m out shopping, but it has its downsides. My last girlfriend didn’t like it when I got too much attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that’s part of why we broke up. It was tough, but sacrifices are necessary in sports; you have to be serious and professional. I’m focused on my game now and will catch up on other things in life after I retire, which happens early in this sport.

**Young Shoppers**

Shopping in supermarkets with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother explains, "They want everything they see. If it’s not the latest sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic. Usually, they want all three. I can’t afford all this, and if I give in to their requests, I feel guilty about buying unhealthy food. But I also feel bad for saying no all the time, and I get stressed before we even leave the house. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but then I worry that they are missing out on learning how to make their own choices. I just can’t win."

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they go shopping. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on television. This amount is likely to grow, and supermarkets are a key place where this advertising works well. Children often do not understand why their parents say they cannot buy certain things, and arguments about how bad sugar is for their teeth are not convincing when compared to the attractive ads they see.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always correct. It is important for parents and children to talk about food. If children only hear about products from TV ads, they get a very one-sided view. Parents feel frustrated because they are competing with the advertising industry and often have to disappoint their children."

The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV advertising, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy products. However, Dibb points out, "The main goal of advertising is to persuade people to buy something. So even if they can’t say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is still the effect."

Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she tries to be patient when discussing food with her children, but she still feels unhappy about how she handles their requests. "My son pays attention to ads but is critical of them. We talk a lot about different products and look at labels together. I’ve talked about it so much that he thinks all ads are bad. Now, we have very little conflict in the supermarket because the children don’t ask for things I don’t want to buy."

Parents also admit they are sometimes inconsistent in how they respond to their children’s requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We refuse to buy sweets for him because they are bad for him, but we are loading our trolley with cream and chocolate for ourselves. It’s nice to buy good things, and it’s normal for children to want to share that. But I still get annoyed by their requests. It also depends on how I feel. If I’m in a good mood, I’m more likely to say yes. It’s hard to be consistent."

Supermarkets could help reduce the conflict between parents and children by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. Even if parents spend less when their children are not with them, the idea of shopping without their children’s demands might attract enough extra customers to make up for it.

**Five-Star Luxury with Modern Technology**

The new five-star Merrion Hotel in Dublin has been created after a lot of research into what customers want and nearly two years of work to convert four large 18th-century houses. This approach has allowed the hotel to use the latest technology for the benefit of both staff and guests.

General Manager Peter MacCann expects his staff to know guests by name. However, he uses the hotel’s computer system to keep track of guests' preferences. This system helps the hotel provide special service to returning clients, which is important for a five-star hotel. Although the system cost £250,000 to install, MacCann believes it will save money in the long run. He appreciates its efficiency and the services it offers. For example, if a guest requests certain music CDs during their first stay, those same CDs will be ready for them on their next visit, thanks to the guest-history feature.

Many hotel guests often complain about room temperature. The Merrion Hotel has a high-tech system that allows guests to adjust the temperature themselves within three degrees of the normal 18°C. Additionally, the front desk can change the temperature in each room between 14°C and 25°C.

Business travelers will find the technology in their rooms especially useful. MacCann estimates that about 65% of the hotel’s business will come from this group. To meet their needs, the hotel has brought traditional business center services into the rooms. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and video-conferencing facilities.

Technology changes quickly, so the hotel has prepared for future improvements by laying extra cables. They rent televisions instead of buying them, allowing for easy upgrades to newer models. DVD recorders can also be updated when needed. Despite all this modern equipment, MacCann emphasizes that they want guests to feel comfortable, not overwhelmed by technology. The 145 bedrooms are spacious, well-furnished, and welcoming.

The hotel also features a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden. As with all luxury hotels, the food must be excellent. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who already had two Michelin stars for his Dublin restaurant, has moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This move has allowed him to design a new kitchen and improve the dining experience. The hotel benefits from having a popular restaurant without financial risks.

With the help of technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is likely to be very successful.

**Where I Get My Energy**

Emma Marsden asked six women who live life fully how they find their energy.

A. **Jeanette Kupfermann, Journalist and Author:** "I get my energy from excitement and challenges. Learning something new gives me a lot of energy. I also feel energized by rhythm; right now, I'm learning flamenco dancing. Dance is expressive and uplifting. If I'm bored, I feel drained. Being effective, even in small ways, gives me energy."

B. **Linda Kelsey, Magazine Editor:** "I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it all. Work is not a burden for me. When you enjoy what you do, it doesn't make you feel low, even if you're tired. I need enough sleep to feel good. When I only get six hours, I feel a bit off. Exercise helps me feel energized, but I sometimes struggle to find the energy to do it. I attend a yoga class once a week and try to work out at home. After exercising, I feel much better. I often feel low in the afternoon, so I think it's good to have a snack then."

C. **Annie Nightingale, Disc Jockey:** "I don't eat healthily for energy; I think my natural enthusiasm and positivity help. I dislike negative people. I believe we should enjoy life and set goals. I love my job, and the last two years have been exciting. I work with many lively young people, which energizes me. I enjoy taking photos, even if I'm not great at it, and I like writing lyrics for fun. It helps me relax while traveling."

D. **Floella Benjamin, Author and Children's TV Presenter:** "My energy comes from doing things I enjoy. I believe in my work and being positive about life. I love working with kids because they are full of energy and resilience. Energy is like a natural chemical that comes from connecting with others. Just smile at someone and see how good it feels when they smile back. I try to eat healthily and don’t smoke or drink, but I don’t have a strict exercise plan. I get my energy from playing with kids."

E. **Deborah Moggach, Author and Playwright:** "What I love most is creating a garden from a wasteland. I once turned a concrete area into a beautiful garden. It was more energizing than any workout. Knowing that someone wants to read my writing also gives me energy. I enjoy sneaking into nature, and if I get caught, I play innocent. I like it because it feels playful."

F. **Katherine Monblot, Therapist:** "I believe you should have an interest in what you do. I like taking risks and get bored easily, which keeps me motivated. Doing things you don’t want to do can drain your energy. I used to be part of many committees, but I didn’t like the demands on my time. You have limited energy, so focus it on what matters most to you."

**ICE SKATING**

Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones, which were used until iron skates appeared in Scandinavia around 200 AD. For the wealthy people in Scandinavia, skating was an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was seen as elegant, but everything changed at the 1924 Winter Olympics when 11-year-old Sonja Henie brought a more athletic style, making skating very popular.

Today, ice skating combines art and athleticism, making it both beautiful and physically challenging. For beginners, balance and control are very important, and you can only go faster as you get better. Your body position is key to maintaining balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and your knees relaxed, leaning a bit forward. Relaxation is crucial in skating, more than in many other sports.

To start skating, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. Push forward with your back foot while making a small movement with the other foot. It sounds easy, right? If you practice this for a while, you can gradually make bigger movements as you gain experience.

Learning how to fall is one of the first skills a skater should master. Even professional skaters fall sometimes. To fall safely, try to stay relaxed, which helps reduce the impact when you hit the ice. To get up, use your hands to kneel first, then stand up.

Once you feel confident on the ice, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance skating, speed skating, and pair skating. The best way to start is by learning figure skating and then basic freestyle. Most ice rinks offer guidance, so you can quickly learn the basic moves, and soon you will be able to do turns, jumps, and spins in freestyle.

If you watch skilled skaters, you will notice how relaxed and smooth their movements are. To achieve this, it’s important to follow a regular exercise program. Skating with a stiff body can be dangerous, so warm-up exercises should focus on your legs, back, shoulders, and especially your ankles and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to prevent stiffness.

Skating helps improve balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also boosts heart and lung health and strengthens your body. When combined with swimming or jogging, it creates a great fitness program for overall health.

**Trills and Bills**

Seeing a talented child win a medal can bring tears of joy. Julia Gregson spoke to three young stars and their mothers about the joys and challenges in their lives.

A. **Annika Reeder**, 15, won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "Right now, the training is very hard. I don’t have time to watch TV, go out with friends, or do much besides gymnastics and school. I take it one day at a time. When I feel really tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I keep going. You can’t take too many days off because it makes your body stiff."

B. **Annika's mother** says, "From a young age, Annika showed great talent. I’ve seen some parents push their kids, but that doesn’t work. To perform at Annika’s level takes a lot of time and energy, so you have to want it yourself. People often say we, as parents, have sacrificed a lot, but they don’t see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it has done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was a shy girl who hid behind me, but now she has met people from all over the world and gained confidence."

C. **Sarah Stokes** started show-jumping at age 10 and has won the British National Championship. "It’s great that my parents love show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere in the horse box. The shows can last from one to five days. I never get tired of it; I love the excitement and fun. Even if my parents weren’t involved, I would still do it because I am determined. I’m happy when they are proud of my wins, but I do it for myself. This year, I want to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team, and my big dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympics."

D. **Sarah's mother** says, "From the moment Sarah sat on a horse at age 1, we knew she had a passion. When she was 5, she would wake up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for big shows, we travel all over England. To save money, we sleep in the living area of our horse box. Sarah is very organized and feels completely happy on a horse. Watching your child succeed at something they love is an amazing feeling."

E. **Jane McShane**, 10, is the Under-14 Chess Champion in Britain. "Tournaments are really friendly. I know everyone, and it’s fun. When I play, I don’t focus as much as I should; I just look around and don’t think too much. I’m not worried about becoming arrogant, and I don’t talk about my success at school because I don’t like to feel embarrassed."

F. **Jane's mother** shares, "Jane played her first game at age 5. My father suggested we see if she liked it. He had tried to teach me when I was young, but I found it boring. Jane loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she had memorized all the moves, and by age 6, she was beating adults. I’m proud when she wins, but if she wanted to stop playing tomorrow, I wouldn’t stop her. I also don’t want to hold her back because she is so talented. If she has this gift, I want her to reach her full potential."

Text: 

It's true - we are all getting taller. Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher jokingly asked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is the tallest man in Britain. 

Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by about one centimeter. More tall people are being born, but this does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are returning to how our ancestors looked. According to Professor Chris Stringer, a palaeontologist, we are becoming like Cro-Magnons, the people who lived 40,000 years ago.

For most of human history, our ancestors had a varied diet. Women gathered fruits and herbs, while men hunted animals. One study showed they ate from 85 different wild plants. However, about 9,000 years ago, agriculture started, which changed everything. Farmers took over many natural areas, and now just three plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide more than half of the calories we eat today. This limited diet has harmed our health. 

In a study in Ohio, scientists found that when healthy hunter-gatherers started farming corn, they became sick and underweight. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Although corn was thought to be a good food, it actually caused health problems. Farming spread because one piece of land could feed many more people than hunting could. 

Today, many people who rely on farming are still poorly nourished. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets starting to reflect the variety of our ancestors' diets again. As a result, the average height of men is now 179 cm in the US, 180 cm in Holland, and 177 cm in Japan. This is a positive change, but it also brings challenges. 

Even though people are getting taller, the standard bed length has stayed at 190 cm since 1860. Legroom in planes and trains seems to be getting smaller, and clothing companies have to change their sizes often. The question is: how tall can we get? 

Some scientists believe we might reach a height of 193 cm this century. However, there is a twist. While individuals may be growing taller due to better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were rounder and taller to keep warm. Now that the climate is warmer, we seem to be getting thinner and shorter, even with good food. As the planet continues to warm, we might shrink even more. So, the growth of humans could be affected by global warming.

**Studio Audiences**

What is it like to be in the audience when a television show is being made? Cosmo Landesman explored this topic. Studio audiences are a common part of television, but many people find them mysterious. When we watch game shows, we often wonder who these audience members are.

Some people think that studio audiences are not very important. I have heard that even those who work in television look down on them, comparing them to cattle. I used to think that studio audiences were made up of silly people wanting a moment of fame. However, there is no typical studio audience. They come from different backgrounds, jobs, and income levels. Television shows try to attract various types of people for different programs.

Many of us who watch television at home wonder why anyone would want to be in a studio audience. Why would someone apply for tickets, travel far, and sit through hours of waiting just to see a show live? One reason is that people hope to be seen on television. I didn’t believe this until I spoke to Angela, who said she came for a chance to appear on TV. Another reason is curiosity about what happens behind the scenes. But the most common reason I heard was, "A friend gave me a ticket."

Most of us have never been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it is like. You sit close to strangers while someone holds up signs that say APPLAUD or LAUGH, and you respond accordingly. This might be true for some shows, but not all. As one studio manager said, "We believe a good show doesn’t need these signs."

Is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching at home? For Claire, being in a studio is "more exciting," while Charlotte enjoyed feeling part of the live show. She said, "Last year I saw my favorite comedian. When you watch him at home, you miss a lot." I found that I missed seeing the live actors because I could only see the back of someone’s head. The opening scenes were filmed far from my seat, so I ended up watching the show on a monitor.

Going to a studio might not be the best way to watch television, but that’s not what matters. For most audience members, it was simply fun and a free night of entertainment.

**Favorite Places**

**Bruce**  
I don’t like wild landscapes that are untouched by people. I find the human element important. When I travel, I prefer charming villages with old temples rather than empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England, and on Saturdays, I would ride my bike to the village of Lastingham in its beautiful valley. Cycling was a way to escape from school. I enjoyed exploring the bare hilltops, sheltered valleys, and old villages. Coming from Scotland, I found the landscape both familiar and different, and I still visit there today. I used to write about my adventures in my private diary, which was my first attempt at travel writing, a field in which I later became well-known.

**Sophia**  
There is a small railway that runs from Hythe to Dungeness, operated by volunteers. I always choose first class because it doesn’t cost much more than the regular ticket. The scenery isn’t amazing. The train travels across Romney Marsh with its sheep and next to a canal. However, there is one part of the journey I always look forward to - when the train goes through back gardens. For a few moments, we passengers get a glimpse into people’s lives as they make tea, wash dishes, or set up deck chairs. I see myself in their eyes, a woman in a tiny train carriage looking into other homes. I like the ordinary landscape of fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. It makes me look more closely and search for something that opens my eyes.

**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a beautiful and remote coast. The beaches are hard to reach and filled with rocks, so there are not many people here. A few brave surfers come, but most visitors prefer to enjoy the beauty of the sea. This coast, facing the Atlantic, is known for shipwrecks. There are walking paths along the coast that you can combine with trips into lovely damp valleys filled with oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in simple self-catering accommodation with a family who owns property in the village of Southole.

**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a wide-open moorland that is perfect for hiking. There are not many people living there, and not many visitors either. It’s a quiet and remote area, and I love the feeling of space. I found this place by chance when I was a student, and since then, I visit every year, either alone, with my boyfriend, or now with my son. It has changed very little since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits even more special. It makes me sad that he is growing up in a city.

**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain. It was about finding peace and reconnecting with my English roots. I grew up in what is now Sri Lanka, but when I was twelve, I went to school in Devon, in the west of England. I used to ride my bike around the moors and village streets. There was a story about a place we would never cycle past: if you went down the driveway, you would never return. That place was Glenthorne. It is my dream place, a magical, secluded, and romantic house. You can only hear the sea, wind, and birds.

**HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**
