We are a family that loves animals. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work to tell me she had found a beautiful pine snake. She asked, "Can we keep him?" I replied, "Yes, but only for one night." We had a special tank ready for animals like this, so we could admire it and look it up in our natural history book.

I got home late and quickly started boiling some water when I heard my sons screaming, "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I rushed to their bedroom. The problem was with Domino, our cat, and Bianca, the white mouse I had received as a Mother's Day gift. Domino was running around with the mouse in his mouth, trying to escape while avoiding the kids who were waving their arms.

In the chaos, I tripped and fell. As I thought about how to stop Domino, I noticed the snake. It had escaped and was slithering off the table and onto the floor. I crouched down as the snake moved closer, while the kids and the cat were jumping around in a loud, chaotic scene. The dog was barking, and the pot in the kitchen boiled over. I quickly turned off the gas and returned to the chaos with renewed energy. 

I managed to grab Domino by the tail and pulled the small, wet mouse from his mouth. Surprisingly, the mouse survived this encounter, even though Domino caught it three more times in its life before it eventually died of old age.

Feeling encouraged, I looked at the snake to find a way to catch it, but it seemed impossible. I sat on the floor, trying to calm the snake down. Slowly, it relaxed and rested its head on its body, but it still looked suspicious. I carefully placed my hands under the snake and stood up, then walked to the end of the garden. I wanted to give the snake a chance to live freely, so I pointed it towards a nearby tree.

When I finally let go of the snake's head, I expected it to attack me, but instead, it slid over my shoulders like a colorful shawl, making itself comfortable. We stood there in the fading light, with my four children, me, and the snake. My oldest son, DJ, broke the silence and said, "You know what, Mum? You're nice and warm, and the shed isn't."

I asked the kids to help encourage the snake to move on. Slowly, it did, climbing up the wall and disappearing over the roof. As the last bit of its tail vanished, my three-year-old son Clay sighed and said what we were all thinking: "Boy, that was one big snake!"

**Drop Me a Line!**

In our fast world of phones, fax machines, and computers, the old art of letter writing is at risk of disappearing. However, I believe that receiving a letter is special and cannot be replaced by any other way of communicating. There is excitement when a letter arrives, joy in seeing who it is from, and pleasure in reading its contents.

Letter writing has been a part of my life for as long as I can remember. It probably started with the little notes I wrote to my mother. She always made sure I wrote my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday gifts. It didn’t matter if they were short or messy, as long as they were letters.

When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, I wrote to my parents every week, and they wrote back. Sometimes my father would write long, funny letters, which I loved. Most of the letters from home shared everyday news about my parents and their friends. We also made phone calls, but I remember the letters the most.

I also received letters from my boyfriends. Many of them had to work or study far away, so we kept in touch through letters. Instead of hurting our relationships, writing letters seemed to make them stronger. I found it easier to express my feelings in writing than in conversation.

I enjoy the letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Short notes are nice, but it’s even better to get a whole year’s worth of news! I especially love receiving letters in airmail envelopes with beautiful stamps. I get letters from friends in different countries, like Mangala in Sri Lanka, a penfriend in Australia, and another in Vancouver. There’s also a lady from France who writes to me. We started talking in a restaurant after a holiday, and I asked for her address. If she hadn’t replied, we would have missed out on a great friendship. Now, we write to each other regularly, which helps me improve my French since she doesn’t speak English. We have visited each other’s homes twice.

My biggest success in letter writing happened this summer when my family and I visited my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. Everyone was surprised that our friendship lasted so long, and the local newspaper even wrote about it on the front page.

I am happy that my children are continuing this tradition. Like my mother, I make sure they write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just as I did to my mother. She and my son also have penfriends in Texas, organized by my penfriend. I strongly encourage everyone not to let letter writing become a lost art.

**Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Rock Art**

Many ancient pictures carved into the rocks at one of France's most important tourist sites are being slowly destroyed. Scientists are worried that the 36,000 drawings on rocks in Mont Bego in the French Alps are being damaged so quickly that they may not survive for future generations. The mountain is believed to have been a place for prayer and worship, and it has drawings that are 4,000 years old. These include images of cows, fields, and various gods and goddesses. However, as more people visit the site, the pictures are being ruined by careless graffiti.

Jean Clottes, the chairman of the International Committee on Rock Art, says, "People think that because the pictures have been there for so long, they will always be there. But if the damage continues at this rate, there will be nothing left in 50 years." He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings, which wears away the rock and damages the artwork. Some visitors even take pieces of the rock as souvenirs. "When people can't take a good photograph, they rub the drawings to make them clearer," he explains. "The drawings are already polished by the weather, and if the sun is shining and they can't see them well, they rub and scrape them to make them look fresher."

Other researchers have noticed that some people come with long sticks to scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks. Experts disagree on the best way to protect the drawings. Henry de Lumley, director of the Museum of Natural History in Paris, believes the only way to save the site is to make the whole mountain a "no-go" area, allowing the public to visit only on guided tours. He warns that if this is not done, the site will be completely destroyed, and important research will be lost.

Clottes disagrees with de Lumley's strict plan. He says, "While it is the most effective, it will also cause protests from local people." The site was declared a historic monument years ago by the Ministry of Culture, and we must do everything we can to protect it. David Lavergne, a regional architect, also wants to keep the site open. He believes that while it is difficult to prevent damage, it is important for people to see it. However, he mentions that there is not enough money to hire enough guards to protect the area, and they may need to consider charging a fee for visitors.

In Nice, Annie Echassoux, who has also researched the site, is worried that as the mountain becomes easier to reach—since tourists can now avoid a long walk by hiring vehicles—the damage will increase quickly. She believes the best solution is to close off parts of the area and provide guides. "We can't say the plan can't go ahead because there is no money," she says. "That is not good enough. Money must be provided because the Ministry of Culture has classified this area as a historic site. If we don't take action, we will be responsible for losing these drawings for future generations."

Usually, they want all three. I can’t afford all this, and if I give in to their requests, I feel guilty for buying unhealthy food. But I also feel bad for always saying no, and I get anxious before we even leave the house. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but then I worry that I’m not letting them learn how to make their own choices. It’s a tough situation."

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they go shopping. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on television. However, Dibb points out, "The goal of advertising is to persuade people to buy products. So even if they can’t say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is still the effect."

Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to accept and which to refuse. **Going Up the Wall**

In the past, climbers went to the mountains to climb. Now, people can enjoy climbing in many places, both indoors and outdoors. The audience watches closely as the French climber Francois Lombard hangs upside down by just two fingers on a climbing wall. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at the National Indoor Arena in Birmingham. This arena is better known for the TV show Gladiators, but both events have one thing in common: The Wall. The ability to hold these events is thanks to new and quickly advancing technology.

Before the mid-1960s, climbers practiced on natural cliffs where there were good climbing spots. In winter, they had to deal with cold weather, go for walks, or climb on snow and ice in Scotland. As climbing became more popular, it was important for top climbers to stay fit. Since they could not use cliffs for much of the year, they started to train on brick edges or stone buildings. This helped them keep their fingers strong and avoid getting bored.

Soon, many sports centers began to build climbing walls specifically for training. These walls used bricks with special edges for climbers to hold on to. One of the first climbing walls was built by Don Robinson, a physical education teacher, in a corridor at Leeds University in the mid-1960s. He created a wall with natural rock set in concrete.

Throughout the 1970s, many climbing walls like this were built in sports halls, but they had some problems. These walls were only vertical, while real cliffs have features like overhangs and slanted rocks. Once a wall was built, it could not be changed, and climbers would eventually get bored with the same routes.

In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny invented a new material that could be shaped like the rocks found on cliffs. These shapes could be attached to any wall and removed when climbers wanted a change. French manufacturers also started to create climbing panels on steel frames. Unlike heavy concrete, steel frames could be built anywhere as free-standing structures. This system allowed climbers to have many different holds to choose from, giving them endless options for climbing.

**So You Want to Be an Actor**

If you tell someone you want to be an actor, they will probably mention that it is a "risky" career. Acting is indeed risky because there are many more actors than there are acting jobs. When you decide to become an actor, some people you thought were your friends might think you are making a bad choice, while others may support you. Everyone will give you different advice, but this is a personal decision, and you are the one responsible for your choices and dreams.

There are no easy paths to becoming an actor. There are no exams to pass, and even after training, there is no guarantee you will succeed in the profession. Success often depends on a mix of luck and talent. However, there is always a need for new actors, and acting can bring excitement, glamour, and sometimes good rewards.

Many people ask what talent is. I think talent is a combination of natural skill and imagination, with imagination being the hardest to measure. It also involves courage and belief in what you are doing. 

The desire to act can be hard to explain. In theater, the important moment is the connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is what motivates actors to perform. When you ask successful actors how they achieved their success, they often don’t have a clear answer. They know some things about their skills and techniques, but they also understand that their success can change quickly. 

Disappointment is a big challenge for actors. One month you might be out of work, doing other jobs, and the next month you could be asked to audition for a role. Even if you really want the job, you might not get it. Because of this, actors often avoid discussing their chances of getting a role. They find ways to cope with the stress of competition and the fear of rejection, which is something no one enjoys. 

From the moment you start auditioning, you are saying you are available and hopeful that you have the talent for the job. Ultimately, it is up to you; if you don’t care enough about your acting career, others may not care about you either.

**Food for Everyone**

We are excited to share our special selection of the best cookbooks available. 

A. When people think of a famous TV cook and writer, they often think of Delia Smith. Her recipes come from many different countries and show her love for exciting food. She understands what the average cook can do in a normal kitchen. The book that made her famous is "Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course." This book is now a key reference for modern cooks. It offers simple but expert advice on both basic and advanced cooking, along with hundreds of interesting recipes. Recently updated, it answers the question: "If I could only have one cookbook, which one would it be?"

B. Raymond Blanc went from being an amateur chef to owning the most famous French restaurant in Britain in just 15 years. To go along with his first TV series, "Blanc Mange," he has released a book with the same name. Raymond wants to help everyone become better cooks by showing how and why certain ingredients work together. He believes that good cooking is easy when you understand what happens in the pan. The book includes over 80 amazing recipes that illustrate his points. It is a practical guide that explains why some dishes can fail and introduces basic food science. Monsieur Blanc enjoys cooking for others, and this book shows that he is very skilled at it.

C. Le Cordon Bleu is a name that represents the best in classical French cooking. For the past 100 years, expert chefs at this famous cooking school have trained students of all levels to achieve excellence. To celebrate its 100th anniversary, they have published the "Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook," which features 100 of the school's most respected recipes. While these recipes are traditional, they are also fresh and modern. The book starts with basic kitchen techniques and includes sections on Appetisers, Main Dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe is illustrated with step-by-step pictures and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Expert chefs from Cordon Bleu schools worldwide have chosen their famous recipes and shared their secrets.

D. Fast food? No way! Many people think that good food requires a lot of time in the kitchen. However, Nigel Slater, the food editor of The Observer, disagrees. His new book, "The 30-Minute Cook," shows that fast food can be delicious. Nigel believes that it is possible to make tasty meals in the same time it takes to order a pizza. He has already written two successful books on this topic. In this new book, you will find over 200 recipes from around the world, each ready in just 30 minutes. Nigel writes in a fun and enjoyable way, proving that fast food can also be great food. If you doubt that fast food can be delicious, try his recipes—they are simply wonderful!

Text: 

It's true - we are all getting taller. Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher jokingly asked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is the tallest man in Britain. 

Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by about one centimeter. More tall people are being born, but this does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are returning to how our ancestors looked. According to Professor Chris Stringer, a palaeontologist, we are becoming like Cro-Magnons, the people who lived 40,000 years ago.

For most of human history, our ancestors had a varied diet. Women gathered fruits and herbs, while men hunted animals. One study found they ate from 85 different wild plants. However, about 9,000 years ago, agriculture started, which changed everything. Farmers took over many natural areas, and now just three plants—wheat, rice, and maize—provide more than half of the calories we eat. This limited diet has harmed our health. 

In a study in Ohio, scientists found that when healthy hunter-gatherers began farming corn, they became sick and underweight. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Although corn was thought to be a good food, it actually caused health problems. Farming spread because one piece of land could feed many more people than hunting could. 

Today, many people who rely on farming are still poorly nourished. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets starting to reflect the variety of our ancestors' diets again. As a result, the average height of men is now 179 cm in the US, 180 cm in Holland, and 177 cm in Japan. This is a positive change, but it also brings challenges. 

Even though people are getting taller, standard bed lengths have not changed since 1860, remaining at 190 cm. Legroom in planes and trains seems to be getting smaller, and clothing companies have to adjust their sizes. The question is: how tall can we get? 

According to Robert Fogel from the University, we might reach a height of 193 cm this century. However, scientists warn that while individuals may be growing taller due to better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, humans were slightly rounder and taller to keep warm. Now that the climate is warmer, we seem to be getting thinner and shorter, even with good food. As the planet continues to warm, we might shrink even more. In other words, our growth could be affected by global warming.

**A NEW LIFE**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. He says, "After 14 years in the City, it became boring and no one was enjoying their work anymore. I didn’t plan to leave for another five or ten years, but then I lost my job unexpectedly. I didn’t get a great pay-off, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a well-known hotel restaurant. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat online. I’m happy to be out of the office, but surprisingly, not much has changed for me: I still work 80 to 90 hours a week and sell a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Able was a manager in advertising, but now he makes a living as an artist. He explains, "I started painting as a hobby, but I found it much more exciting than my job. It made sense to take redundancy and become an artist. The career counselor I spoke to was very supportive. I think I was the first person to tell him, 'I don’t want to go back to my old job.' He was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to find work quickly for money. My wife and I married young, and our children are grown, so we took a risk and moved to northern England, where we didn’t know anyone. We left our friends behind, but we’ve been lucky; many of them still visit us."

**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business in her London flat. She says, "Being a lawyer was fun and paid well, but the hours were terrible. I didn’t want to become a senior partner and work even more, so I left. Many people thought I would get bored, but that hasn’t happened. The key is to set deadlines. In fashion, there are always collections and new designs to work on, so I keep a strict schedule. I feel happier now and less stressed. However, I miss the social interaction with colleagues. What I love about this job is that I am fully responsible for my work. If I do a bad job, I am the one to blame. When you work for a company, you care, but when your name is on the product, you care even more."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He shares, "I was in finance from the age of 22, making deals. I enjoyed the excitement, but I didn’t find the work fulfilling. I almost lost my job in 1989, but I decided to resign and travel for a year. During that time, I thought about what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited top gyms and spoke to the owners about how they started. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took massage courses. Then, I got a part-time job at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my life, which is the best part."

**A Winning Game**

Two brothers have found that their childhood game is great for business. Dave and Norm Lagasse, who are in their forties, are sitting in their simple home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA, and enjoying their childhood memories. In front of them is a wooden board with round plastic pieces. They are playing pichenotte, an ancient game that they believe is unique. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, who was a grocer from Quebec, Canada, brought the game to the USA and taught it to his family. Soon, every weekend and holiday, the family would play together and have a wonderful time. 

Later, the family moved to New Mexico, but they did not forget their grandfather's pichenotte board, which he made from old wooden crates. They continued to play regularly. When visitors came over, they were often curious because the game was unknown in the southern USA. 

Three years ago, Dave noticed that their old pichenotte board was cracked and worn out, so he decided to make a new one. The new board was beautiful, and soon a relative wanted one, followed by a friend. To see how much interest there was, the brothers took one of Dave's new boards to a sports bar in Santa Fe. Dave said, "People started to watch and say, 'No way I'm playing that silly game.' But then they would sit down, and soon they couldn't get up from the table!" 

When people asked about the game's origins, Dave did some research. He found that the game likely started in India, where a similar game called 'carroms' is played. This game was adapted into 'squails' in British pubs, and British immigrants brought it to Canada. The French-Canadian version is called pichenotte, which can be played by two to four people. 

Pichenotte is a game of skill. Each player has 12 pieces, or 'pucks', which they flick across a wheel-like board using their fingers. Getting a puck into a small hole is worth 20 points, while three rings around the hole are worth 15, 10, and 5 points. There are also eight small posts that act as obstacles. The game usually lasts about two minutes. 

After seeing how popular the game was at the bar, the Lagasse brothers made more boards and took them to markets and craft fairs. Crowds gathered, money was exchanged, and the game's popularity grew. Soon, championships were held, and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup' was created. As word spread, the boards sold quickly, and the brothers decided to start a pichenotte business full-time. 

They set up a workshop in their garage and have made over 450 boards so far. Each board is made of birchwood and mahogany, weighs 12 kg, and is 1 cm thick. Norm explains, "They're very durable because they need to handle a lot of use." The boards are sold for $595 each on the brothers' website. 

Currently, there are no professional pichenotte players or TV shows about the game. However, the brothers hope that one day their garage will be home to a luxury car instead of tools and wood. Until then, they are happy to spend their free time playing the game that they hope will bring them success.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**

When you first enter the Model Village, it is hard to believe that just a few years ago, this area was a messy piece of land, covered in brambles. For a long time, it was seen as useless land. However, with careful planning and hard work from one man, supported by his wife, this land has been transformed into the beautiful place you see today.

During the construction of the village, many thousands of tons of soil and clay were moved to change the flat land into the shaped landscape you see now. Although machines like bulldozers helped, a lot of hard work was also done by hand. Once the land was shaped, about 1,000 tons of topsoil were added to create lawns, flower beds, and rock gardens. 

In building the Model Village, hundreds of trees and shrubs were planted. These plants were carefully chosen to survive in the salty air near the sea and to withstand strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some were brought from as far away as Canada and New Zealand.

The whole idea for the village came from Colin Sims, who made over 100 models by hand over nine years after the village opened in 1972. The models are made from different materials like stone, concrete, treated wood, and plastics to resist all kinds of weather. At first, Colin needed help from experts to learn how to choose materials that would last. Soon, he became an expert himself.

You will notice that all the models are built to the same scale and that great care has been taken with even the smallest details. This was achieved through patience and special building techniques. The Model Village has become a popular attraction, known for its high-quality work and maintenance. The methods used to create these realistic models have been used in other model villages in England and have even been included in some college courses on modeling.

All the buildings in the village show traditional British architectural styles and are not based on any one specific place. One of the most impressive buildings is the Manor House, a typical 13th-century stone building with a brick tower and stone walls, inspired by manor houses found in the West Country. As you walk around the village, you will also see a Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is the newest addition.

We ask you to stay on the paths during your visit and not to touch any of the models, as any damage can take a long time to repair. You can take photos from the pathways only. Dogs are welcome on a short lead.

To make your visit more enjoyable, you will find buttons in front of some models. Press these buttons to see the models move. At the end of your visit, we would love to hear your comments. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us create a more interesting display. We also want to know if any models did not meet your expectations, as we are always updating and replacing them.

We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again. Please tell your friends about us!

Every week, British tabloid newspapers publish pictures that invade people's privacy and break the rules set by newspaper editors. While some pop stars do pose for paparazzi sometimes, this is not common. More often, serious harm is done to public figures when their private moments are shown on the front page. However, very few people report these issues to the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), which was created to handle such problems. These pictures rarely serve the public interest. For example, how do private photos of pop stars help solve a crime? How did a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony protect public health and safety? The actress has complained about long-lens photos before, and since she was in a hotel—a place where people expect privacy—she had a good reason to complain, but she did not take any action. It is a scandal that the PCC did not start an investigation on its own. 

The PCC should also look into a recent shocking story about a pop star's love life. Like the actress, the pop star has not made a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take action against these shameful attacks? This seems like a good idea because it could lead to many decisions against newspapers. These decisions would be reported by other media, and the public would not support such behavior. Editors would have to stop publishing this kind of material, and photographers would find it hard to make a living by hiding to take pictures of celebrities.

If the PCC decided to act like a "police officer," there would be several challenges. How would it decide whether to start an investigation? Should it contact the victim and encourage them to complain? If the person still refused to act, should the PCC proceed anyway? Celebrities and royals might expect the PCC to take up their stories and be upset if it does not. The role of the PCC is too big. How could it realistically monitor all of the British press, including national and regional newspapers and magazines? 

There is also the issue of embarrassment. Even if someone's privacy is invaded, would they want the added embarrassment of an investigation? Most people probably just want to move on with their lives. Some might have other reasons for staying quiet, like hiding a worse story from the press that could come out if they complain. In this way, the PCC could become an enemy.

One British comedian faced problems with the press when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon in the Caribbean. He did not complain then, nor did he complain later when a photographer took pictures of him and his family during a holiday. He was afraid that the newspaper, News of the World, would publish the pictures again with a new story about his anger, claiming they thought it was just a joke and that he would find it funny because he is a comedian. This fear is understandable. People believe they will become targets again if they challenge the tabloids. It is difficult to find an easy solution to this serious problem.

Many college graduates receive advice about starting their first job. This article focuses on what to consider when moving to a second job. We are not talking about those who are looking for a temporary job while searching for a permanent one, or those who leave a job they don’t like within a few weeks. Instead, we will discuss how to choose a second job that fits your career goals after you have gained some experience and skills.

What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. Think about whether you want to specialize in a certain area, aim for higher positions, or explore a wider field. Whatever you choose, it is important to select your second job carefully, as you should plan to stay in it for two to three years. Future employers will look closely at this job when you apply for your next position. It should show that you are serious about your career and that it helps you grow and take on more responsibilities.

If you feel the urge to travel, this might be a good time to do so. You can work temporarily while you travel and then return to find your second job later. Employers will appreciate that you have satisfied your desire to travel and are ready to settle down.

Juliette Davidson spent her first year after college working for three lawyers. She found this job to be a good start because her employers were supportive. She learned how to work in an office and improved her computer skills. However, there was no chance for promotion, so she decided to leave, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year.

Now, Juliette works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. She says, "In two and a half years, I have become more skilled, and my job has really developed." From the start, her boss wanted to help her grow. Although her job title has not changed, her responsibilities have increased. She now handles most of the correspondence and budgets and answers questions from various people, including company chairmen and those wanting to start their own businesses. Brenda involves her in all her work and also gives her specific projects and events to manage.

**Confident People: What’s Their Secret?**

Confident people may seem like they were born that way, but many say it is a skill they learned over time. Nina Hathway talks to five people about how they became confident.

**A. Jenny**  
When I finished school, I was very shy and thought I would always be that way. At twenty-five, I helped at my daughter’s school. I was nervous but did well, and someone suggested I take a university course. On my first day, I was very anxious, but my confidence grew over time. Working at the school changed my life and helped me become more outgoing.

**B. Michaela**  
My journey began four years ago when my father got sick, and I had to run the family business. I was scared and became too aggressive at first. I learned that to be confident, you need to believe in yourself. If work gets too hard, I don’t feel guilty about leaving some tasks for the next day. When facing challenges, I remind myself that I have nothing to lose. Fear can make you feel unconfident, so I talk to myself to calm those fears.

**C. Lisa**  
People see me as confident, but I often feel scared inside. I learned to appear confident because it is important in my job in TV. Interviewing people showed me that many of us feel nervous in important situations. My mother once told me that everyone is too busy worrying about themselves to notice me. I remember this advice often. I also believe that facing your fears helps build confidence. I was very nervous during my driving test, but after passing, I felt I could handle anything.

**D. Barbara**  
I feel confident because I enjoy my work, and I have built this confidence over the years. If you keep working and learn from mistakes, you will feel more confident next time. I work hard and am liked at my restaurant, but not everyone will like you, and that’s okay. You need to accept yourself and not try to be what others want. My company offers training courses, which have helped me feel better about myself. Setting small goals is also helpful because it shows you are making progress.

**E. Kim**  
After college, I worked as a secretary and often sat in meetings without sharing my thoughts because I was too scared. Eventually, I found the courage to speak up. When I started working in politics, I had never spoken in public and was very nervous. I told myself that many people do this every day, so I could too. Writing down my thoughts helped me feel more prepared. I believe everyone feels a bit nervous when speaking in public. The key to confidence is to keep telling yourself, “Nothing is impossible.”

**Visit to Malaysia**

Paul Forster attends a kite-flying festival and spends a nervous night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled widely when I gave him his torn kite. "You have to keep it," he said. "It's traditional - if the line breaks, the finder keeps it... and I have many more." He pointed to a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. All the kites were exactly 120 cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and split bamboo. We sat in the shade of the tall trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, looking at Malaysia's biggest kite festival.

In the center of the beach, there were 10 platforms where helpers held up the kites. A line of nervous competitors held the strings of their kites, waiting for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered, and the kites flew into the sky like rockets. More than 500 men and boys had signed up for the competition, which lasts for five days every year. Each participant entered four different kite designs, which were judged on decoration, stability in the air, and flying ability. 

"Flying kites isn't very hard," Adnan said, "but making them takes real skill. Come visit me at home, and I'll show you how to make one." This was one of five invitations I received that day, and I decided to accept. At his house, I drank cold milky tea and ate fish crackers in a large, shiny room. As night fell, he asked me to come back the next day to start rebuilding his kite, but I couldn't. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur, through beautiful mountains covered in lush rainforest.

I took a wrong turn, and the smooth road suddenly ended at a river. A small boat was waiting to take people across. Nearby, I saw a sign that pointed up a path into the forest, saying: "Jelawang Jungle 3 km." Before I started, it would have been good to know that most of the path was steep and slippery. When I reached the campsite, I found a man named Baba waiting with a flask of tea. He managed a kitchen and a few bamboo huts. I decided to stay there, trying not to think about the insects crawling under my thin mattress. 

At night, it was completely dark, filled with different sounds. A waterfall roared nearby, and many creatures moved and made noise. In the morning, I enjoyed a stunning view of five ranges of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First, the wind blew, then lightning struck the treetops. Moments later, I was soaked. As I slid down the hill, I wondered how the giant butterflies avoided the heavy rain. I also worried about my car getting washed away (which sometimes happens) and the chance of drowning if I opened my mouth. Luckily, my car was still there at the bottom of the hill, covered in mud.

In Kota Bahru, the capital of Kelantan, everyone asked me questions: "Where are you from?" "How old are you?" But their questions were friendly. While Kelantan is famous for its kites, I will always remember it for the kindness of its people.

What kind of shopper are you? We all go shopping, but there are different types of shoppers. Do you know which type you are? Abby Edwards asked some people about their shopping habits:

A. Melanie, 22, dancer: "I'm a shopping addict! I love spending money. When I have cash, I go shopping and it makes me happy. I can't resist sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we often shop together. We're both addicted!"

B. Brenda, 40, office manager: "I'm a reluctant shopper. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks and knows what he likes. I don’t enjoy shopping for clothes, especially with my kids, because we all have different tastes. I don’t spend much on myself, so when I do, I feel guilty and tell my husband I spent less than I really did."

C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager: "I only shop for essentials. I dislike shopping and only go when I have to. When I do shop, I know exactly what I want and I won’t settle for anything else. Shopping is tiring for me."

D. Anita, 35, TV producer: "I like to look around sometimes, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don’t waste time and try to shop quickly. However, I do have some clothes in my wardrobe that I regret buying, so maybe I’m a careful shopper who makes mistakes."

E. Lizzie, 41, secretary: "I really dislike shopping. I can never find what I want or get help. The shops are too noisy and messy, which makes it a nightmare for me. Luckily, I don’t have to shop for clothes often because I get most of my clothes as gifts. For food, I go to the supermarket once a week and do it quickly."

F. Lisa, 22, actress: "I’m probably a happy shopper. Sometimes I go shopping with my friends, and we often end up buying things. I don’t usually have something specific in mind, but if I see something I like, I buy it."

G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant: "I’m a careful shopper. I enjoy shopping, but I don’t buy much. I usually know what I want and don’t spend too much. Sometimes I shop to feel better, but then I often regret spending too much money."

H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker: "I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on Saturdays because it’s too busy. I’m a careful shopper. I have a good idea of what I want and I take my time to look in different shops for the best deals."

I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager: "I’m an unwilling shopper. Since I work in the city center, shopping isn’t exciting for me anymore. When I have to shop, I don’t try things on because it’s too much trouble. The clothes I buy don’t always fit, but I don’t mind making mistakes rather than putting in a lot of effort."

**NEW OPPORTUNITIES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE**

The Open University offers degrees just like other universities, but you can study without leaving your job. This can help you explore many new interests. If you have never studied before, you will enjoy the excitement of learning new things. You will also meet many different people. Your degree may lead to new job opportunities.

At the Open University, you do not attend lectures in person. Instead, you study at home using television, radio, and computer programs. If you want, you can go to one class a month at an Open University center. Like any university, you will need to take exams.

If you want to learn more, just fill out the form below. This could be the beginning of an exciting new chapter in your life.

**Gallery News**

**Easter Quiz for Children**  
During the Easter holidays, young visitors can join a quiz about surprises. Free quiz sheets are available at the desk by the Orange Street entrance. Children will be guided to 14 surprising paintings and will answer different questions about them. The quiz sheets can be picked up from 25 March to 9 April during normal gallery hours.

**New Picture**  
The Gallery now has a beautiful still life painting by the Dutch artist Jan van Os from the 18th century. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) shows flowers and fruit in bright colors on wood. It is one of the first paintings of this kind in the Gallery. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778. It is common for artists to date their work in two years because they wait for certain flowers to bloom in different seasons. This painting was kindly given to the Gallery by Miss Violet Churchman in memory of her sister, Ida Nancy. It is now displayed in Room 25.

**Special Exhibition**  
The exhibition "Painting in Spain during the Late 18th Century" opened in the Sunley Room on 15 March. The Gallery has recently acquired works by three Spanish painters from this time: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu, who are the main focus of the exhibition. They are joined by Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italian artists who worked in Spain during this period: Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition will be open until 31 May.

**Lecture News**  
A series of lectures related to the special exhibition continues every Wednesday. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will talk about Melendez's work. On 12 April, Sarah Symmons will discuss Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will speak about Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists often tell stories through their paintings.

**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**  
The Gallery is happy to announce that the restaurant has improved and expanded its services. With new kitchens, the restaurant now offers a wide variety of hot and cold dishes at reasonable prices.

**Information for Visitors**  
Free guided tours of the Gallery are available every day at 11:00 am and 3:00 pm (except Sundays). These tours introduce some of the Gallery's greatest paintings and showcase important European artworks from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

**Little Chefs**

A group of children aged ten to fifteen spends their Saturdays learning how to cook. Their small classes are very popular, and there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course, where kids can have fun and learn to make delicious food. 

Bill, who is ten years old, says, "I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down to eat the food we've made." 

Flora, who is twelve, has some trouble with onions. She says, "I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really enjoyed it. My mum suggested I find a hobby instead of doing nothing on weekends. I was happy at home, so I wasn't very excited at first. But I'm really glad I decided to come." 

Their teacher, Philippe, says, "It's a lot of fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, even if the kitchen isn't always clean when they cook! As adults, we keep learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking when they are young, they will have the skills to cook for themselves when they leave home."

**Outdoor Centre Fees**  
The fees for the Outdoor Centre are for a car with four people. If you have more than four people, it costs an extra 50p for each additional person. Please pay the fees at the main office. The centre is not a private club; it is open to everyone and aims to provide outdoor sports and recreation for the public. If you are coming with a group, please let the centre know in advance.

**Windsurfing - One-Day Course**  
We offer beginner windsurfing courses on Saturdays and Sundays when the weather is good. Learning to windsurf is very enjoyable, and the thrill of sailing across the water for the first time is unforgettable. We provide boards with small sails for beginners. **MONEY**

What is money? The pound, the dollar, and the franc are types of money, similar to how a gram or a kilometer are units of measurement. The main difference is that you can use money to buy things. For example, a five-pound note can be used to buy a book, a large bag of sweets, or a few cinema tickets. However, the note itself is just a piece of paper that costs very little to produce.

Thousands of years ago, people did not have money like we do today. There were no banks or shops. Back then, Mr. Green, a farmer, would trade the corn he grew for Mr. Hive's honey. This was a direct exchange between two people, each with something the other wanted. Over time, most societies created their own forms of money, called 'currencies', to make trading easier. Eventually, different currencies started to connect, which is why today we all use a national currency.

**THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST**

Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many centuries, she was the only woman scientist recognized in history. Her father was the director of Alexandria University, and he ensured that she received the best education possible. This was rare because most women at that time had few chances to study.

After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia returned to Alexandria and started teaching mathematics. She quickly became well-known for her understanding of new ideas. Although we do not have any of her books today, we know she wrote several important works on mathematics. Hypatia was also interested in technology and created several scientific tools to assist her work.

During her time, many rulers were afraid of science, and people involved in it were often in danger. In March 415, Hypatia was attacked in the street and killed.

**Grass**

Grass is one of the most successful plants in the world. There are more than 9,000 different types of grasses, and they can be found in every part of the earth. Grass is unique because it can grow in very cold places like the Arctic and Antarctic. 

Grasslands are home to many animals, from small insects and birds to large animals like cows and lions. All these animals rely on grass for food in some way. 

One interesting thing about grass is that it grows back quickly after being cut or damaged. Unlike other plants, new leaves grow from below the ground, not from the top. This is why many animals can live together in one area. When they eat all the grass, new grass starts to grow again, providing fresh food for them.

Kal Kaur Rai, the Young Achiever of the Year, has always loved fashion. She recently won this title at the Asian Business Awards. Since she was a child, she enjoyed drawing clothes and creating designs. However, she never told her parents, who run a supermarket, about her dream to make fashion her career. She thought they wanted her to choose a more traditional job, so she studied management at university.

After finishing university, Kal moved to London and worked at an advertising agency. She had to go to many industry events but couldn’t afford the designer clothes she admired. To solve this, she started making skirts and tops for herself. When her friends saw her creations, they asked her to make clothes for them too. 

Kal then found a small shop in London that agreed to sell her designs on a sale-or-return basis. Her clothes became very popular, and nothing was returned. This success encouraged her to leave her advertising job, take out a £20,000 loan, and start her own womenswear brand.

When Bo the cat decided to explore a furniture van, she had a bigger adventure than she thought. The driver found her after he had driven over 500 kilometers. It was the end of a long day, and both the driver and Bo were hungry. He gave her some milk and started to ask questions. He called his last customers, but they had not lost a cat.

**The Ghan Train**

Mark Ottaway took a train journey from Darwin, in northern Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train travels across Australia, from the warm northern coast through vast deserts to the cooler Southern Ocean. It is often called the "famous Ghan," but it is known for being late.

The idea of a train link between Darwin and Adelaide started in the 1920s, with a line reaching Alice Springs. However, heavy flooding often made it hard for trains to run. A new line was finished just a few months before my trip. The railway was built for speeds up to 115 kph, but the Ghan is not a fast train. It has few stops, and most passengers are on holiday. The Ghan does not offer luxury like the Orient Express, but the food on board is very good. The railway was originally built to transport goods, not passengers. It was believed that sending goods from Europe to southern Australia through Darwin and the train would save time and money compared to shipping around the continent.

It is rare to complete a transcontinental railway, and the Ghan claims to be the world's first north-south railway. As I waited to board, I noticed that everyone was excited about the journey. Many of my fellow travelers were Australian retirees who were especially eager to get on the train.

Our first stop was Katherine, where the Ghan stayed for four hours. Some passengers got off to take a boat trip in the gorge. I stayed on the train until Alice Springs, where I joined a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock is not encouraged now, and few people do it. Our group walked around the rock and enjoyed the beautiful sunset.

From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week going south, so many passengers stop their journey there. The view from the train after Alice Springs is not very interesting; there is a lot of flat land with only cattle to see. But on the third day at dawn, we reached the foothills near the Southern Ocean. My journey was ending, and even though the train did not meet all the promises made in advertisements, it took me to some of the most amazing sights in Australia.

**Climbing to the Top of Britain**

Every year, thousands of people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. Because it is in the north, the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt shares his experience of climbing Ben Nevis for the first time.

It was February, and it was my first big winter climb. We chose a route up the north face of the mountain to Tower Ridge. This climb is six hundred meters high, making it one of the longest in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are large bowl-shaped areas cut into the mountain halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You really need these spikes on Ben Nevis because the snow can be so hard that it feels like walking on ice. 

Even though some people in our group were very experienced, we packed a lot of safety equipment, including lights to signal for help, hard hats, and extra clothes. The weather forecast was good, with no strong winds, but we still felt nervous when we started our climb. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is always difficult.

As we climbed, the path became steeper, and my legs felt heavy. I was the weakest member of the group, so I needed to take more breaks. The others sometimes stopped to let me catch up, but as soon as I did, they would start climbing again. I promised myself that I would train better before my next climb.

After climbing 200 meters, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the path that leads to the top of Ben Nevis. This path is only a meter and a half wide, and the mountain drops hundreds of meters on both sides. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on every step as we moved slowly along it. After seven hours of climbing, we finally reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, which is 48 kilometers away. Unfortunately, we were not lucky that day because a mist had come down.

Getting back down to camp can be just as hard as going up. You need to read a map well because a wrong turn could lead to dangerous slopes in winter. I was glad we took turns reading the map. It was only when I was safe in the tent that I could say I really enjoyed the experience. But at least I made it to the top!

This week has been very exciting because we have moved into our new school building! It is a wonderful place. The builders used wood for the whole building, just like in our old school, but this one is also designed to be environmentally friendly. It took many months to build, and we watched the construction happen. It was exciting to see the builders clear the land, but it also meant that some nice open space was lost. The noise from the machines was very loud, and sometimes the builders had to stop because of heavy rain. We started to think the building would never be finished.

Now, we have five classrooms that are very big—much larger than the old school next door, which was very old. We share one room with people from the town for meetings. There is also a nursery, a nice dining room, and large changing rooms that we are excited to use when our new sports field is ready.

When you enter the school, you will notice that there are no heaters! Instead, the heat comes from everyone inside—the children, the teachers, and the computers. The building is designed to keep the heat inside, and it also keeps the sound in, so when we sing in our classrooms, it feels like we are in a concert hall!

Another interesting thing is that the school roof has a tree on it! The builders put it there after finishing the roof because it is a custom in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for the lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We visited it with our teacher yesterday, and it spins very fast. It is so big that we can see it from far away! We took some pictures to put on our website.

Even though we are already using the school, some parts are still being finished. For example, we are putting on a play for our parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall to do it. The new hall will be ready by next year. We are very happy with our new school, and our teachers say we will learn much faster now that we are here!

**Letter to the Newport Evening News**

On Saturday afternoon, I left my handbag on the bus. Inside it were my cheque book, address book, and my purse, which had about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized I had lost it, it was too late. I didn’t know what to do. I am 72 years old, far from home, and I felt very worried. I stood by the road and cried.

A young man saw me and asked what was wrong. I told him what happened, and he gave me some money for my bus fare home. When I explained the situation to the bus driver, he said I could keep the fare. I got home safely, and soon after, the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus. He told me they had found my handbag and offered to bring it back to me.

I was amazed to get my handbag back with everything inside still there. I want to thank everyone who helped me that day. I really appreciate their kindness and honesty.

Mrs. B. James, Newport

**Sharks**

Sharks are some of the most frightening animals in our oceans. They are very good at hunting underwater because they can see well and feel movement through special lines on the sides of their bodies. This makes sharks dangerous for smaller sea animals that they eat.

Although sharks are similar to other fish in some ways, their bodies are different. For example, most sharks need to swim all the time to breathe and stay alive, so they hardly ever sleep. Also, if sharks are turned upside down, they can stop moving completely. This is a useful technique for researchers who need to study sharks. It helps them learn more about these interesting creatures.

**Joining the Kirov Ballet**

My name is Nathalie. Last year, I became one of the youngest foreign students to join the Kirov ballet school in St Petersburg, Russia. **THE ICEHOTEL**

For many years, the Arctic was a popular place to visit in the summer to see the land of the midnight sun. However, in winter, the few people living there enjoyed the snow and ice by themselves. By the end of the 1980s, people started to see the dark and cold winter as a good thing. 

In the winter of 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit was invited to open an exhibition in a special igloo (a building made of snow) in the small town of Jukkasjarvi, located on the frozen Torne River. This building, called Arctic Hall, attracted many visitors. One night, a group of foreign guests decided to sleep in Arctic Hall. The next morning, they were very happy with their experience, and the idea of an ice hotel was created. Today, it is famous around the world.

When winter starts, a team of snow builders, architects, and artists from different countries come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel for that year. As each part is finished, it opens to visitors and guests, while the other parts are still being built. The first part is completed in December, and every week after that, a new part opens until January 7th, when the hotel is fully completed. Because the ICEHOTEL is built outside using natural winter materials, the finishing date can change depending on the weather.

In spring, as the weather gets warmer, the hotel melts. Inside the hotel, the temperature is never colder than -5 to -8 degrees Celsius, no matter how cold it is outside. Guests receive warm winter clothes like overalls, hats, and gloves as part of their stay. It is also a good idea for guests to bring sweaters, scarves, and plenty of woollen socks. They should choose shoes that are a bit larger than normal to fit the thick socks.

If you plan to visit the hotel, you can buy warm sweaters, woollen socks, and more on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these items along with your booking, and they will be delivered to your room when you check in. The hotel is located in the village of Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. You can arrange bus transport from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.

**Shopping for Furniture**

A report by Dave Worthington

Homestyle, a new furniture shop, had to close shortly after it opened at midnight last Thursday. Up to 6,000 people rushed to the shop because of many special offers. For example, a leather sofa was on sale for £45, but only until 3 am, and a bed was £30, but only between 3 am and 8 am. The shop's regular hours will be from 9 am to 9 pm every day, but Homestyle had planned to stay open for the first 24 hours without closing. However, it had to shut down just half an hour after opening.

A police officer who came to the shop said, "We knew a large crowd was coming, but people were not patient. The shop quickly became full, and the managers wisely decided to close the doors. The people outside got angry because they thought everything would be sold out before they could get in, and they refused to wait quietly in line until there was space for them. Another problem was that there was a long line of cars trying to get to the parking lot. I couldn't believe that many people just left their cars in the middle of the road and walked the last few meters to the shop, which blocked the road completely."

One customer, Jenny Smith, who got into the shop, said, "I waited in line for three hours, but I didn't have time to buy what I wanted. The staff were very calm and explained what was happening. They had no choice because it wasn't safe. I will come back when they reopen, but I don't want to wait in line again."
