For nearly thirty years, the Society has brought writers into schools, helping children and teachers with new ideas and building confidence in writing. One of our current projects is the Young Writer of the Year, which started in 1998 and is for writers aged 11-18. All winners receive book prizes and are invited to a five-day course taught by professional writers.

**The Writers' Cafe**

The Writers' Cafe is the social center of the Society. It is a relaxed and stylish place with freshly cooked vegetarian food, great coffee, and cold drinks. It is perfect for looking through the Society's magazines. The Cafe also hosts monthly exhibitions, short courses, and readings. It is located in the heart of London and is open from 11:00 am to 10:00 pm Monday to Friday and 11:00 am to 8:00 pm on Saturday. Members receive discounts on selected products and events.

**Becoming a Member**

We have members all over the world, and anyone aged 18 or older can join. If you want to become a member of The Short Story Society, click here and fill out a registration form.

**Free-diving in the Caribbean**

Tanya Streeter is a free-diver who holds four world records in this sport. Free-diving is when people dive deep into the ocean using only one breath of air. In 2003, Tanya made history by becoming the first person to dive 120 meters deep while holding her breath and then swim back up without any help. A year earlier, she had dived deeper but used a balloon to come back up. This time, she held her breath for over three and a half minutes, making her the first woman to break a world record previously held by a man.

During her dive, a team of fourteen safety divers watched her from different depths. Some people think free-diving is too dangerous because of accidents that have happened, but Tanya believes that safety and training are very important. 

Most free-divers focus on one or two types of events, but Tanya follows a consistent training schedule. Two-thirds of her training is done in the gym, while the rest is split between the pool and the ocean. She uses an exercise bike to improve her heart fitness but avoids running to protect her knees. Instead, she prefers fast walking to stay fit.

When she practices diving, she usually travels away from home. She aims to complete fourteen dives over four weeks, taking a rest day between each dive. It is crucial for her to avoid getting tired, as this could affect her performance.

When Tanya is not training, she often makes public appearances to promote sports products and supports environmental organizations through research and films. Growing up on the Caribbean island of Grand Cayman, she loved swimming and exploring rock pools to see sea life. Tanya feels that her life now is like living her childhood dreams. Because she is famous in some countries, she believes people listen to her when she talks about environmental issues.

Looking to the future, Tanya, who is now in her thirties, plans to continue breaking her own world records. She started free-diving at the age of twenty-five and is excited to keep competing for many more years.

**CARTOON FILMS**

Cartoon films have very few limits. If you can draw something, you can make it move on the screen. New ideas and advanced computer programs are making cartoons exciting for people of all ages. By the end of the 1970s, many in the film industry thought cartoons were only for children. However, a few directors came up with original ideas that showed cartoons could be fun for both adults and children. 

Not every cartoon film was a success, though. For example, "The Black Cauldron" did not do well because it was too scary for children and too silly for adults. Directors learned from this mistake, and film companies started to make a lot of money again.

New TV Star Caroline Benson talks about her first role on television. 

"I never thought I would spend part of my first year at university filming The Finnegans. I had only acted in school plays, but I loved the book since I was eleven. My grandmother used to say I was just like Polly Finnegan, and I always dreamed of playing her. 

Before starting university, I took a year off to travel. While I was in Chile, my mother emailed me to say they were planning to make the book into a TV drama. I knew I had to try for the role. My mother was surprised at first, but she sent my photo to the director and convinced him to meet me. I flew back and got the part. 

Filming started a week after university began, so I asked for permission to be away for three weeks. When I returned to university, I woke up at 6:00 am to catch up on the essays I had missed. I didn’t tell my friends at university, but they found out and thought it was amazing. It was a wonderful experience, and I feel very lucky. 

After university, I definitely want to make acting my career. I’m not from an acting family, but my grandfather was an opera singer. I have tried for other TV roles, but I haven’t received any offers yet. I’m not sure how I managed everything because I also had a busy social life. 

When filming ended, I didn’t know what to do next. Since then, I have acted in two college plays. Unfortunately, I haven’t been home much, and now that my first year at university is over, I’m going to Greece for the summer with friends."

**No Title**

When I opened the first 'Body Shop' in 1976, my main goal was to earn enough money to feed my children. Today, 'The Body Shop' is a fast-growing international company. Over the years, I have learned a lot, and much of this knowledge is shared in this book. I believe our company has valuable insights on how to run a successful business while staying true to our beliefs.

This is not a typical business book, nor is it just about my life. The main message is that to succeed in business, you need to be different. Business can be enjoyable, it can be run with love, and it can make a positive impact. In both business and life, I want to feel happy, have a sense of family, and be excited by new experiences. I have always wanted the people who work for 'The Body Shop' to feel the same way.

Now, this book shares my ideas with the world. I believe there are no limits to our 'family' or to what we can achieve. I find this thought exciting, and I hope you do too.

**A Journey Along the Beautiful Douro River**

Jules Verne operates a 'hotel ship' on the Douro River in Portugal. The MV Lady Ivy May can accommodate 160 guests in double cabins, all with outside views and private bathrooms. On the ship, you will find air-conditioning, a sun-deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library.

**Itinerary**

**Day 1:** You will leave London Heathrow in the early evening and arrive in Oporto. Your guide will meet you and take you to the Lady Ivy May, where you will spend the night.

**Day 2:** After sightseeing in Oporto in the morning, you will return to the ship and sail to Entre-os-Rios. This part of the journey takes four hours.

**Day 3:** You will continue up the river. In the early evening, the ship will stop at Peso da Regua, known for its port wine. At dinner, you can enjoy delicious local food and drinks.

**Day 4:** After breakfast, you will travel by bus to the ancient town of Lamego. You will visit the cathedral, several churches, and a museum that used to be a palace. The museum has a great collection of paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. After the visit, you will return to the ship and sail to Tua.

**Day 5:** The Douro River becomes very narrow here. Depending on the river's depth, you may take a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. You will return to Tua by coach, enjoying the sights along the way.

**Day 6:** In the morning, you will drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for one of the best views in the Douro Valley. After lunch on the ship, you will take the Douro Valley railway for a scenic ride to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting for you.

**Day 7:** You will visit Vila Real before returning to the ship for lunch. Then, you will sail down the river back to Oporto, where you will spend the night on board.

**Day 8:** You will arrive in Oporto with enough time for sightseeing and last-minute shopping before your flight back to London Heathrow.

**HONEY**

Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It is made up of water and sugars. To make just half a kilo of honey, bees can travel up to seventy-five thousand kilometers and visit over two million flowers. The color and taste of honey depend on the type of flower the bees visit. There are more than three hundred different types of honey. Generally, lighter-colored honey has a milder taste than darker honey.

In ancient times, honey was the main sweet food because sugar was very rare. The ancient Egyptians valued honey so much that they used it as a form of payment. Today, honey is produced and consumed all over the world. Research shows that honey can help reduce tiredness and improve athletic performance. Additionally, honey is not only a food; it can also be used to soothe sore throats and is found in many skin and hair-care products.

**Norwich**

Norwich is the capital of East Anglia, a region in Britain, and has been a place to live for over two thousand years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. By the time of the Norman invasion in 1066, it had grown into one of the largest towns in England. Norwich has two cathedrals and a mosque, making it an important center for different religions. The first cathedral was built in 1095 and recently celebrated its 900th anniversary. In 1994, Norwich celebrated its 800th anniversary of becoming a city, which allowed it to govern itself.

Today, Norwich is smaller than cities like London or Manchester, with a population of about 150,000. However, in the 16th century, it was the second city of England. For the next 300 years, it continued to grow and became wealthy, known for having as many churches as there are weeks in a year and as many pubs as there are days in a year. Nowadays, there are fewer churches and pubs, but in 1964, the University of East Anglia was established in Norwich. With a growing number of students and its success as a commercial center (it is the largest center for insurance services outside London), Norwich now offers many entertainment options, including theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, busy cafes, excellent restaurants, and arts and leisure centers. The city also has a football team known as 'The Canaries', which wears green and yellow, though the reason for the name is unclear.

One of the city's new attractions is a modern shopping center called 'The Castle Mall'. For over two years, the people of Norwich dealt with a large hole in the city while builders worked on the main car park. They moved nearly a million tons of earth to create a park on the roof of the Mall, complete with water features and many trees. The local people are happy that the old open market still exists in the city center, next to the new development. Both areas continue to thrive, showing that Norwich has successfully combined the old and the new.

**The Albuquerque Balloon Festival**

Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a city in the southwestern United States, fills with bright colors. This is the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, a nine-day event that happens every year. The first festival took place in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of a local radio station. It started with about twelve hot-air balloons taking off from a parking lot in the city. Since then, the festival has grown a lot. This year, at least a thousand balloons from over a third of the countries in the world are expected to join the event at its new location outside the city.

**What to See**

The balloon pilots communicate with each other using radios, and they all light up their balloon burners at the same time. This event is called a "balloon glow," and it is a great chance to take beautiful photos. To see the balloon glows, you should arrive just after dark or before 5:30 am. During the day, you can walk among the balloons and talk to the pilots as they get ready for take-off. The balloons come in many sizes and colors, with some shaped like animals or cartoon characters, as well as popular products like soft drinks and fast food. Kids will really enjoy it!

In the afternoon, you can also take a balloon ride over the desert with one of the many companies that offer this experience. Another option is to ride the cable car from the desert floor to the top of the nearby mountains, which is the longest cable car ride in the world, and enjoy a great view of the festival.

There are many other attractions for visitors of all ages, including balloon races and fireworks on the first night and the last three nights of the festival.

**The Albuquerque Box**

This is a local wind pattern that creates perfect conditions for balloon flying. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentler winds at different heights. This allows skilled pilots to control the direction of their balloons by going up or down.

**Practical Advice**

Buy your tickets in advance online to avoid long waits at the festival. Wear several layers of light clothing because it can be cool at night and in the early morning, but during the day, you will need sunglasses and sunscreen. Bring a flashlight for night events and, of course, don’t forget your camera. If you use film instead of a digital camera, make sure to bring high-speed film for evening and night photos.

The Eden Project

Since it opened, the Eden Project in the south-west of England has become one of the most popular tourist attractions in the UK. At first glance, the large 'biospheres' on this old industrial site look like something from a science-fiction movie. Each biosphere represents a different climate zone, showing visitors how important the connection between people and plants is. It is surprising to see how many everyday products come from plants, such as wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate. Over 135,000 different types of plants are grown here. No matter how cold it is outside, computer-controlled heaters keep the plants at the right temperature. In the Rainforest Zone, the air is always humid because of a large waterfall. Another zone mimics the environment of the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa, and there are plans to create a desert zone in the near future.

Some people have said they do not like this year's collection, New Writing 3, but I don’t understand why. It is amazing to have 500 pages of original writing for just £6.99. Most of the book is fiction, including parts of novels and complete short stories. There are enjoyable pieces by well-known writers like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. Interestingly, many lesser-known writers have written mainly about food. I recommend you avoid reading Jane Harris's Those Nails right after eating, as it has some very unpleasant scenes that might upset you! 

The collection also features great work from nineteen poets, including R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. There are excerpts from novels that are still being written by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. Additionally, there is a bit of non-fiction, including a funny article by Alan Rusbridger about certain newspapers and a remarkable piece by Ursula Owen about her life. Overall, this is an exceptional collection, and I am excited to see what next year's edition will bring.

**The Best Age to Start Learning the Violin**

Margaret Porter, a violinist and music teacher, believes that the best age to start learning the violin is between three and six years old. She says this is when children are discovering the world around them. Margaret, who lives in London, usually teaches children who are three or four years old, but she sometimes makes exceptions for enthusiastic five-year-olds.

When she began teaching in 1972, her first class included her children’s five-year-old friends. Margaret teaches in groups, with about twelve students in each class. Each lesson lasts one hour and takes place every two weeks. In addition, each student has one individual lesson with her every week. Parents are also required to attend the classes because it is important for them to be involved in their child's learning.

From the very first lessons, students learn to play music by ear. They do not start reading music until they have been playing for several years. For a long time, there is a noticeable difference between how well they can play and how well they can read music. Margaret explains that her teaching method is not meant to create expert violinists. She often advises students who excel to leave and study the violin using more traditional methods.

**Moonshine**

The band Moonshine released their third CD last week. The new album, called "Here Again," follows their previous one, "The Waves." There have been some changes in the band since the last CD. Tom Wilcott is now playing bass guitar, replacing Simon McVee, who left the band last year. Also, Tom Simpson has joined as the new drummer.

From the first song, which is a dance track, it is clear that the band is moving away from slow songs. The second song is also a dance tune and is even louder and heavier. Many fans might be surprised by these two tracks, as they are different from the band's usual style. However, both songs are excellent and could easily become popular singles. 

Singer Rob Letchford shows off his talent by hitting every note perfectly. Fans should be thankful that he recorded these songs before he had problems with his throat, which has caused the band to cancel their upcoming tour. Anyone who bought tickets does not need to worry, as the concerts will be rescheduled once Rob has recovered.

In this CD, Moonshine demonstrates that they can create great music in different styles, from the slow songs fans know to the upbeat tracks that make you want to dance. However, I felt that the best songs were at the beginning, and the last few tracks were not as strong. Despite this, "Here Again" is sure to be a big success and will bring more recognition to the band.

**San Francisco**

San Francisco is located on the northern California coast. The first Europeans to find this area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola, who saw it for the first time in 1769. Interestingly, even though San Francisco Bay is a beautiful natural harbor, it was discovered by land, not by sea.

In 1849, many people came to San Francisco hoping to find gold. However, it was not the gold seekers who became rich. The wealthiest people were those who owned banks and law firms, and they built large houses on a hill called Nob Hill.

Today, many tourists visit San Francisco to see famous sites like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Many also take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to visit the old prison there.

**SAMUEL PEPYS**

The most famous diary in English was written by Samuel Pepys. It gives a detailed and interesting look at everyday life in England from 1660 to 1669. Pepys writes about important events of that time, such as diseases, an enemy navy coming up the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also shares personal stories, including his own mistakes—like often falling asleep in church or looking at pretty girls. 

He talks about his home life, including arguments with his wife and how they made up, as well as his worries about her health. Besides reading, he enjoyed music, the theatre, card games, and parties with good food and fun. Pepys was a busy man with many important jobs; he was a Member of Parliament and the President of the Royal Society. He is also remembered for his contributions to the British Navy.

**The History of Shoes**

In the past, people did not think much about whether shoes were comfortable or stylish. Early shoes were likely made from animal skins, which people tied around their ankles to keep warm. Today, we still use leather, but other materials like silk, plastic, and cotton are also common, depending on current fashion trends. 

It was only about 150 years ago that people started wearing different shoes for each foot. Before that, shoes were straight and could be worn on either foot. All shoes used to be made by hand, but now most shoes are made by machines in large factories. The invention of sewing machines helped the shoe industry produce many more shoes at lower prices, making them available to more people.

**No Title**

When I hurt my back, I had to stop running for a while. I wanted to help more women get into running, to show them how enjoyable it can be and to help them feel confident enough to start. So, I decided to create a running club for women in my area. I was frustrated with many race organisers who complain about not having enough women in the sport but do not provide separate changing rooms for them.

I put up posters, and 40 women of different ages and fitness levels joined the club. Most of them were interested in losing weight, but I don’t think they had considered running before. If they did, they only thought about the hard training. They didn’t imagine running could be fun, with chatting and smiling in beautiful places, like by a river.

At first, they could only run for one minute, but now they can run for thirty minutes. They have also learned about healthy eating and staying fit from other runners. I wanted to do something for women’s running, and it has been a joy to see their progress, almost as much as they have enjoyed it themselves.

**THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH**

In the 1880s, gold was found in Alaska, the northernmost state in the USA. Many people came to Alaska hoping to become rich. New towns were built quickly, including one called Iditarod, which means "far, distant place." In 1909, Iditarod grew so fast that it briefly became the largest city in Alaska.

In the summer, supplies could be delivered to these towns by boat. However, in winter, the rivers and ocean froze, making it hard to reach them. To solve this problem, a winter trail was built in 1910 for dog teams pulling sleds. These teams delivered mail, food, and clothes to gold miners. This trail became known as the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for a team of dogs to travel across Alaska, stopping at "roadhouses" where drivers could find a warm bed and food for themselves and their dogs.

The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when airplanes replaced dog teams and boats as the main way to transport goods. However, in 1925, dogs became famous again when a disease called diphtheria struck the city of Nome. The medicine needed to cure the disease was in Anchorage, on the other side of Alaska. At that time, airplanes were new, and no one was sure if they could fly in the cold weather. The only skilled pilot, Carl Eielson, was away on a trip. So, it was decided to use dog teams to transport the medicine instead.

The journey was over 1,000 kilometers, mostly along the Iditarod Trail. Twenty dog teams completed the trip in just six days. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian who had come to Alaska for gold, traveled the first 400 kilometers. He relied on his dog Togo to guide them through the heavy snow, and Togo proved to be a great help. The last part of the journey was done by Gunnar Kaasen, who had driven dog teams in Alaska for 21 years. His lead dog was Saito. At one point, Balto, another dog, refused to go further, preventing the team from falling into icy water. Thanks to their efforts, the diphtheria outbreak was stopped, and Balto became a hero.

Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the route of that famous journey in 1925. This race is called the Iditarod and is known as "The Last Great Race on Earth."

**Sweden's Ice Hotel**

The village of Jukkasjarvi is located in Swedish Lapland, where winter temperatures can drop to -40°C. Despite the cold, around 6,000 tourists visit each year to see one of the most unique hotels in Europe. In this hotel, everything is made of ice, including the rooms where you eat, drink, and sleep. You can even have a wedding there! The bar is also made of ice, so it is not a good idea to put hot drinks on it.

The bedrooms are kept at about -4°C, but guests receive special sleeping bags to keep warm in the cold. If needed, the hotel can also provide suitable outdoor clothing. The Ice Hotel is rebuilt every winter because it melts in the summer, and it is never older than six months. Building the hotel requires 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow.

**Maria Mutola**

In 1988, Maria Mutola was the only girl playing football on an all-boys team in a local competition in Mozambique. "We won," she said. "At first, no one thought it was a problem that I was a girl. But then the team we beat complained." This story was published in a local newspaper, and Jose Craveirinha, who supported other African athletes, learned about Maria. He went to meet her and saw her kicking a ball outside the football club. He quickly realized she was very fast.

"He talked to me about athletics," Maria said. "I didn’t understand what he meant. The only sport I knew was football. Then he bought me running shoes and took me to train. It was very hard work, and my legs hurt a lot." Jose also spoke to her parents and convinced them that she could be successful, which would help their family. They agreed to let him take her away to train.

In 1991, Maria accepted an invitation to train in the United States. She had said no before because she was worried about missing her family. Her life was very different from the girls she met in the US. She explained, "They were good athletes, but while I worried about my parents having enough food, they worried about dresses and make-up. They didn’t know much about me or my problems. But I knew I was lucky to be there. The trainers were amazing, and I learned a lot."

Today, Maria still runs and spends most of the year happily living in South Africa with her mother.

**The Skywalk**

The Grand Canyon in the United States was formed by the Colorado River. Many people visit Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and especially to enjoy the view. The view is amazing, and it is even more impressive because of the Skywalk. The Skywalk is 1,219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform made of glass, allowing you to see the beautiful rocks below. Up to 120 people can stand on it at the same time. The Skywalk opened in 2007, and since then, thousands of visitors have experienced it. To protect the glass, you must wear special covers over your shoes. Walking on the Skywalk feels like flying high in the air, just like a bird.

**THE ROCKIES**

The Rocky Mountains stretch almost the entire length of North America. They begin in the Northwest and are only a few hundred miles from the center in the southern areas. Although the Rockies are smaller than the Alps, they are still very beautiful. There are many roads that go through the Rockies, but the best way to see them is by train. 

You can start your journey from Vancouver, which is one of the most beautiful cities in Canada. This city is located by the water and near the mountains, allowing people to ski just 15 minutes by car from the city center. 

In the past, thirty passenger trains left Vancouver every day for the cross-continent railway. Now, there are only three trains a week, but the trip is still an exciting adventure. You can sleep on the train, which is fun, but you will see some of the best views at night.

**ZOOS**

People have kept animals in zoos for over 3,000 years. The first big zoo was called the Gardens of Intelligence, opened by the rulers of China. In the past, animals in zoos were trained to perform for visitors, but this is no longer done. Now, the main purpose of zoos is to let people see animals behaving naturally.

Today, most cities have a zoo or wildlife park. However, not everyone agrees with the idea of zoos. Supporters believe that zoos help us learn about nature and allow us to see wild animals up close. They think these experiences would not be possible without zoos.

On the other hand, some people do not support zoos. They believe it is wrong to keep animals in cages. They also argue that in poorly managed zoos, animals may live in dirty conditions and eat the wrong food.

**JAZZ**  
By Katie Atkins, aged 14  

I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from local high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different costumes, from black school uniforms like mine to bright T-shirts. We may not have looked like professional adult bands, but we were all used to performing in competitions, so the quality of our playing was amazing, especially since we are all so young. Players from each band even made up new songs right on stage. It was exciting to watch, but even better when my band performed!  

My school has a great jazz band, but not everyone who wants to join gets in—only about half of the applicants. However, anyone who is eager to play can attend jazz practice before school, and we often spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning about it. We also go on trips to jazz summer camps around the country. I have been to a couple and learned a lot.  

Adults are often surprised that young people are interested in jazz. My music teacher thinks it’s because pop music is not challenging enough for serious music lovers like me. I find jazz exciting because it feels both new and old at the same time. You can create your own music, but you also feel connected to its history, playing on stage like the great jazz performers before you. My school is very lucky to have great teachers and supportive parents. Without them, we wouldn’t get far with our music!

**Watering the Desert**

In Marrakesh, Morocco, it can rain anytime from November to March. However, it does not rain often. When it does rain, the city's water pipes cannot handle the sudden floods, causing the streets to become like rivers. Many winters have been dry recently, so when it finally rains, the local people are very happy.

The parks and gardens in Marrakesh do not rely on rain. Instead, they get water from a system of underground channels that were built in the 11th century. These channels bring water from the mountains all year round. Places that are mostly dry but receive water this way are called oases.

If you travel south from Marrakesh, you will reach Skoura. In Skoura, every piece of land is divided into small squares by water channels, and people use this land to grow food. The snow-covered Atlas mountains in winter create a beautiful view in the background.

**Gareth Ellis**

Gareth Ellis is 13 years old and the youngest son of Alan, an engineer, and Kath, a nursery teacher. His older brothers work in banking and computers, but Gareth has always wanted to be a clown. Three years ago, the whole family joined a circus. Kath says, "People laugh when we tell them, but it's true. Gareth has wanted to be a clown since we took him to the circus when he was three."

When Alan lost his job, he and Kath decided to look for full-time jobs in the circus. They both found jobs with a well-known circus, and Gareth started training to be a clown. He calls himself Bippo. They travel with the circus in the summer and go home in the winter. Gareth's brothers are old enough to take care of the house while they are away.

Kath explains, "I can't say it was easy. There was a lot to think about and organize. We only had a car and a small caravan to sleep in, and we were leaving our nice house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths."

Gareth shares, "People ask about my education, but from the start, someone has always come to teach me wherever we go. I use the same books as my friends at school, and I have a computer. I've never fallen behind my classmates."

What about the future? Kath says, "It was a hard decision, but there was no other way to teach Gareth about being a clown. I'm happy to say it's working, and we're enjoying it." And Gareth? He says, "I'm going to be the main clown in a circus one day, maybe Bippo's circus."

**Eight-eighteen News**

Eight-eighteen News is a news agency for young people aged 8 to 18. We collect news and write reports, stories, and articles. We send these to important newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, and websites to be published. You can read or listen to the news stories and articles by our members on the Eight-eighteen website.

We have three centers across the country where young people can meet others and join projects. We plan to open more centers soon. Since we started in 1994, when we were called 'Young News', over 2,500 young people have been members. Sophie is one of them. She says, "I first heard about Eight-eighteen when they interviewed me for an article about young people's views on hip hop music. I was amazed by the opportunities the young journalists had. Age didn’t matter; they were trusted to do stories on their own. I started going to the Eight-eighteen center in my city, got some training, and was a member until I turned 18. Eight-eighteen helped me achieve more than I thought I could. With the skills I learned, I got a job at 19 and am now the youngest employee on a major news website, checking articles before they are published."

**Get Involved at Every Level**

When you join Eight-eighteen, you will receive training and participate in monthly meetings to decide who will write each news story. Eight-eighteen encourages members to share their skills. 'Peer trainers' are experienced members aged 12 and older who train new members and teach them basic journalism skills. As they gain more experience, some members present sessions to young people and adults outside of Eight-eighteen, often in youth clubs and summer camps. These young trainers are always supported by older staff during these trips.

Eight-eighteen News holds training sessions for new members three times a year. Our next training for new members will be in February. If you or someone you know is interested in joining, call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The Eight-eighteen program is suitable for children with reading and writing skills at all levels. Membership is free, and there is no test to join.

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**

Welcome to our website! Here, you will find all the information you need before booking a flight.

During the short summer in Antarctica, we offer sightseeing flights from Sydney, Australia, on a Boeing 747. These flights take you over Antarctica and then back to Sydney. The exact dates for next year are not confirmed yet, but if you book now, your deposit can be moved to a different date if needed.

**Frequently Asked Questions**

**How long is the flight?**  
The average flight lasts 12 hours. About four hours into the flight, we usually see the first sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours flying over Antarctica and the rest of the time returning home. During the flight, experts who have worked in Antarctica will give talks about the environment and history, and they will answer your questions. There is also a camera next to the pilot that shows a view from the cockpit throughout the flight.

**Will I get a seat next to a window?**  
All passengers receive two boarding passes. At the halfway point of the flight, you will need to move to the seat shown on your second boarding pass. Business and first-class passengers will have a window seat for half of the flight and a seat next to a window for the other half. Economy passengers will have either a window seat or a seat next to a window for half of the flight and an end-of-row seat for the other half. While we are over Antarctica, we encourage passengers to get up and move around the plane so everyone can enjoy the views. The pilot will fly in long 'figure 8s' over interesting sights to ensure everyone can see well from both sides of the plane.

**What happens if the weather is bad?**  
We have 17 different approved flight plans. On the morning of the flight, our captain will check the satellite images of the clouds and choose the direction that offers the best views.

**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**  
Most wildlife in Antarctica lives at sea level, which is over 3,000 meters below the plane, so we cannot see them clearly. We do not land in Antarctica for environmental reasons. If you want to see Antarctic wildlife, you would need to join a boat tour.

**Can I take photographs?**  
Yes! You can bring all types of cameras. We also have some fun photo opportunities on board where you can try on Antarctic cold weather clothes.

**Little Chefs**

A group of children aged ten to fifteen spends their Saturdays learning how to cook. Their small classes are very popular, and there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course, where kids can have fun and learn to make delicious food. 

Bill, who is ten years old, says, "I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down to eat the food we've made." 

Flora, who is twelve, has some trouble with onions. She says, "I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really enjoyed it. My mum suggested I find a hobby instead of doing nothing on weekends. I was happy at home, so I wasn't very excited at first. But I'm really glad I decided to come." 

Their teacher, Philippe, says, "It's a lot of fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, even if the kitchen isn't always clean when they cook! As adults, we keep learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking when they are young, they will have the skills to cook for themselves when they leave home."

**Winter Driving**

Winter can be dangerous because it is hard to predict what will happen, and accidents can happen easily. Fog can appear suddenly over a hill, and ice can be hidden under melting snow, making it easy to lose control of your car. A car coming towards you might slide across the road unexpectedly.

**Rule Number One** for driving on icy roads is to drive smoothly. Quick or rough movements can make it hard to control your car. When you turn the wheel, brake, or speed up, do it gently and slowly. You can think of it like driving with a full cup of hot coffee next to you; drive carefully so you don’t spill it.

**Rule Number Two** is to pay attention to what could happen. The more ice there is, the further ahead you should look. Test how long it takes to stop by braking gently. Remember, you might be driving faster than you realize. Generally, you should allow double your normal stopping distance on wet roads, three times this distance on snow, and even more on ice. Always try to keep control of your car to avoid problems.

**Craigie Aitchison**

Craigie Aitchison was a painter from Scotland. He moved to London to study law but decided to go to art school instead. He found the traditional drawing classes hard, but he continued to paint. In his late twenties, the Italian government gave him money to study art, and he became interested in early Italian artists. This influence can be seen in some of his paintings. He loved the greens and browns of the Italian countryside and the bright light there, and he wanted to capture this light in his work.

To do this, he painted colors in thin layers from light to dark, but he admits he is never sure how it will turn out. He says, "It's a secret - because I don't know myself. I don't start by painting yellow, knowing I'm going to put anything on top." Like many talented artists, Aitchison makes it sound easy. He believes anyone can use colors because they can be bought. He simply pays attention to how colors look next to each other.

Unlike some artists, Aitchison does not make drawings before starting a painting. He feels that if he did, he might lose interest and not finish the painting. Instead, he often changes his paintings many times before they are complete. This is why he prefers to paint people who do not ask to see their portraits while he is working. He says, "If I feel they're worried and want to look at the painting, I can't do it."

Since moving to London, Aitchison has not felt connected to the Scottish art scene. He says he is not interested in following any tradition; he just paints in his own way. However, his work still inspires many young British painters.

**Rock Band**

Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked us for a drum set for his birthday. At first, we didn’t like the idea because of the noise. Ben argued, “It’s better than watching TV or playing video games in my free time, and it will keep me out of trouble.” In the end, we agreed. We said, “Okay, but you must think about the rest of the family and the neighbors when you play.”

That was just the start. Since drums are hard to move, Ben's band members began coming to our house with their guitars and other equipment. Now, for several hours each week, our house shakes with their music and singing. At least Ben's hobby is good for our health: whenever the band practices, my husband and I go for a long walk. 

I must admit that, even though their music can sound a bit strange, they are a friendly and polite group of young men. I can’t judge their musical talent—after all, I didn’t expect my parents to like the same music I did when I was a teenager—but they do play regularly in local clubs for young people. 

Our main concern is that they might not spend enough time on their schoolwork because of their music, but this hasn’t happened yet. I always remind Ben how important his studies are. One thing is clear: Ben was right; playing music has kept him out of trouble and he is never bored.

**Atlantic College**

Last week, I visited Atlantic College, a great private college in Wales. This college offers students important experiences outside the classroom, along with the chance to study for their exams. The students, aged 16 to 18 and from all over the world, study in the morning. In the afternoon, they participate in useful activities, such as helping on a farm, caring for people with learning difficulties, or checking rivers for pollution.

One of the best things about Atlantic College is that its students come from many different backgrounds and countries. Since the fees are £20,000 for two years, many students receive financial support. About a quarter of the students are British, and many of them can only attend because they get help from the government.

Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands, said, "I really admire the college for encouraging international understanding among young people. You learn to live with people and respect them, even those you don’t like. During the summer holidays, my mother couldn’t believe how much less I argued with my sister."

In conclusion, Atlantic College provides its students with an excellent education through methods that really work.

**Being an Older Student**

At 32 years old, I have just completed my first year at university. I attend lectures regularly and have learned to read books quickly and write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. As a secretary, I earned a decent salary, but I felt bored because my job did not challenge me. I became more and more unhappy, feeling stuck in my job. I envied the students at the local university who seemed happy, carefree, and excited about their future. I wanted to be part of that.

Now that I am a student, I find it difficult to connect with younger classmates. They often mistake me for a teacher and ask me questions I cannot answer. I also feel distant from the professors because, even though we are the same age, I know much less than they do. However, I am grateful for this chance to study because I understand that having a qualification is important for getting a good job.

Unlike most eighteen-year-olds, I prefer spending my weekends studying rather than going out to parties. I also enjoy the typical student benefits, like long holidays and discounts for theaters and cinemas. I sometimes worry about what I will do after university, but I hope that continuing my education at this age is a smart decision.

**Henry Ford**

Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863, but he did not enjoy farming. When he was fifteen, he started working as a mechanic. In 1893, he built his first car. After driving it for 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and made two larger cars. In 1903, he founded the Ford Motor Company. He used strong but light steel to create affordable cars for regular people. In 1908, he introduced the first Ford Model 'T', which cost $825. Soon, he was selling 100 cars every day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was valued at $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and inexpensive, but this simplicity sometimes meant fewer options. Henry Ford famously said about the Model T, "You can have any color you like, as long as it's black."

**Rebecca Stevens**

Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to climb Mount Everest. Before this achievement, she worked as a journalist and lived in a small apartment in south London. In 1993, Rebecca decided to leave her job and family to travel to Asia with a group of climbers. She discovered that life on Everest is very difficult. 

"You have to carry everything on your back," she said. "This means you can only take what you really need. You can't wash on the mountain, and in the end, I didn't even bring a toothbrush. I usually like to be clean, but there is no water, only snow. Water is very heavy, so you only take enough to drink!"

When Rebecca reached the top of Mount Everest on May 17, 1993, it was the happiest moment of her life. Suddenly, she became famous. Now, she has written a book about her journey, and people often invite her to speak about it. She also has a new job on a science program on television. 

Today, Rebecca is well-known and has more money, but she still lives in her small apartment in south London, surrounded by her pictures and books about mountains!

**CANADA GEESE**

Canada Geese are large birds with blue and white feathers. When autumn comes, they need to fly south to find warmer weather. The winters in Canada are very cold, and the birds can die if they stay there. 

Last spring, a man named Bill Lishman found sixteen young Canada Geese on his farm. These young birds had lost their parents. Bill thought, "These young birds won’t know how to fly south in autumn." He had a small plane, so he decided to teach the geese to follow him. 

All summer long, Bill took short flights in his plane, and the young geese flew after him. When autumn arrived and the weather got colder, Bill flew to Virginia in the United States, which is 600 miles south of his home in Canada. The geese followed him the whole way. 

After reaching Virginia, Bill left the geese there and returned home. This spring, he waited for the birds to come back, but they did not arrive. So, Bill flew back to Virginia to find them. He searched for two weeks but could not find them. 

When he returned home, Bill was surprised to see the geese waiting for him. They had found their way back home without his help!

**ESTHER'S STORY**

When Esther finished school at sixteen, her aunt Flory gave her £500 for her birthday. While most of Esther's friends chose to go to college, Esther decided to use her aunt's money to start her own business. She bought fruit, sugar, and glass jars to make her own jam. She sold the jam for £1 a jar to her friends and quickly made back her aunt's £500.

At first, Esther's parents were not happy with her decision. They wanted her to study and hoped she would become a teacher or a doctor. However, Esther ignored their advice and continued making jam. After a few months, she began selling her jam at the local market. She also started making orange juice, which she sold to a school where one of her friends worked.

After two years, her business grew very large, and her parents were proud of her. She made many different types of food and sold them to shops and supermarkets. She became so busy that she needed to hire some people to help her.

**Corryvale Farm**

Corryvale Farm is located in the west of England. Stephen and Jenny Blackler raise cows and chickens and sell milk and eggs. However, most of their income comes from Jenny's sheep. She has 50 sheep, and each sheep produces enough wool for six sweaters. Every six months, Stephen shears the wool from the sheep to keep them cool.

Five years ago, Jenny tried to sell sweaters made from the wool at country markets, but it was summer and too hot for people to buy sweaters. Instead, she made socks, which everyone loved because they were cheap, strong, and easy to wash. This is how Jenny's business began. 

At first, she made the socks at home, but soon she had thousands of customers. So, she started sending the wool to a factory, where machines now make all the socks. There are six colors, five sizes for all ages, and different types of socks for walkers, sportsmen, and skiers. 

Jenny is especially busy at Christmas because Corryvale socks are a popular gift. In her office, she has many letters from happy customers from all over the world.

**BURGLARS PREFER THE AFTERNOON**

Most house burglaries happen between 2 p.m. and 6 p.m., according to the police. Inspector Ian Saunders told our newspaper that the number of burglaries has increased by more than 30% compared to last year. He also mentioned that 67% of burglaries occur when people leave their homes and forget to close a door or a window. 

Night-time burglaries are rare because families are usually at home during that time. However, winter afternoons are the best for burglars because it gets dark, making it hard for them to be seen. Many houses are empty during this time since people are often still at work.

Inspector Saunders suggested that it is a good idea to leave lights on in living rooms and bedrooms when you go on holiday. This can help keep burglars away. He also encouraged neighbors to watch over each other’s houses when someone is not home and to call the police if they notice anything suspicious. 

"We will also give you tips on how to make your house safer," Inspector Saunders said. "This kind of help is free."

**The History of Farming**

Before farming started, people searched in forests for plants and fruits to eat. This meant they had to move around a lot to find food. About 12,000 years ago, in the Middle East, people began to grow their own food. These early farmers were the first to practice agriculture. 

Farming allowed people to stay in one place, and over time, their villages grew larger. Some villagers could then focus on other jobs, like making clothes, because the farmers provided food for everyone. However, farming was challenging, especially during bad weather, which sometimes led to food shortages.

Today, farmers can produce much more food, and it can travel thousands of kilometers from where it is grown to our homes.

**WORKING FOR AN AIRLINE**

Nicola Peet finished school at eighteen, went to college, and then worked at a local airport. After nine months, she started working for Saudi Arabian Airlines and later became an air hostess for British Airways. Four years later, she got her current job as a manager. "My office is at Heathrow Airport, but I spend 60% of my time in the air. I teach air hostesses and help them with any problems they have. I also attend many meetings. My working hours are usually from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., but sometimes I work from 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. 

At work, the first thing I do is check flight times on my computer, and then I talk with some of the air hostesses. Sometimes, I go on long flights to see how the air hostesses are doing. That is my favorite part of the job, but I also enjoy office work. Traveling can be tiring. When I return from a long trip, all I want to do is eat something and then go to bed! I don’t earn a lot of money, but I am happy with British Airways and want to stay there and keep traveling."

The Weather People study the weather for many reasons, and it is important for many jobs. For instance, the weather is very important for farmers. In the past, farmers spent a lot of time watching the sky, animals, and flowers to understand the weather better. Now, we have many computer programs that help us learn about the weather, and people can even get weather updates on their mobile phones. 

Today, many people still believe in old weather sayings. For example, some say that if the sky is red in the evening, it will be sunny the next day. Others think that if cows lie down in the fields, it will soon rain.

A great idea! Frazer and Peter are two 14-year-old boys from the same small town in Canada. They have always been friends and classmates. Like their other friends, they enjoy fishing and swimming on weekends. However, for the last few months, they have spent every weekend in Peter's room working on his laptop. This is not because they have a lot of homework. They have created a new computer word game. 

The idea for the game came from Frazer's little brother, Kevin, who has trouble with reading. Kevin learns words better when he can see pictures and hear sounds rather than just reading. His brother wanted to help him. Frazer and Peter worked together for over 200 hours to create this computer game, and now it is ready to use.

**How Does the Irish Pop Group 'Boyzone' Live a Healthy Life?**

Sleeping well is very important. When I can go back to my mother's house, I sleep for ten hours. However, after a concert, I find it hard to sleep because my mind is full of music. 

Sports are also important. Before my car accident, I went to the sports center for two and a half hours a day, five days a week. Now, I can't do that, so I do about 150 sit-ups every day. I do not drink alcohol or smoke, and I try to eat healthy food. I also drink a lot of water because it is good for your health. **Bollywood**

Bollywood is the name of the film industry in Mumbai, India. It produces almost 1,000 films every year. Since its first film in 1913, Bollywood has created over 29,000 films, making it the largest film industry in the world, much bigger than that of the USA. Many Indians prefer watching films to any other leisure activity, with ten million people going to the cinema every day.

Bollywood films often tell romantic love stories, and singing and dancing are important parts of these movies. Indian films are also popular outside of India. Last year, Bollywood earned over $500 million by selling its films to other countries. 

Indian actors make more films each year than American actors in Hollywood, but they earn less money. This is why most Bollywood films cost about $2 million to make, while Hollywood films usually cost at least $5 million. Most Bollywood actors are young and work hard, but they often have short careers. Amitabh Bachchan, who many consider India's greatest actor, is an exception. He has starred in more than 140 films over a career that has lasted almost 40 years.

Bill Bryson

I was born in the United States, but I have written many travel books about England. I lived in England with my wife and four children for 20 years. For the last three years, we have been back in the United States. Our children are now learning about life here, and I believe they will be happier because they have experienced living in two countries. I love Britain and want to return, but my daughter, Felicity, is starting college here soon, so we will not go back for another four years.

This experience is very different from my life in the United States when I am writing. In England, I was driven around in large cars and stayed in nice hotels. It was great because I did not have to pay for anything. Everyone was very kind to me, and I had a lot of fun.

**Schnauzer Dogs**

There are three sizes of Schnauzer dogs. The two smaller sizes came to England more than 50 years ago, but the Giant Schnauzer is newer to the country. The name "Giant" is fitting because these dogs are 65 to 67.5 cm tall. All Schnauzers have long hair that needs to be cut regularly. Most smaller Schnauzers are grey, while the Giant Schnauzer is usually black. 

Schnauzers come from Germany, where farmers use them to help with sheep. They are also used by the police because they are very intelligent. Schnauzers make great family pets. They are friendly and good with young children.

Mary stayed in the mountains for six weeks. Although it was hard work, she says it was the best experience she has ever had. She hopes to return next year to do more work there.

**The History of Horse Racing**

Horse racing has been an important sport since the earliest history books were written. It began in Central Asia around 4,500 years ago and was popular in ancient Greece and Rome. Modern horse racing started in the 12th century when Arab horses were brought to Europe. 

At first, races were long and only involved two horses. However, in the early 18th century, this changed. Races became shorter and included several horses competing against each other. 

Today, horse racing is one of the most-watched sports in the USA, second only to baseball. It is also very popular in many other parts of the world.

**Parrots**

You may have seen parrots, which are beautiful birds with bright colors and long tails, in forests or zoos. Parrots live in countries like Brazil, Australia, and India. They usually stay in large groups and enjoy eating fruit, which can sometimes cause problems for farmers.

There are many types of parrots, but they all have strong beaks and feet that help them climb and hold their food. Some of the largest parrots can live for up to 80 years. They are very loud, but they are also intelligent and can be taught to talk easily. Some zoos have parrot shows where you can watch these birds perform tricks they have learned.

HOWARD BONNIER

Bray is a lovely village about fifty kilometers west of London. A young Englishman named Howard Bonnier opened a restaurant called The Palace there about three and a half months ago. Not many people in Britain know Mr. Bonnier yet, but he is already quite famous in France. This is because he has written for French magazines about many of the best restaurants in that country. He enjoyed this so much that he chose to spend his money on visiting France and eating at good restaurants instead of buying many clothes and CDs. He also collected a lot of French and English cookbooks—he says he has more than two hundred and fifty!

**The Rhino**

There are five types of rhinos in the world today. The Black and White Rhinos live in the open fields of Africa, while the other types live in forests in Asia. All rhinos have large, heavy bodies. Their skin is very tough, and they have very little hair. A rhino stands on four short legs, and each foot has three toes. They usually walk slowly, but they can run at speeds of up to 50 kilometers per hour. 

Rhinos are generally quiet and calm animals, and they eat grass and other plants. A baby rhino weighs about 40 kilos when it is born and stays inside its mother for around fifteen months. An adult rhino can weigh over 200 kilos and may live for up to 50 years.

**THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE**

Today, we see policemen everywhere, but in 1700, London had no police force. A few old men tried to protect the streets at night, but they were not paid much. About 300 years ago, London was growing larger. The city was very dirty, and many people were poor. There were many thieves who stole money in the streets, so people preferred to stay at home.

In 1750, Henry Fielding began to pay a group of people to catch thieves. They were like policemen and were called the 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London had grown so much that it needed more police.

In 1829, the first Metropolitan Police Force was created with 3,000 officers. Most of the men worked on foot, but some rode horses. Until 1920, all police officers in London were men. Today, London police officers are paid well, and those who still ride horses earn even more than the others.

Visit the Edinburgh Festival! Every year, many people come to Edinburgh, the capital of Scotland, to enjoy the Edinburgh Festival. For three weeks in August and September, the city is full of actors and artists from around the world. They come to take part in the largest arts festival in Britain. During this time, the streets are filled with music and dance from morning until night. You can even see artists painting on the streets. 

One of the highlights of the Festival is the 'Fringe', where students perform comedy shows in small venues and cafes. Many tourists visit the Festival to watch new films, plays, and listen to music from famous musicians. This year, there are over five hundred performances featuring actors from more than forty countries. Tickets for these shows are quite affordable, and it is often easier to see your favorite star in Edinburgh than in London. 

So, plan to visit Edinburgh next summer! Just remember that finding a place to stay can be hard, so it’s a good idea to book your hotel now!

**ICE FISHING**

If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you will reach Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake freezes, and many Canadian fishermen go there every weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and paint them in bright colors. Inside these houses, they try to catch fish that swim under the ice.

Bob Marvisch has been coming here for twenty-five years during this season. He says, "You need clothes that are light but warm: two pairs of socks, gloves, several thin sweaters, and a snow suit on top. Catching fish is easy." 

To catch fish, first, you break the ice and make a small round hole. Then, you take a fishing line, put some bread on it, and lower it through the hole into the water. You pull the line up when the fish eat the bread. The fish are usually between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people like to eat them, but Bob prefers to have chocolate or another snack after catching three or four fish. 

Today, he has caught twenty-five! He thinks it is a great sport, and you can meet nice people while fishing!

Madame Tussaud's

One well-known place for tourists in London is Madame Tussaud's museum. In this museum, visitors can see wax figures of famous people. Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle, who was a doctor, made wax figures and opened a museum in Paris. Marie helped him with this work. 

In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie was sent to prison. While in prison, she had to create wax models of famous people who had died, including Queen Marie Antoinette. In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud, and in 1802, she moved to London with her wax figures. She opened a museum there, and her figures can still be seen today.

**BICYCLES**

Bicycles are an affordable and environmentally friendly way to travel. The first bicycle was created about 150 years ago. At that time, bicycles were very expensive, so only wealthy people could afford them. These early bicycles looked quite different from the ones we use today. 

As bicycles became cheaper, more people started to buy them. Many began to ride bicycles to work and for leisure. Nowadays, people often use cars instead of bicycles because cars are faster and keep you dry in the rain. However, some people still choose to cycle to work. They believe there are too many cars in city centers, making it hard to find parking.

The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop, age 14

Last summer, I went to Thailand for a beach holiday with my family. One day, we visited a park near our hotel. The park had beautiful flower gardens, but we were excited to see the elephant show. 

We went to a large area with seats on three sides. Three elephants came in with their trainers and stood in front of a big piece of white card. Each elephant was given a paintbrush and started to paint on its own card. The trainers would give them a new brush with paint and take away the old one. Slowly, following their trainers' instructions, the elephants created pictures on the cards. I couldn’t believe my eyes! One picture showed a river, another a tree, and the third a bunch of flowers. When the trainers held up the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one.

We also gave the elephants the bananas we had brought for our lunch. Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they do not work there anymore, but the smartest elephants live in special centers where visitors can watch them.

**Big Cats**

There are many types of cats, and they vary in size, appearance, and behavior. Tigers are the largest cats, measuring up to 3.7 meters from head to tail. While most cats avoid water, tigers often enjoy lying in pools when it is hot outside. 

Lions are unique because they live in large family groups. These groups work together to hunt for food. Lions usually inhabit flat, open areas where they can see far and easily track other animals. 

All cats have excellent eyesight, which helps them catch smaller animals for food. They also need to be fast and strong.

**THE OSTRICH**

The ostrich is the largest bird in the world, and an adult can weigh more than 90 kilos. Most wild ostriches live in southern Africa, but there are only a few left in the wild. Like all birds, ostriches have wings, but they cannot fly. They use their wings to help them turn while running. Ostriches can run very fast, at speeds of 65 to 90 kilometers per hour, making it hard for other animals to catch them. Baby ostriches are about the same size as chickens and take around 3 years to grow into adults. Ostriches eat plants and can survive for many days without water.

**Snowboarding**

Victoria Jamieson is a 23-year-old snowboarder from Britain. She started snowboarding when she was 20 and has won many competitions. Last week, we talked to her at a snowboarding competition in Switzerland. We asked her why she began snowboarding. She said, "I have always enjoyed sports, especially skiing, so it felt natural to try snowboarding. It’s easy to learn, and you can get really good in just a few months."

We also asked her about practice. She replied, "In winter, I snowboard in the mountains every day from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also run and bike. I love all of it! I enjoy the competitions and being in the mountains because it is so beautiful. But for me, free-riding—doing what you want when you’re not in a competition—is the best part."

Finally, we asked her what is important when learning to snowboard. She explained, "You can learn quickly, but you need lessons. It’s also important to wear the right clothes so you don’t get wet, especially because you will fall a lot at first!"

**Mount Kilimanjaro**

Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. Many people have climbed it, including a seven-year-old boy and an 87-year-old man. There are different paths to reach the top. The Marangu path, which is five kilometers long, is considered the easiest. It usually takes about five days to climb and is very popular with tourists. 

However, only half of the climbers who attempt to reach the summit succeed. This is often due to sudden changes in the weather. At the start of the climb, it can be hot and rainy, but when climbers reach the top, they encounter ice and snow, and the temperature can drop below 20 degrees Celsius. Therefore, climbers should bring both sunglasses and warm clothing!

**Otters**

Not many people have seen an otter. These animals live near rivers and build their homes using small pieces of wood. They usually come out at night. Otters are excellent swimmers and can swim faster than 10 kilometers per hour. They have thick brown fur that keeps them warm in the water. An otter can close its ears and nose, which allows them to stay underwater for several minutes.

Twenty years ago, there were very few otters in Great Britain. The rivers were very dirty, which caused many fish and insects to die, leaving otters without food. However, today there is plenty of food for them because the rivers are clean again.

**Buildings**

People have always built structures. We need houses to keep us warm and dry, and we create stadiums to watch football matches and concerts. Other buildings, like museums, are used to display beautiful items. 

Many people work together to create a building. The architect decides how the building will look and draws plans to show their ideas. Engineers ensure that the building is strong and safe. Then, workers carefully construct it.

The Sydney Opera House is a famous modern building known for its beautiful roof. However, the building is attractive from all sides, not just the top. Another well-known roof is on the Olympic Stadium in Munich, which looks like a glass tent.

The Cerne Giant

Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in the south of England that are close to each other. Between these towns, there are many green hills and fields. On one of these hills, there is a large image of a man. This man is called the Cerne Giant because the nearby village is named Cerne. No one knows exactly when the Cerne Giant was created, but it is believed to be a very long time ago. You can walk from Cerne to get closer to the picture. If you visit on the first of May at sunrise, you will see the villagers dancing around the giant on the hill.

Gail Rollins is one of the best runners in Edinburgh. This summer, she wants to compete in the 10,000 metres and maybe the 5,000 metres at the European Championships. In the past, Gail was known for finishing second in big competitions. She always smiled and laughed, which made people in her city love her. However, everything changed in 2004 when she ran her first half-marathon, a long road race. She won with a very good time, the fastest of any British woman that year.

Gail's manager and husband, Mike Rollins, used to race when he was younger, but he had to stop because he hurt his right leg. He can still run a little and sometimes trains with Gail, but it’s not fun for him when she runs faster and leaves him behind.

Gail trains hard. She does a long run in the morning and fast runs in the afternoon, but she always takes Sundays off from running. Mike says, "I am with her all the time. Sometimes I ask, 'Are you sure you should be eating that?' It's usually cakes, but she can eat almost anything."

**Piano Players - Their Early Years**

**Ivan Petrov**  
Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From the age of twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher could not play the piano but taught him and his sister songs from operas. His mother started teaching him the piano when he was six years old. At the age of ten, he decided he wanted to write music and soon began working on his first song.

**Oleg Gagarin**  
Oleg was the youngest of five children. When he was four, his father, who enjoyed playing the piano, taught him some traditional Russian music. At six, he began taking lessons from a piano teacher in his city. Oleg quickly started winning prizes for his piano playing. When he was fourteen, he attended a music college in Austria for two years before returning to Russia.

**Josef Heptmann**  
Josef's father was German and taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two years old, and he started playing the piano a year later. He gave his first concert at the age of six. When he was ten, he performed fifty-two concerts in two months during a trip to England! Josef loved music but was also interested in physics and languages. Although he is very busy now, he hopes to write his own music one day.

**Bill Prince-Smith**

Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer, a teacher, and a dentist before he became a writer of children's books at the age of 60. Now, thirteen years later, he has written more than 80 books. Every day, he goes to his office to write. In the evening, he gives his work to his wife to read. "She tells me when she doesn't like something," says Bill. His ten grandchildren do not live nearby, but they also read his stories and give their opinions on them. This helps Bill understand what young children want to read.

Bill writes about life in his village and the farms around it. His favorite book is his fifth one, called *The Sheepdog*, which is about a farmer and the dog that helps him. "I have always liked animals," says Bill, "and dogs are very clever; they learn quickly." Last year, this book was made into a film with real animals and actors. The filmmakers used the latest computer technology to make it look like the animals are speaking. Bill was very happy with the film. "Sometimes filmmakers change books, but they didn't change mine, and I love the film."

**POSTCARDS**

Today, many people enjoy sending postcards to their friends and family. These postcards usually have images of beaches, mountains, or castles, and you can write a message on the back. A lot of people send postcards while they are on holiday because they are inexpensive, and the pictures are often nicer than the photos people take themselves.

The first postcard was sent at the end of the 1800s. It had a picture of a seaside town. Later, postcards featured images related to current events, like accidents or visits from important people. People liked these postcards because newspapers at that time did not include many pictures.

Dinosaurs

No one has ever seen a dinosaur because the last one died about 60 million years ago, long before people existed on Earth. We do not know exactly why they all disappeared. The closest living relatives of dinosaurs are birds. 

Dinosaurs were not all the same; there were more than 5,000 different kinds. Some were very small, while others were huge. The largest dinosaurs were bigger than any other land animals that have ever lived. For example, the Brontosaurus was twenty meters long and ate plants. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was not as long, but it was very strong. It had sharp teeth for eating meat and could run fast because it had long back legs.

**Bears**

Bears can be dangerous animals. An adult bear is very strong and can harm a person. They are good at climbing trees and can run very fast. However, bears do not see well, and like many animals, they use their sense of smell to find food.

There are seven types of bears. The largest is the polar bear, which can be almost three meters tall. There are two types of black bears: one lives in the forests of North America, and the other is found in South-East Asia. Not all black bears are actually black; some can be dark brown or reddish-brown.

Many people love the black and white panda bear, which comes from China. Unfortunately, not many pandas live in the wild today because it is hard for them to find food.

CROCODILES

Crocodiles live in warm areas of the world, such as Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They usually stay in slow-moving water, but they can swim quickly and also move fast on land. You often see crocodiles in large groups. They eat many things, including fish, birds, and small animals. Sometimes, they even eat larger animals or people.

There are more than ten different types of crocodiles, and they all have very sharp teeth. They often lose their teeth, but they grow new ones quickly. Most crocodiles are about 3.5 meters long, but some can be much larger. Crocodiles can live for a long time; the oldest one in a zoo lived to be 66 years old.

A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL

In 1783, two French brothers created the first balloon that could carry people into the sky. One hundred and twenty years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers built the first powered airplane and flew it in the United States. In 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service. 

Over the next thirty years, airplanes changed a lot. In the 1950s, they became much faster because they were equipped with jet engines. In 1976, Concorde was built in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger plane in the world, flying at 2,500 kilometers per hour, which means the trip from London to New York takes only four hours. 

Today, millions of people travel by airplane, and it is hard to imagine a world without them.

The Globe Theatre

Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was very different from today. The building was round and had no roof, so people could get cold and wet if it rained. The queen enjoyed going to the Globe Theatre, located by the River Thames, to watch the plays of William Shakespeare. At that time, all the actors were men. Visitors would eat, talk to their friends, walk around during the show, and some even threw things at the actors! 

Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre has been built in the same place near the river. You can enjoy a Shakespeare play there or learn about life in the seventeenth century.
